00:17:29.156 --> 00:17:30.332
BG: Thank you.

00:17:30.356 --> 00:17:32.219
(Applause)

title: Capitalism will eat democracy -- unless we speak up
transcript: Democracy. In the West, we make a colossal mistake taking it for granted. We see democracy not as the most fragile of flowers that it really is, but we see it as part of our society's furniture. We tend to think of it as an intransigent given. We mistakenly believe that capitalism begets inevitably democracy. It doesn't.Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew and his great imitators in Beijing have demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt that it is perfectly possible to have a flourishing capitalism, spectacular growth, while politics remains democracy-free. Indeed, democracy is receding in our neck of the woods, here in Europe.Earlier this year, while I was representing Greece — the newly elected Greek government — in the Eurogroup as its Finance Minister, I was told in no uncertain terms that our nation's democratic process — our elections — could not be allowed to interfere with economic policies that were being implemented in Greece. At that moment, I felt that there could be no greater vindication of Lee Kuan Yew, or the Chinese Communist Party, indeed of some recalcitrant friends of mine who kept telling me that democracy would be banned if it ever threatened to change anything.Tonight, here, I want to present to you an economic case for an authentic democracy. I want to ask you to join me in believing again that Lee Kuan Yew, the Chinese Communist Party and indeed the Eurogroup are wrong in believing that we can dispense with democracy — that we need an authentic, boisterous democracy. And without democracy, our societies will be nastier, our future bleak and our great, new technologies wasted.Speaking of waste, allow me to point out an interesting paradox that is threatening our economies as we speak. I call it the twin peaks paradox. One peak you understand — you know it, you recognize it — is the mountain of debts that has been casting a long shadow over the United States, Europe, the whole world. We all recognize the mountain of debts. But few people discern its twin. A mountain of idle cash belonging to rich savers and to corporations, too terrified to invest it into the productive activities that can generate the incomes from which you can extinguish the mountain of debts and which can produce all those things that humanity desperately needs, like green energy.Now let me give you two numbers. Over the last three months, in the United States, in Britain and in the Eurozone, we have invested, collectively, 3.4 trillion dollars on all the wealth-producing goods — things like industrial plants, machinery, office blocks, schools, roads, railways, machinery, and so on and so forth. $3.4 trillion sounds like a lot of money until you compare it to the $5.1 trillion that has been slushing around in the same countries, in our financial institutions, doing absolutely nothing during the same period except inflating stock exchanges and bidding up house prices.So a mountain of debt and a mountain of idle cash form twin peaks,  failing to cancel each other out through the normal operation of the markets.The result is stagnant wages, more than a quarter of 25- to 54-year-olds in America, in Japan and in Europe out of work. And consequently, low aggregate demand, which in a never-ending cycle, reinforces the pessimism of the investors, who, fearing low demand, reproduce it by not investing — exactly like Oedipus' father, who, terrified by the prophecy of the oracle that his son would grow up to kill him, unwittingly engineered the conditions that ensured that Oedipus, his son, would kill him.This is my quarrel with capitalism. Its gross wastefulness, all this idle cash, should be energized to improve lives, to develop human talents, and indeed to finance all these technologies, green technologies, which are absolutely essential for saving planet Earth.Am I right in believing that democracy might be the answer? I believe so, but before we move on, what do we mean by democracy? Aristotle defined democracy as the constitution in which the free and the poor, being in the majority, control government.Now, of course Athenian democracy excluded too many. Women, migrants and, of course, the slaves. But it would be a mistake to dismiss the significance of ancient Athenian democracy on the basis of whom it excluded.What was more pertinent, and continues to be so about ancient Athenian democracy, was the inclusion of the working poor, who not only acquired the right to free speech, but more importantly, crucially, they acquired the rights to political judgments that were afforded equal weight in the decision-making concerning matters of state. Now, of course, Athenian democracy didn't last long. Like a candle that burns brightly, it burned out quickly. And indeed, our liberal democracies today do not have their roots in ancient Athens. They have their roots in the Magna Carta, in the 1688 Glorious Revolution, indeed in the American constitution. Whereas Athenian democracy was focusing on the masterless citizen and empowering the working poor, our liberal democracies are founded on the Magna Carta tradition, which was, after all, a charter for masters. And indeed, liberal democracy only surfaced when it was possible to separate fully the political sphere from the economic sphere, so as to confine the democratic process fully in the political sphere, leaving the economic sphere — the corporate world, if you want — as a democracy-free zone.Now, in our democracies today, this separation of the economic from the political sphere, the moment it started happening, it gave rise to an inexorable, epic struggle between the two, with the economic sphere colonizing the political sphere, eating into its power.Have you wondered why politicians are not what they used to be? It's not because their DNA has degenerated.(Laughter)It is rather because one can be in government today and not in power, because power has migrated from the political to the economic sphere, which is separate.Indeed, I spoke about my quarrel with capitalism. If you think about it, it is a little bit like a population of predators, that are so successful in decimating the prey that they must feed on, that in the end they starve.Similarly, the economic sphere has been colonizing and cannibalizing the political sphere to such an extent that it is undermining itself, causing economic crisis. Corporate power is increasing, political goods are devaluing, inequality is rising, aggregate demand is falling and CEOs of corporations are too scared to invest the cash of their corporations.So the more capitalism succeeds in taking the demos out of democracy, the taller the twin peaks and the greater the waste of human resources and humanity's wealth.Clearly, if this is right, we must reunite the political and economic spheres and better do it with a demos being in control, like in ancient Athens except without the slaves or the exclusion of women and migrants.Now, this is not an original idea. The Marxist left had that idea 100 years ago and it didn't go very well, did it?The lesson that we learned from the Soviet debacle is that only by a miracle will the working poor be reempowered, as they were in ancient Athens, without creating new forms of brutality and waste.But there is a solution: eliminate the working poor. Capitalism's doing it by replacing low-wage workers with automata, androids, robots. The problem is that as long as the economic and the political spheres are separate, automation makes the twin peaks taller, the waste loftier and the social conflicts deeper, including — soon, I believe — in places like China.So we need to reconfigure, we need to reunite the economic and the political spheres, but we'd better do it by democratizing the reunified sphere, lest we end up with a surveillance-mad hyperautocracy that makes The Matrix, the movie, look like a documentary.(Laughter)So the question is not whether capitalism will survive the technological innovations it is spawning. The more interesting question is whether capitalism will be succeeded by something resembling a Matrix dystopia or something much closer to a Star Trek-like society, where machines serve the humans and the humans expend their energies exploring the universe and indulging in long debates about the meaning of life in some ancient, Athenian-like, high tech agora.I think we can afford to be optimistic. But what would it take, what would it look like to have this Star Trek-like utopia, instead of the Matrix-like dystopia?In practical terms, allow me to share just briefly, a couple of examples.At the level of the enterprise, imagine a capital market, where you earn capital as you work, and where your capital follows you from one job to another, from one company to another, and the company — whichever one you happen to work at at that time — is solely owned by those who happen to work in it at that moment. Then all income stems from capital, from profits, and the very concept of wage labor becomes obsolete. No more separation between those who own but do not work in the company and those who work but do not own the company; no more tug-of-war between capital and labor; no great gap between investment and saving; indeed, no towering twin peaks.At the level of the global political economy, imagine for a moment that our national currencies have a free-floating exchange rate, with a universal, global, digital currency, one that is issued by the International Monetary Fund, the G-20, on behalf of all humanity. And imagine further that all international trade is denominated in this currency — let's call it "the cosmos," in units of cosmos — with every government agreeing to be paying into a common fund a sum of cosmos units proportional to the country's trade deficit, or indeed to a country's trade surplus. And imagine that that fund is utilized to invest in green technologies, especially in parts of the world where investment funding is scarce.This is not a new idea. It's what, effectively, John Maynard Keynes proposed in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference. The problem is that back then, they didn't have the technology to implement it. Now we do, especially in the context of a reunified political-economic sphere.The world that I am describing to you is simultaneously libertarian, in that it prioritizes empowered individuals, Marxist, since it will have confined to the dustbin of history the division between capital and labor, and Keynesian, global Keynesian. But above all else, it is a world in which we will be able to imagine an authentic democracy.Will such a world dawn? Or shall we descend into a Matrix-like dystopia? The answer lies in the political choice that we shall be making collectively. It is our choice, and we'd better make it democratically.Thank you.(Applause)Bruno Giussani: Yanis ... It was you who described yourself in your bios as a libertarian Marxist. What is the relevance of Marx's analysis today?Yanis Varoufakis: Well, if there was any relevance in what I just said, then Marx is relevant. Because the whole point of reunifying the political and economic is — if we don't do it, then technological innovation is going to create such a massive fall in aggregate demand,what Larry Summers refers to as secular stagnation. With this crisis migrating from one part of the world, as it is now, it will destabilize not only our democracies, but even the emerging world that is not that keen on liberal democracy. So if this analysis holds water, then Marx is absolutely relevant. But so is Hayek, that's why I'm a libertarian Marxist, and so is Keynes, so that's why I'm totally confused.(Laughter)BG: Indeed, and possibly we are too, now.(Laughter)(Applause)YV: If you are not confused, you are not thinking, OK?BG: That's a very, very Greek philosopher kind of thing to say —YV: That was Einstein, actually —BG: During your talk you mentioned Singapore and China, and last night at the speaker dinner, you expressed a pretty strong opinion about how the West looks at China. Would you like to share that?YV: Well, there's a great degree of hypocrisy. In our liberal democracies, we have a semblance of democracy. It's because we have confined, as I was saying in my talk, democracy to the political sphere, while leaving the one sphere where all the action is — the economic sphere — a completely democracy-free zone.In a sense, if I am allowed to be provocative, China today is closer to Britain in the 19th century. Because remember, we tend to associate liberalism with democracy — that's a mistake, historically. Liberalism, liberal, it's like John Stuart Mill. John Stuart Mill was particularly skeptical about the democratic process. So what you are seeing now in China is a very similar process to the one that we had in Britain during the Industrial Revolution, especially the transition from the first to the second. And to be castigating China for doing that which the West did in the 19th century, smacks of hypocrisy.BG: I am sure that many people here are wondering about your experience as the Finance Minister of Greece earlier this year.YV: I knew this was coming.BG: Yes.BG: Six months after, how do you look back at the first half of the year?YV: Extremely exciting, from a personal point of view, and very disappointing, because we had an opportunity to reboot the Eurozone. Not just Greece, the Eurozone. To move away from the complacency and the constant denial that there was a massive — and there is a massive architectural fault line going through the Eurozone, which is threatening, massively, the whole of the European Union process.We had an opportunity on the basis of the Greek program — which by the way, was the first program to manifest that denial — to put it right. And, unfortunately, the powers in the Eurozone, in the Eurogroup, chose to maintain denial.But you know what happens. This is the experience of the Soviet Union. When you try to keep alive an economic system that architecturally cannot survive, through political will and through authoritarianism, you may succeed in prolonging it, but when change happens it happens very abruptly and catastrophically.BG: What kind of change are you foreseeing?YV: Well, there's no doubt that if we don't change the architecture of the Eurozone, the Eurozone has no future.BG: Did you make any mistakes when you were Finance Minister?YV: Every day.BG: For example? YV: Anybody who looks back —(Applause)No, but seriously. If there's any Minister of Finance, or of anything else for that matter, who tells you after six months in a job, especially in such a stressful situation, that they have made no mistake, they're dangerous people. Of course I made mistakes.The greatest mistake was to sign the application for the extension of a loan agreement in the end of February. I was imagining that there was a genuine interest on the side of the creditors to find common ground. And there wasn't. They were simply interested in crushing our government, just because they did not want to have to deal with the architectural fault lines that were running through the Eurozone. And because they didn't want to admit that for five years they were implementing a catastrophic program in Greece. We lost one-third of our nominal GDP. This is worse than the Great Depression. And no one has come clean from the troika of lenders that have been imposing this policy to say, "This was a colossal mistake."BG: Despite all this, and despite the aggressiveness of the discussion, you seem to be remaining quite pro-European.YV: Absolutely. Look, my criticism of the European Union and the Eurozone comes from a person who lives and breathes Europe. My greatest fear is that the Eurozone will not survive. Because if it doesn't, the centrifugal forces that will be unleashed will be demonic, and they will destroy the European Union. And that will be catastrophic not just for Europe but for the whole global economy.We are probably the largest economy in the world. And if we allow ourselves to fall into a route of the postmodern 1930's, which seems to me to be what we are doing, then that will be detrimental to the future of Europeans and non-Europeans alike.BG: We definitely hope you are wrong on that point. Yanis, thank you for coming to TED.YV: Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.158 --> 00:00:14.358
Democracy.

00:00:14.918 --> 00:00:16.254
In the West,

00:00:16.278 --> 00:00:20.214
we make a colossal mistake
taking it for granted.

00:00:20.238 --> 00:00:21.534
We see democracy

00:00:21.558 --> 00:00:26.054
not as the most fragile
of flowers that it really is,

00:00:26.078 --> 00:00:28.918
but we see it as part
of our society's furniture.

00:00:29.918 --> 00:00:33.918
We tend to think of it
as an intransigent given.

00:00:34.638 --> 00:00:39.854
We mistakenly believe that capitalism
begets inevitably democracy.

00:00:39.878 --> 00:00:41.214
It doesn't.

00:00:41.238 --> 00:00:45.614
Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew
and his great imitators in Beijing

00:00:45.638 --> 00:00:48.574
have demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt

00:00:48.598 --> 00:00:52.494
that it is perfectly possible
to have a flourishing capitalism,

00:00:52.518 --> 00:00:54.118
spectacular growth,

00:00:54.918 --> 00:00:57.974
while politics remains democracy-free.

00:00:57.998 --> 00:01:02.414
Indeed, democracy is receding
in our neck of the woods,

00:01:02.438 --> 00:01:04.014
here in Europe.

00:01:04.038 --> 00:01:07.414
Earlier this year,
while I was representing Greece --

00:01:07.438 --> 00:01:10.174
the newly elected Greek government --

00:01:10.198 --> 00:01:12.894
in the Eurogroup as its Finance Minister,

00:01:12.918 --> 00:01:17.854
I was told in no uncertain terms
that our nation's democratic process --

00:01:17.878 --> 00:01:19.294
our elections --

00:01:19.318 --> 00:01:21.094
could not be allowed to interfere

00:01:21.118 --> 00:01:24.358
with economic policies
that were being implemented in Greece.

00:01:25.078 --> 00:01:26.294
At that moment,

00:01:26.318 --> 00:01:30.614
I felt that there could be no greater
vindication of Lee Kuan Yew,

00:01:30.638 --> 00:01:32.174
or the Chinese Communist Party,

00:01:32.198 --> 00:01:35.934
indeed of some recalcitrant
friends of mine who kept telling me

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:40.278
that democracy would be banned
if it ever threatened to change anything.

00:01:41.598 --> 00:01:44.854
Tonight, here, I want to present to you

00:01:44.878 --> 00:01:48.038
an economic case
for an authentic democracy.

00:01:48.558 --> 00:01:53.414
I want to ask you
to join me in believing again

00:01:53.438 --> 00:01:55.438
that Lee Kuan Yew,

00:01:56.438 --> 00:01:57.814
the Chinese Communist Party

00:01:57.838 --> 00:01:59.214
and indeed the Eurogroup

00:01:59.238 --> 00:02:02.878
are wrong in believing
that we can dispense with democracy --

00:02:03.558 --> 00:02:07.294
that we need an authentic,
boisterous democracy.

00:02:07.318 --> 00:02:10.294
And without democracy,

00:02:10.318 --> 00:02:13.174
our societies will be nastier,

00:02:13.198 --> 00:02:15.334
our future bleak

00:02:15.358 --> 00:02:18.174
and our great, new technologies wasted.

00:02:18.198 --> 00:02:19.454
Speaking of waste,

00:02:19.478 --> 00:02:22.253
allow me to point out
an interesting paradox

00:02:22.278 --> 00:02:25.054
that is threatening
our economies as we speak.

00:02:25.078 --> 00:02:27.374
I call it the twin peaks paradox.

00:02:27.398 --> 00:02:28.694
One peak you understand --

00:02:28.718 --> 00:02:30.334
you know it, you recognize it --

00:02:30.358 --> 00:02:35.414
is the mountain of debts
that has been casting a long shadow

00:02:35.438 --> 00:02:38.254
over the United States,
Europe, the whole world.

00:02:38.278 --> 00:02:40.158
We all recognize the mountain of debts.

00:02:40.838 --> 00:02:44.958
But few people discern its twin.

00:02:45.598 --> 00:02:47.798
A mountain of idle cash

00:02:48.798 --> 00:02:52.158
belonging to rich savers
and to corporations,

00:02:53.078 --> 00:02:55.654
too terrified to invest it

00:02:55.678 --> 00:02:58.974
into the productive activities
that can generate the incomes

00:02:58.998 --> 00:03:02.054
from which you can extinguish
the mountain of debts

00:03:02.078 --> 00:03:06.054
and which can produce all those things
that humanity desperately needs,

00:03:06.078 --> 00:03:07.734
like green energy.

00:03:07.758 --> 00:03:10.094
Now let me give you two numbers.

00:03:10.118 --> 00:03:11.454
Over the last three months,

00:03:11.478 --> 00:03:14.254
in the United States,
in Britain and in the Eurozone,

00:03:14.278 --> 00:03:18.694
we have invested, collectively,
3.4 trillion dollars

00:03:18.718 --> 00:03:21.374
on all the wealth-producing goods --

00:03:21.398 --> 00:03:24.414
things like industrial plants, machinery,

00:03:24.438 --> 00:03:26.654
office blocks, schools,

00:03:26.678 --> 00:03:29.814
roads, railways, machinery,
and so on and so forth.

00:03:29.838 --> 00:03:32.574
$3.4 trillion sounds like a lot of money

00:03:32.598 --> 00:03:36.454
until you compare it to the $5.1 trillion

00:03:36.478 --> 00:03:39.174
that has been slushing around
in the same countries,

00:03:39.198 --> 00:03:41.014
in our financial institutions,

00:03:41.038 --> 00:03:44.238
doing absolutely nothing
during the same period

00:03:45.398 --> 00:03:50.254
except inflating stock exchanges
and bidding up house prices.

00:03:50.278 --> 00:03:55.534
So a mountain of debt
and a mountain of idle cash

00:03:55.558 --> 00:03:59.254
form twin peaks, 
failing to cancel each other out

00:03:59.278 --> 00:04:02.094
through the normal
operation of the markets.

00:04:02.118 --> 00:04:04.438
The result is stagnant wages,

00:04:05.318 --> 00:04:10.974
more than a quarter of 25- to 54-year-olds
in America, in Japan and in Europe

00:04:10.998 --> 00:04:12.494
out of work.

00:04:12.518 --> 00:04:14.854
And consequently, low aggregate demand,

00:04:14.878 --> 00:04:17.094
which in a never-ending cycle,

00:04:17.118 --> 00:04:19.838
reinforces the pessimism of the investors,

00:04:20.838 --> 00:04:24.654
who, fearing low demand,
reproduce it by not investing --

00:04:24.678 --> 00:04:27.374
exactly like Oedipus' father,

00:04:27.398 --> 00:04:29.893
who, terrified
by the prophecy of the oracle

00:04:29.917 --> 00:04:32.654
that his son would grow up to kill him,

00:04:32.678 --> 00:04:34.614
unwittingly engineered the conditions

00:04:34.638 --> 00:04:37.638
that ensured that Oedipus,
his son, would kill him.

00:04:38.518 --> 00:04:40.518
This is my quarrel with capitalism.

00:04:41.158 --> 00:04:43.174
Its gross wastefulness,

00:04:43.198 --> 00:04:44.814
all this idle cash,

00:04:44.838 --> 00:04:48.934
should be energized to improve lives,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.294
to develop human talents,

00:04:50.318 --> 00:04:53.174
and indeed to finance
all these technologies,

00:04:53.198 --> 00:04:54.454
green technologies,

00:04:54.478 --> 00:04:57.238
which are absolutely essential
for saving planet Earth.

00:04:58.238 --> 00:05:01.494
Am I right in believing
that democracy might be the answer?

00:05:01.518 --> 00:05:02.734
I believe so,

00:05:02.758 --> 00:05:03.974
but before we move on,

00:05:03.998 --> 00:05:05.398
what do we mean by democracy?

00:05:06.478 --> 00:05:08.894
Aristotle defined democracy

00:05:08.918 --> 00:05:13.854
as the constitution
in which the free and the poor,

00:05:13.878 --> 00:05:16.038
being in the majority, control government.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:20.254
Now, of course Athenian democracy
excluded too many.

00:05:20.278 --> 00:05:23.318
Women, migrants and,
of course, the slaves.

00:05:23.998 --> 00:05:25.254
But it would be a mistake

00:05:25.278 --> 00:05:28.854
to dismiss the significance
of ancient Athenian democracy

00:05:28.878 --> 00:05:30.878
on the basis of whom it excluded.

00:05:31.638 --> 00:05:32.894
What was more pertinent,

00:05:32.918 --> 00:05:36.774
and continues to be so
about ancient Athenian democracy,

00:05:36.798 --> 00:05:40.294
was the inclusion of the working poor,

00:05:40.318 --> 00:05:45.014
who not only acquired
the right to free speech,

00:05:45.038 --> 00:05:47.294
but more importantly, crucially,

00:05:47.318 --> 00:05:49.934
they acquired the rights
to political judgments

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.334
that were afforded equal weight

00:05:52.358 --> 00:05:56.014
in the decision-making
concerning matters of state.

00:05:56.038 --> 00:05:59.094
Now, of course, Athenian
democracy didn't last long.

00:05:59.118 --> 00:06:03.534
Like a candle that burns brightly,
it burned out quickly.

00:06:03.558 --> 00:06:04.774
And indeed,

00:06:04.798 --> 00:06:09.054
our liberal democracies today
do not have their roots in ancient Athens.

00:06:09.078 --> 00:06:11.414
They have their roots in the Magna Carta,

00:06:11.438 --> 00:06:14.694
in the 1688 Glorious Revolution,

00:06:14.718 --> 00:06:16.934
indeed in the American constitution.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:21.974
Whereas Athenian democracy
was focusing on the masterless citizen

00:06:21.998 --> 00:06:24.278
and empowering the working poor,

00:06:25.198 --> 00:06:29.374
our liberal democracies are founded
on the Magna Carta tradition,

00:06:29.398 --> 00:06:32.494
which was, after all,
a charter for masters.

00:06:32.518 --> 00:06:36.814
And indeed, liberal democracy
only surfaced when it was possible

00:06:36.838 --> 00:06:40.694
to separate fully the political sphere
from the economic sphere,

00:06:40.718 --> 00:06:45.774
so as to confine the democratic process
fully in the political sphere,

00:06:45.798 --> 00:06:47.654
leaving the economic sphere --

00:06:47.678 --> 00:06:49.614
the corporate world, if you want --

00:06:49.638 --> 00:06:52.318
as a democracy-free zone.

00:06:53.678 --> 00:06:56.654
Now, in our democracies today,

00:06:56.678 --> 00:07:00.174
this separation of the economic
from the political sphere,

00:07:00.198 --> 00:07:02.454
the moment it started happening,

00:07:02.478 --> 00:07:06.774
it gave rise to an inexorable,
epic struggle between the two,

00:07:06.798 --> 00:07:10.014
with the economic sphere
colonizing the political sphere,

00:07:10.038 --> 00:07:11.558
eating into its power.

00:07:12.438 --> 00:07:15.838
Have you wondered why politicians
are not what they used to be?

00:07:16.518 --> 00:07:18.934
It's not because their DNA
has degenerated.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.574
(Laughter)

00:07:20.598 --> 00:07:25.214
It is rather because one can be
in government today and not in power,

00:07:25.238 --> 00:07:28.534
because power has migrated
from the political to the economic sphere,

00:07:28.558 --> 00:07:29.798
which is separate.

00:07:31.118 --> 00:07:32.694
Indeed,

00:07:32.718 --> 00:07:35.014
I spoke about my quarrel
with capitalism.

00:07:35.038 --> 00:07:36.774
If you think about it,

00:07:36.798 --> 00:07:40.118
it is a little bit like
a population of predators,

00:07:41.038 --> 00:07:45.758
that are so successful in decimating
the prey that they must feed on,

00:07:46.518 --> 00:07:48.654
that in the end they starve.

00:07:48.678 --> 00:07:49.894
Similarly,

00:07:49.918 --> 00:07:53.614
the economic sphere has been colonizing
and cannibalizing the political sphere

00:07:53.638 --> 00:07:57.014
to such an extent
that it is undermining itself,

00:07:57.038 --> 00:07:58.774
causing economic crisis.

00:07:58.798 --> 00:08:00.894
Corporate power is increasing,

00:08:00.918 --> 00:08:03.134
political goods are devaluing,

00:08:03.158 --> 00:08:04.974
inequality is rising,

00:08:04.998 --> 00:08:06.574
aggregate demand is falling

00:08:06.598 --> 00:08:12.718
and CEOs of corporations are too scared
to invest the cash of their corporations.

00:08:13.478 --> 00:08:20.134
So the more capitalism succeeds
in taking the demos out of democracy,

00:08:20.158 --> 00:08:21.494
the taller the twin peaks

00:08:21.518 --> 00:08:25.054
and the greater the waste
of human resources

00:08:25.078 --> 00:08:26.518
and humanity's wealth.

00:08:27.598 --> 00:08:30.454
Clearly, if this is right,

00:08:30.478 --> 00:08:33.534
we must reunite the political
and economic spheres

00:08:33.558 --> 00:08:37.054
and better do it
with a demos being in control,

00:08:37.078 --> 00:08:40.014
like in ancient Athens
except without the slaves

00:08:40.038 --> 00:08:42.998
or the exclusion of women and migrants.

00:08:44.078 --> 00:08:45.814
Now, this is not an original idea.

00:08:45.838 --> 00:08:48.613
The Marxist left
had that idea 100 years ago

00:08:48.637 --> 00:08:50.318
and it didn't go very well, did it?

00:08:50.798 --> 00:08:54.214
The lesson that we learned
from the Soviet debacle

00:08:54.238 --> 00:09:00.574
is that only by a miracle
will the working poor be reempowered,

00:09:00.598 --> 00:09:02.574
as they were in ancient Athens,

00:09:02.598 --> 00:09:06.358
without creating new forms
of brutality and waste.

00:09:06.918 --> 00:09:08.158
But there is a solution:

00:09:08.838 --> 00:09:10.678
eliminate the working poor.

00:09:11.318 --> 00:09:12.574
Capitalism's doing it

00:09:12.598 --> 00:09:17.478
by replacing low-wage workers
with automata, androids, robots.

00:09:19.038 --> 00:09:20.254
The problem is

00:09:20.278 --> 00:09:23.494
that as long as the economic
and the political spheres are separate,

00:09:23.518 --> 00:09:27.838
automation makes the twin peaks taller,

00:09:28.598 --> 00:09:30.334
the waste loftier

00:09:30.358 --> 00:09:32.414
and the social conflicts deeper,

00:09:32.438 --> 00:09:33.638
including --

00:09:34.278 --> 00:09:35.814
soon, I believe --

00:09:35.838 --> 00:09:37.438
in places like China.

00:09:38.678 --> 00:09:41.094
So we need to reconfigure,

00:09:41.118 --> 00:09:44.774
we need to reunite the economic
and the political spheres,

00:09:44.798 --> 00:09:50.174
but we'd better do it
by democratizing the reunified sphere,

00:09:50.198 --> 00:09:55.894
lest we end up with
a surveillance-mad hyperautocracy

00:09:55.918 --> 00:09:59.934
that makes The Matrix, the movie,
look like a documentary.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.534
(Laughter)

00:10:01.558 --> 00:10:04.974
So the question is not
whether capitalism will survive

00:10:04.998 --> 00:10:07.318
the technological innovations
it is spawning.

00:10:07.918 --> 00:10:09.534
The more interesting question

00:10:09.558 --> 00:10:15.294
is whether capitalism will be succeeded
by something resembling a Matrix dystopia

00:10:15.318 --> 00:10:19.734
or something much closer
to a Star Trek-like society,

00:10:19.758 --> 00:10:22.134
where machines serve the humans

00:10:22.158 --> 00:10:26.574
and the humans expend their energies
exploring the universe

00:10:26.598 --> 00:10:30.894
and indulging in long debates
about the meaning of life

00:10:30.918 --> 00:10:34.918
in some ancient, Athenian-like,
high tech agora.

00:10:36.318 --> 00:10:39.758
I think we can afford to be optimistic.

00:10:41.358 --> 00:10:42.654
But what would it take,

00:10:42.678 --> 00:10:44.654
what would it look like

00:10:44.678 --> 00:10:49.558
to have this Star Trek-like utopia,
instead of the Matrix-like dystopia?

00:10:50.198 --> 00:10:51.454
In practical terms,

00:10:51.478 --> 00:10:53.214
allow me to share just briefly,

00:10:53.238 --> 00:10:54.438
a couple of examples.

00:10:55.038 --> 00:10:56.814
At the level of the enterprise,

00:10:56.838 --> 00:10:59.174
imagine a capital market,

00:10:59.198 --> 00:11:01.878
where you earn capital as you work,

00:11:02.838 --> 00:11:08.174
and where your capital follows you
from one job to another,

00:11:08.198 --> 00:11:09.694
from one company to another,

00:11:09.718 --> 00:11:10.974
and the company --

00:11:10.998 --> 00:11:14.454
whichever one you happen
to work at at that time --

00:11:14.478 --> 00:11:18.798
is solely owned by those who happen
to work in it at that moment.

00:11:19.358 --> 00:11:24.054
Then all income stems
from capital, from profits,

00:11:24.078 --> 00:11:28.454
and the very concept
of wage labor becomes obsolete.

00:11:28.478 --> 00:11:35.094
No more separation between those
who own but do not work in the company

00:11:35.118 --> 00:11:38.374
and those who work
but do not own the company;

00:11:38.398 --> 00:11:41.598
no more tug-of-war
between capital and labor;

00:11:42.398 --> 00:11:46.534
no great gap between
investment and saving;

00:11:46.558 --> 00:11:49.798
indeed, no towering twin peaks.

00:11:50.558 --> 00:11:52.934
At the level of the global
political economy,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.894
imagine for a moment

00:11:54.918 --> 00:11:59.894
that our national currencies
have a free-floating exchange rate,

00:11:59.918 --> 00:12:03.694
with a universal,
global, digital currency,

00:12:03.718 --> 00:12:07.734
one that is issued
by the International Monetary Fund,

00:12:07.758 --> 00:12:08.974
the G-20,

00:12:08.998 --> 00:12:11.534
on behalf of all humanity.

00:12:11.558 --> 00:12:12.774
And imagine further

00:12:12.798 --> 00:12:17.134
that all international trade
is denominated in this currency --

00:12:17.158 --> 00:12:18.974
let's call it "the cosmos,"

00:12:18.998 --> 00:12:20.398
in units of cosmos --

00:12:21.678 --> 00:12:26.054
with every government agreeing
to be paying into a common fund

00:12:26.078 --> 00:12:31.614
a sum of cosmos units proportional
to the country's trade deficit,

00:12:31.638 --> 00:12:35.038
or indeed to a country's trade surplus.

00:12:35.678 --> 00:12:40.894
And imagine that that fund is utilized
to invest in green technologies,

00:12:40.918 --> 00:12:46.238
especially in parts of the world
where investment funding is scarce.

00:12:46.798 --> 00:12:48.374
This is not a new idea.

00:12:48.398 --> 00:12:51.734
It's what, effectively,
John Maynard Keynes proposed

00:12:51.758 --> 00:12:55.078
in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference.

00:12:56.038 --> 00:12:57.254
The problem is

00:12:57.278 --> 00:13:00.574
that back then, they didn't have
the technology to implement it.

00:13:00.598 --> 00:13:01.814
Now we do,

00:13:01.838 --> 00:13:07.758
especially in the context
of a reunified political-economic sphere.

00:13:08.598 --> 00:13:11.014
The world that I am describing to you

00:13:11.038 --> 00:13:13.494
is simultaneously libertarian,

00:13:13.518 --> 00:13:18.094
in that it prioritizes
empowered individuals,

00:13:18.118 --> 00:13:19.334
Marxist,

00:13:19.358 --> 00:13:22.574
since it will have confined
to the dustbin of history

00:13:22.598 --> 00:13:25.054
the division between capital and labor,

00:13:25.078 --> 00:13:26.638
and Keynesian,

00:13:27.278 --> 00:13:28.758
global Keynesian.

00:13:30.278 --> 00:13:31.854
But above all else,

00:13:31.878 --> 00:13:36.798
it is a world in which we will be able
to imagine an authentic democracy.

00:13:37.718 --> 00:13:39.478
Will such a world dawn?

00:13:40.358 --> 00:13:44.854
Or shall we descend
into a Matrix-like dystopia?

00:13:44.878 --> 00:13:48.998
The answer lies in the political choice
that we shall be making collectively.

00:13:49.678 --> 00:13:51.294
It is our choice,

00:13:51.318 --> 00:13:53.638
and we'd better make it democratically.

00:13:54.238 --> 00:13:55.494
Thank you.

00:13:55.518 --> 00:13:58.878
(Applause)

00:14:01.438 --> 00:14:02.638
Bruno Giussani: Yanis ...

00:14:03.838 --> 00:14:08.278
It was you who described yourself
in your bios as a libertarian Marxist.

00:14:10.358 --> 00:14:12.878
What is the relevance
of Marx's analysis today?

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:17.294
Yanis Varoufakis: Well, if there was
any relevance in what I just said,

00:14:17.318 --> 00:14:18.534
then Marx is relevant.

00:14:18.558 --> 00:14:22.054
Because the whole point of reunifying
the political and economic is --

00:14:22.078 --> 00:14:23.294
if we don't do it,

00:14:23.318 --> 00:14:25.574
then technological innovation
is going to create

00:14:25.598 --> 00:14:27.894
such a massive fall in aggregate demand,

00:14:27.918 --> 00:14:32.694
what Larry Summers
refers to as secular stagnation.

00:14:32.718 --> 00:14:35.574
With this crisis migrating
from one part of the world,

00:14:35.598 --> 00:14:37.134
as it is now,

00:14:37.158 --> 00:14:39.854
it will destabilize
not only our democracies,

00:14:39.878 --> 00:14:44.094
but even the emerging world that is not
that keen on liberal democracy.

00:14:44.118 --> 00:14:47.934
So if this analysis holds water,
then Marx is absolutely relevant.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.694
But so is Hayek,

00:14:49.718 --> 00:14:51.534
that's why I'm a libertarian Marxist,

00:14:51.558 --> 00:14:52.774
and so is Keynes,

00:14:52.798 --> 00:14:54.694
so that's why I'm totally confused.

00:14:54.718 --> 00:14:55.934
(Laughter)

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.014
BG: Indeed, and possibly we are too, now.

00:14:58.038 --> 00:14:59.334
(Laughter)

00:14:59.358 --> 00:15:01.334
(Applause)

00:15:01.358 --> 00:15:04.134
YV: If you are not confused,
you are not thinking, OK?

00:15:04.158 --> 00:15:07.254
BG: That's a very, very Greek
philosopher kind of thing to say --

00:15:07.278 --> 00:15:08.934
YV: That was Einstein, actually --

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.574
BG: During your talk
you mentioned Singapore and China,

00:15:11.598 --> 00:15:13.654
and last night at the speaker dinner,

00:15:13.678 --> 00:15:18.854
you expressed a pretty strong opinion
about how the West looks at China.

00:15:18.878 --> 00:15:20.454
Would you like to share that?

00:15:20.478 --> 00:15:22.638
YV: Well, there's a great
degree of hypocrisy.

00:15:23.358 --> 00:15:27.654
In our liberal democracies,
we have a semblance of democracy.

00:15:27.678 --> 00:15:30.414
It's because we have confined,
as I was saying in my talk,

00:15:30.438 --> 00:15:32.094
democracy to the political sphere,

00:15:32.118 --> 00:15:35.574
while leaving the one sphere
where all the action is --

00:15:35.598 --> 00:15:36.814
the economic sphere --

00:15:36.838 --> 00:15:38.678
a completely democracy-free zone.

00:15:39.238 --> 00:15:40.494
In a sense,

00:15:40.518 --> 00:15:42.718
if I am allowed to be provocative,

00:15:43.838 --> 00:15:48.254
China today is closer to Britain
in the 19th century.

00:15:48.278 --> 00:15:49.534
Because remember,

00:15:49.558 --> 00:15:51.894
we tend to associate
liberalism with democracy --

00:15:51.918 --> 00:15:53.414
that's a mistake, historically.

00:15:53.438 --> 00:15:55.974
Liberalism, liberal,
it's like John Stuart Mill.

00:15:55.998 --> 00:16:00.694
John Stuart Mill was particularly
skeptical about the democratic process.

00:16:00.718 --> 00:16:06.094
So what you are seeing now in China
is a very similar process

00:16:06.118 --> 00:16:09.294
to the one that we had in Britain
during the Industrial Revolution,

00:16:09.318 --> 00:16:12.294
especially the transition
from the first to the second.

00:16:12.318 --> 00:16:15.614
And to be castigating China

00:16:15.638 --> 00:16:18.774
for doing that which the West did
in the 19th century,

00:16:18.798 --> 00:16:20.118
smacks of hypocrisy.

00:16:21.478 --> 00:16:25.134
BG: I am sure that many people here
are wondering about your experience

00:16:25.158 --> 00:16:27.894
as the Finance Minister of Greece
earlier this year.

00:16:27.918 --> 00:16:29.299
YV: I knew this was coming.

00:16:29.323 --> 00:16:30.574
BG: Yes.

00:16:30.598 --> 00:16:31.934
BG: Six months after,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.358
how do you look back
at the first half of the year?

00:16:35.878 --> 00:16:38.494
YV: Extremely exciting,
from a personal point of view,

00:16:38.518 --> 00:16:39.774
and very disappointing,

00:16:39.798 --> 00:16:43.694
because we had an opportunity
to reboot the Eurozone.

00:16:43.718 --> 00:16:45.814
Not just Greece, the Eurozone.

00:16:45.838 --> 00:16:48.774
To move away from the complacency

00:16:48.798 --> 00:16:51.254
and the constant denial
that there was a massive --

00:16:51.278 --> 00:16:54.134
and there is a massive
architectural fault line

00:16:54.158 --> 00:16:56.334
going through the Eurozone,

00:16:56.358 --> 00:17:00.774
which is threatening, massively,
the whole of the European Union process.

00:17:00.798 --> 00:17:03.974
We had an opportunity
on the basis of the Greek program --

00:17:03.998 --> 00:17:05.334
which by the way,

00:17:05.358 --> 00:17:09.734
was the first program
to manifest that denial --

00:17:09.758 --> 00:17:10.974
to put it right.

00:17:10.998 --> 00:17:12.214
And, unfortunately,

00:17:12.238 --> 00:17:14.054
the powers in the Eurozone,

00:17:14.078 --> 00:17:15.278
in the Eurogroup,

00:17:16.037 --> 00:17:18.014
chose to maintain denial.

00:17:18.037 --> 00:17:19.294
But you know what happens.

00:17:19.317 --> 00:17:21.373
This is the experience
of the Soviet Union.

00:17:21.398 --> 00:17:23.893
When you try to keep alive

00:17:23.918 --> 00:17:27.797
an economic system
that architecturally cannot survive,

00:17:28.478 --> 00:17:31.133
through political will
and through authoritarianism,

00:17:31.158 --> 00:17:32.814
you may succeed in prolonging it,

00:17:32.838 --> 00:17:34.413
but when change happens

00:17:34.438 --> 00:17:36.934
it happens very abruptly
and catastrophically.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.965
BG: What kind of change
are you foreseeing?

00:17:38.989 --> 00:17:40.243
YV: Well, there's no doubt

00:17:40.267 --> 00:17:42.934
that if we don't change
the architecture of the Eurozone,

00:17:42.959 --> 00:17:44.853
the Eurozone has no future.

00:17:44.878 --> 00:17:47.774
BG: Did you make any mistakes
when you were Finance Minister?

00:17:47.798 --> 00:17:49.014
YV: Every day.

00:17:49.038 --> 00:17:51.574
BG: For example?
YV: Anybody who looks back --

00:17:51.598 --> 00:17:53.678
(Applause)

00:17:56.078 --> 00:17:57.454
No, but seriously.

00:17:57.478 --> 00:18:01.054
If there's any Minister of Finance,
or of anything else for that matter,

00:18:01.078 --> 00:18:03.294
who tells you after six months in a job,

00:18:03.318 --> 00:18:07.014
especially in such a stressful situation,

00:18:07.038 --> 00:18:09.734
that they have made no mistake,
they're dangerous people.

00:18:09.758 --> 00:18:11.054
Of course I made mistakes.

00:18:11.078 --> 00:18:13.894
The greatest mistake
was to sign the application

00:18:13.918 --> 00:18:16.014
for the extension of a loan agreement

00:18:16.038 --> 00:18:17.654
in the end of February.

00:18:17.678 --> 00:18:18.894
I was imagining

00:18:18.918 --> 00:18:21.894
that there was a genuine interest
on the side of the creditors

00:18:21.918 --> 00:18:23.174
to find common ground.

00:18:23.198 --> 00:18:24.414
And there wasn't.

00:18:24.438 --> 00:18:27.054
They were simply interested
in crushing our government,

00:18:27.078 --> 00:18:28.534
just because they did not want

00:18:28.558 --> 00:18:31.694
to have to deal with
the architectural fault lines

00:18:31.718 --> 00:18:33.734
that were running through the Eurozone.

00:18:33.758 --> 00:18:35.574
And because they didn't want to admit

00:18:35.598 --> 00:18:39.214
that for five years they were implementing
a catastrophic program in Greece.

00:18:39.238 --> 00:18:42.134
We lost one-third of our nominal GDP.

00:18:42.158 --> 00:18:44.094
This is worse than the Great Depression.

00:18:44.118 --> 00:18:45.374
And no one has come clean

00:18:45.398 --> 00:18:48.334
from the troika of lenders
that have been imposing this policy

00:18:48.358 --> 00:18:51.334
to say, "This was a colossal mistake."

00:18:51.358 --> 00:18:52.574
BG: Despite all this,

00:18:52.598 --> 00:18:54.934
and despite the aggressiveness
of the discussion,

00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:57.374
you seem to be remaining
quite pro-European.

00:18:57.398 --> 00:18:58.614
YV: Absolutely.

00:18:58.638 --> 00:19:02.774
Look, my criticism
of the European Union and the Eurozone

00:19:02.798 --> 00:19:06.838
comes from a person
who lives and breathes Europe.

00:19:07.638 --> 00:19:11.214
My greatest fear is that
the Eurozone will not survive.

00:19:11.238 --> 00:19:12.694
Because if it doesn't,

00:19:12.718 --> 00:19:15.574
the centrifugal forces
that will be unleashed

00:19:15.598 --> 00:19:17.294
will be demonic,

00:19:17.318 --> 00:19:19.294
and they will destroy the European Union.

00:19:19.318 --> 00:19:21.734
And that will be catastrophic
not just for Europe

00:19:21.758 --> 00:19:23.374
but for the whole global economy.

00:19:23.398 --> 00:19:27.494
We are probably the largest
economy in the world.

00:19:27.518 --> 00:19:29.254
And if we allow ourselves

00:19:29.278 --> 00:19:32.094
to fall into a route
of the postmodern 1930's,

00:19:32.118 --> 00:19:34.774
which seems to me to be what we are doing,

00:19:34.798 --> 00:19:36.614
then that will be detrimental

00:19:36.638 --> 00:19:40.054
to the future of Europeans
and non-Europeans alike.

00:19:40.078 --> 00:19:42.494
BG: We definitely hope
you are wrong on that point.

00:19:42.518 --> 00:19:44.214
Yanis, thank you for coming to TED.

00:19:44.238 --> 00:19:45.454
YV: Thank you.

00:19:45.478 --> 00:19:50.301
(Applause)

title: Glow-in-the-dark sharks and other stunning sea creatures
transcript: I'm a marine biologist and an explorer-photographer with National Geographic, but I want to share a secret. This image is totally incorrect, totally incorrect. I see a couple of people crying in the back that I've blown their idea of mermaids. All right, the mermaid is indeed real, but anyone who's gone on a dive will know that the ocean looks more like this. It's because the ocean is this massive filter, and as soon as you start going underwater, you're going to lose your colors, and it's going to get dark and blue very quickly.But we're humans — we're terrestrial mammals. And we've got trichromatic vision, so we see in red, green and blue, and we're just complete color addicts. We love eye-popping color, and we try to bring this eye-popping color underwater with us.So there's been a long and sordid history of bringing color underwater, and it starts 88 years ago with Bill Longley and Charles Martin, who were trying to take the first underwater color photograph. And they're in there with old-school scuba suits, where you're pumping air down to them, and they've got a pontoon of high-explosive magnesium powder, and the poor people at the surface are not sure when they're going to pull the string when they've got their frame in focus, and — boom! — a pound of high explosives would go off so they could put a little bit of light underwater and get an image like this beautiful hogfish. I mean, it's a gorgeous image, but this is not real. They're creating an artificial environment so we can satisfy our own addiction to color.And looking at it the other way, what we've been finding is that instead of bringing color underwater with us, that we've been looking at the blue ocean, and it's a crucible of blue, and these animals living there for millions of years have been evolving all sorts of ways to take in that blue light and give off other colors. And here's just a little sample of what this secret world looks like. It's like an underwater light show.(Music)Again, what we're seeing here is blue light hitting this image. These animals are absorbing the blue light and immediately transforming this light.So if you think about it, the ocean is 71 percent of the planet, and blue light can extend down to almost a 1,000 meters. As we go down underwater, after about 10 meters, all the red is gone. So if you see anything under 10 meters that's red, it's an animal transforming and creating its own red. This is the largest single monochromatic blue environment on our planet.And my gateway into this world of biofluorescence begins with corals. And I want to give a full TED Talk on corals and just how cool these things are. One of the things that they do, one of their miraculous feats, is they produce lots of these fluorescent proteins, fluorescent molecules. And in this coral, it could be making up to 14 percent of its body mass — could be this fluorescent protein. So you wouldn't be making, like, 14 percent muscle and not using it, so it's likely doing something that has a functional role. And for the last 10, 15 years, this was so special to me, because this molecule has turned out to be one of the most revolutionary tools in biomedical science, and it's allowing us to better see inside ourselves.So, how do I study this? In order to study biofluorescence, we swim at night. And when I started out, I was just using these blue duct-tape filters over my strobe, so I could make sure I'm actually seeing the light that's being transformed by the animals. We're making an exhibit for the Museum of Natural History, and we're trying to show off how great the fluorescent corals are on the reef, and something happened that just blew me away: this. In the middle of our corals, is this green fluorescent fish. It's the first time we've ever seen a green fluorescent fish or any vertebrate for that matter. And we're rubbing our eyes, checking the filters, thinking that somebody's maybe playing a joke on us with the camera, but the eel was real.It was the first green fluorescent eel that we found, and this just changed my trajectory completely. So I had to put down my corals and team up with a fish scientist, John Sparks, and begin a search around the world to see how prevalent this phenomenon is. And fish are much more interesting than corals, because they have really advanced vision, and some of the fish even have, the way that I was photographing it, they have lenses in their eyes that would magnify the fluorescence. So I wanted to seek this out further.So we designed a new set of gear and we're scouring the reefs around the world, looking for fluorescent life. And it's a bit like "E.T. phone home." We're out there swimming with this blue light, and we're looking for a response, for animals to be absorbing the light and transferring this back to us. And eventually, we found our photobombing Kaupichphys eel. It's a really shy, reclusive eel that we know almost nothing about. They're only about the size of my finger, and they spend about 99.9 percent of their time hidden under a rock. But these eels do come out to mate under full-moon nights, and that full-moon night translates underwater to blue. Perhaps they're using this as a way to see each other, quickly find each other, mate, go back into their hole for the next long stint of time. But then we started to find other fluorescent marine life, like this green fluorescent bream, with its, like, racing stripes along its head and its nape, and it's almost camouflaged and fluorescing at the same intensity as the fluorescent coral there.After this fish, we were introduced to this red fluorescent scorpionfish cloaked and hidden on this rock. The only time we've ever seen this, it's either on red fluorescent algae or red fluorescent coral.Later, we found this stealthy green fluorescent lizardfish. These lizardfish come in many varieties, and they look almost exactly alike under white light. But if you look at them under fluorescent light, you see lots of patterns, you can really see the differences among them. And in total — we just reported this last year — we found over 200 species of biofluorescent fish.One of my inspirations is French artist and biologist Jean Painlevé. He really captures this entrepreneuring, creative spirit in biology. He would design his own gear, make his own cameras, and he was fascinated with the seahorse, Hippocampus erectus, and he filmed for the first time the seahorse giving birth. So this is the male seahorse. They were one of the first fish to start swimming upright with their brain above their head. The males give birth, just phenomenal creatures. So he stayed awake for days. He even put this electrical visor on his head that would shock him, so he could capture this moment. Now, I wish I could have shown Painlevé the moment where we found biofluorescent seahorses in the exact same species that he was studying. And here's our footage.(Music)They're the most cryptic fish. You could be swimming right on top of them and not see the seahorse. They would blend right into the algae, which would also fluoresce red, but they've got great vision, and they go through this long mating ritual, and perhaps they're using it in that effect.But things got pretty edgy when we found green fluorescence in the stingray, because stingrays are in the Elasmobranch class, which includes ... sharks. So I'm, like, a coral biologist. Somebody's got to go down and check to see if the sharks are fluorescent. And there I am.(Laughter)And I was like, "Maybe I should go back to corals."(Laughter)It turns out that these sharks are not fluorescent. And then we found it. In a deep, dark canyon off the coast of California, we found the first biofluorescent swellshark, right underneath all the surfers. Here it is. They're just about a meter long. It's called a swellshark. And they call them a swellshark because if they're threatened, they can gulp down water and blow up like an inner tube, about twice their size, and wedge themselves under a rock, so they don't get eaten by a predator. And here is our first footage of these biofluorescent swellsharks. Just magnificent — I mean, they're showing these distinct patterns, and there are areas that are fluorescent and areas that are not fluorescent, but they've also got these twinkling spots on them that are much brighter than other parts of the shark.But this is all beautiful to see. I was like, this is gorgeous. But what does it mean to the shark? Can they see this? And we looked in the literature, and nothing was known about this shark's vision. So I took this shark to eye specialist Ellis Loew at Cornell University, and we found out that this shark sees discretely and acutely in the blue-green interface, probably about 100 times better than we can see in the dark, but they only see blue-green. So what it's doing is taking this blue world and it's absorbing the blue, creating green. It's creating contrast that they can indeed see. So we have a model, showing that it creates an ability for them to see all these patterns. And males and females also have, we're finding, distinct patterns among them.But our last find came really just a few miles from where we are now, in the Solomon Islands. Swimming at night, I encountered the first biofluorescent sea turtle. So now it's going from fish and sharks into reptiles, which, again, this is only one month old, but it shows us that we know almost nothing about this hawksbill turtle's vision. And it makes me think about how much more there is to learn. And here in the Solomon Islands, there's only a few thousand breeding females of this species left, and this is one of the hotspots for them. So it shows us how much we need to really protect these animals while they're still here, and understand them.In thinking about biofluorescence, I wanted to know, how deep does it go? Does this go all the way to the bottom of the ocean? So we started using submarines, and we equipped them with special blue lights on the front here. And we dropped down, and we noticed one important thing — that as we get down to 1,000 meters, it drops off. There's no biofluorescent marine life down there, below 1,000 meters — almost nothing, it's just darkness. So it's mainly a shallow phenomenon. And below 1,000 meters, we encountered the bioluminescent zone, where nine out of 10 animals are actually making their own lights and flashing and blinking.As I try to get deeper, this is slapping on a one-person submarine suit — some people call this my "Jacques Cousteau meets Woody Allen" moment.(Laughter)But as we explore down here, I was thinking about: How do we interact with life delicately? Because we're entering a new age of exploration, where we have to take great care, and we have to set examples how we explore. So I've teamed up with roboticist Rob Wood at Harvard University, and we've been designing squishy underwater robot fingers, so we can delicately interact with the marine life down there. The idea is that most of our technologies to explore the deep ocean come from oil and gas and military, who, you know, they're not really caring to be gentle. Some corals could be 1,000 years old. You don't want to just go and crush them with a big claw. So my dream is something like this. At night, I'm in a submarine, I have force-feedback gloves, and I could delicately set up a lab in the front of my submarine, where the squishy robot fingers are delicately collecting and putting things in jars, and we can conduct our research.Back to the powerful applied applications. Here, you're looking at a living brain that's using the DNA of fluorescent marine creatures, this one from jellyfish and corals, to illuminate the living brain and see its connections. It's funny that we're using RGB just to kind of satisfy our own human intuition, so we can see our brains better. And even more mind-blowing, is my close colleague Vincent Pieribone at Yale, who has actually designed and engineered a fluorescent protein that responds to voltage. So he could see when a single neuron fires. You're essentially looking at a portal into consciousness that was designed by marine creatures.So this brings me all back to perspective and relationship. From deep space, our universe looks like a human brain cell, and then here we are in the deep ocean, and we're finding marine creatures and cells that can illuminate the human mind. And it's my hope that with illuminated minds, we could ponder the overarching interconnectedness of all life, and fathom how much more lies in store if we keep our oceans healthy.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.696 --> 00:00:15.856
I'm a marine biologist
and an explorer-photographer

00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:17.621
with National Geographic,

00:00:17.645 --> 00:00:19.323
but I want to share a secret.

00:00:19.751 --> 00:00:23.394
This image is totally incorrect,

00:00:23.418 --> 00:00:25.155
totally incorrect.

00:00:25.179 --> 00:00:27.306
I see a couple of people
crying in the back

00:00:27.330 --> 00:00:29.774
that I've blown their idea of mermaids.

00:00:29.798 --> 00:00:32.449
All right, the mermaid is indeed real,

00:00:32.473 --> 00:00:34.608
but anyone who's gone on a dive

00:00:34.632 --> 00:00:37.230
will know that the ocean
looks more like this.

00:00:37.725 --> 00:00:41.225
It's because the ocean
is this massive filter,

00:00:41.249 --> 00:00:43.322
and as soon as you start going underwater,

00:00:43.346 --> 00:00:45.019
you're going to lose your colors,

00:00:45.043 --> 00:00:48.249
and it's going to get dark
and blue very quickly.

00:00:48.273 --> 00:00:51.058
But we're humans --
we're terrestrial mammals.

00:00:51.082 --> 00:00:53.257
And we've got trichromatic vision,

00:00:53.281 --> 00:00:55.947
so we see in red, green and blue,

00:00:55.971 --> 00:00:58.296
and we're just complete color addicts.

00:00:58.320 --> 00:01:00.963
We love eye-popping color,

00:01:00.987 --> 00:01:03.574
and we try to bring this eye-popping color

00:01:03.598 --> 00:01:04.978
underwater with us.

00:01:05.002 --> 00:01:09.039
So there's been a long and sordid history
of bringing color underwater,

00:01:09.063 --> 00:01:14.009
and it starts 88 years ago
with Bill Longley and Charles Martin,

00:01:14.033 --> 00:01:16.954
who were trying to take
the first underwater color photograph.

00:01:16.978 --> 00:01:19.693
And they're in there
with old-school scuba suits,

00:01:19.717 --> 00:01:21.842
where you're pumping air down to them,

00:01:21.866 --> 00:01:27.456
and they've got a pontoon
of high-explosive magnesium powder,

00:01:27.480 --> 00:01:29.687
and the poor people
at the surface are not sure

00:01:29.711 --> 00:01:33.341
when they're going to pull the string
when they've got their frame in focus,

00:01:33.365 --> 00:01:36.289
and -- boom! -- a pound
of high explosives would go off

00:01:36.313 --> 00:01:39.368
so they could put
a little bit of light underwater

00:01:39.392 --> 00:01:42.162
and get an image
like this beautiful hogfish.

00:01:42.186 --> 00:01:45.035
I mean, it's a gorgeous image,
but this is not real.

00:01:45.059 --> 00:01:47.818
They're creating an artificial environment

00:01:47.842 --> 00:01:51.518
so we can satisfy
our own addiction to color.

00:01:51.954 --> 00:01:55.782
And looking at it the other way,
what we've been finding

00:01:55.806 --> 00:01:59.010
is that instead of bringing color
underwater with us,

00:01:59.034 --> 00:02:01.786
that we've been looking at the blue ocean,

00:02:01.810 --> 00:02:04.072
and it's a crucible of blue,

00:02:04.096 --> 00:02:07.192
and these animals living there
for millions of years

00:02:07.216 --> 00:02:11.746
have been evolving all sorts of ways
to take in that blue light

00:02:11.770 --> 00:02:13.461
and give off other colors.

00:02:13.485 --> 00:02:16.771
And here's just a little sample
of what this secret world looks like.

00:02:16.795 --> 00:02:18.673
It's like an underwater light show.

00:02:18.697 --> 00:02:22.781
(Music)

00:02:23.453 --> 00:02:27.373
Again, what we're seeing here
is blue light hitting this image.

00:02:27.397 --> 00:02:29.486
These animals are absorbing the blue light

00:02:29.510 --> 00:02:31.991
and immediately transforming this light.

00:02:35.348 --> 00:02:39.721
So if you think about it, the ocean
is 71 percent of the planet,

00:02:39.745 --> 00:02:43.815
and blue light can extend down
to almost a 1,000 meters.

00:02:43.839 --> 00:02:45.943
As we go down underwater,

00:02:45.967 --> 00:02:48.661
after about 10 meters,
all the red is gone.

00:02:48.685 --> 00:02:51.888
So if you see anything
under 10 meters that's red,

00:02:51.912 --> 00:02:54.970
it's an animal transforming
and creating its own red.

00:02:55.430 --> 00:03:01.683
This is the largest single monochromatic
blue environment on our planet.

00:03:02.628 --> 00:03:07.318
And my gateway into this world
of biofluorescence begins with corals.

00:03:07.342 --> 00:03:09.428
And I want to give
a full TED Talk on corals

00:03:09.452 --> 00:03:11.254
and just how cool these things are.

00:03:11.278 --> 00:03:14.500
One of the things that they do,
one of their miraculous feats,

00:03:14.524 --> 00:03:17.302
is they produce lots of these
fluorescent proteins,

00:03:17.326 --> 00:03:18.811
fluorescent molecules.

00:03:18.835 --> 00:03:23.582
And in this coral, it could be making
up to 14 percent of its body mass --

00:03:23.606 --> 00:03:25.691
could be this fluorescent protein.

00:03:25.715 --> 00:03:30.144
So you wouldn't be making, like,
14 percent muscle and not using it,

00:03:30.168 --> 00:03:33.752
so it's likely doing something
that has a functional role.

00:03:33.776 --> 00:03:37.613
And for the last 10, 15 years,
this was so special to me,

00:03:37.637 --> 00:03:43.057
because this molecule has turned out
to be one of the most revolutionary tools

00:03:43.081 --> 00:03:44.781
in biomedical science,

00:03:44.805 --> 00:03:48.319
and it's allowing us
to better see inside ourselves.

00:03:49.422 --> 00:03:51.763
So, how do I study this?

00:03:51.787 --> 00:03:54.858
In order to study biofluorescence,
we swim at night.

00:03:54.882 --> 00:03:56.260
And when I started out,

00:03:56.284 --> 00:04:00.295
I was just using these blue
duct-tape filters over my strobe,

00:04:00.319 --> 00:04:02.698
so I could make sure
I'm actually seeing the light

00:04:02.722 --> 00:04:04.754
that's being transformed by the animals.

00:04:04.778 --> 00:04:08.255
We're making an exhibit
for the Museum of Natural History,

00:04:08.279 --> 00:04:12.086
and we're trying to show off how great
the fluorescent corals are on the reef,

00:04:12.110 --> 00:04:15.166
and something happened
that just blew me away:

00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:16.579
this.

00:04:16.603 --> 00:04:18.419
In the middle of our corals,

00:04:18.443 --> 00:04:21.449
is this green fluorescent fish.

00:04:21.473 --> 00:04:24.285
It's the first time we've ever seen
a green fluorescent fish

00:04:24.309 --> 00:04:25.936
or any vertebrate for that matter.

00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:28.515
And we're rubbing our eyes,
checking the filters,

00:04:28.539 --> 00:04:31.738
thinking that somebody's maybe
playing a joke on us with the camera,

00:04:31.762 --> 00:04:33.705
but the eel was real.

00:04:33.729 --> 00:04:37.268
It was the first green
fluorescent eel that we found,

00:04:37.292 --> 00:04:40.251
and this just changed
my trajectory completely.

00:04:40.275 --> 00:04:43.609
So I had to put down my corals and team up

00:04:43.633 --> 00:04:45.666
with a fish scientist, John Sparks,

00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:48.189
and begin a search around the world

00:04:48.213 --> 00:04:51.464
to see how prevalent this phenomenon is.

00:04:51.488 --> 00:04:53.963
And fish are much more
interesting than corals,

00:04:53.987 --> 00:04:56.201
because they have really advanced vision,

00:04:56.225 --> 00:05:00.010
and some of the fish even have,
the way that I was photographing it,

00:05:00.034 --> 00:05:03.470
they have lenses in their eyes
that would magnify the fluorescence.

00:05:03.494 --> 00:05:05.804
So I wanted to seek this out further.

00:05:05.828 --> 00:05:07.550
So we designed a new set of gear

00:05:07.574 --> 00:05:09.863
and we're scouring the reefs
around the world,

00:05:09.887 --> 00:05:11.466
looking for fluorescent life.

00:05:11.490 --> 00:05:13.545
And it's a bit like "E.T. phone home."

00:05:13.569 --> 00:05:16.278
We're out there swimming
with this blue light,

00:05:16.302 --> 00:05:18.507
and we're looking for a response,

00:05:18.531 --> 00:05:22.106
for animals to be absorbing the light
and transferring this back to us.

00:05:22.130 --> 00:05:26.842
And eventually, we found
our photobombing Kaupichphys eel.

00:05:26.866 --> 00:05:31.336
It's a really shy, reclusive eel
that we know almost nothing about.

00:05:31.360 --> 00:05:33.321
They're only about the size of my finger,

00:05:33.345 --> 00:05:37.825
and they spend about 99.9 percent
of their time hidden under a rock.

00:05:37.849 --> 00:05:41.970
But these eels do come out to mate
under full-moon nights,

00:05:41.994 --> 00:05:45.487
and that full-moon night
translates underwater to blue.

00:05:45.511 --> 00:05:48.041
Perhaps they're using this
as a way to see each other,

00:05:48.065 --> 00:05:49.526
quickly find each other, mate,

00:05:49.550 --> 00:05:53.264
go back into their hole
for the next long stint of time.

00:05:53.288 --> 00:05:56.168
But then we started to find
other fluorescent marine life,

00:05:56.192 --> 00:05:58.989
like this green fluorescent bream,

00:05:59.013 --> 00:06:02.998
with its, like, racing stripes
along its head and its nape,

00:06:03.022 --> 00:06:07.323
and it's almost camouflaged
and fluorescing at the same intensity

00:06:07.347 --> 00:06:09.133
as the fluorescent coral there.

00:06:10.148 --> 00:06:12.235
After this fish,

00:06:12.259 --> 00:06:16.560
we were introduced to this red
fluorescent scorpionfish

00:06:16.584 --> 00:06:18.727
cloaked and hidden on this rock.

00:06:18.751 --> 00:06:22.552
The only time we've ever seen this,
it's either on red fluorescent algae

00:06:22.576 --> 00:06:24.251
or red fluorescent coral.

00:06:24.592 --> 00:06:29.925
Later, we found this stealthy
green fluorescent lizardfish.

00:06:29.949 --> 00:06:32.037
These lizardfish come in many varieties,

00:06:32.061 --> 00:06:35.330
and they look almost exactly alike
under white light.

00:06:35.354 --> 00:06:37.728
But if you look at them
under fluorescent light,

00:06:37.752 --> 00:06:39.153
you see lots of patterns,

00:06:39.177 --> 00:06:41.863
you can really see
the differences among them.

00:06:41.887 --> 00:06:44.824
And in total -- we just reported
this last year --

00:06:44.848 --> 00:06:49.196
we found over 200 species
of biofluorescent fish.

00:06:50.093 --> 00:06:56.019
One of my inspirations is French artist
and biologist Jean Painlevé.

00:06:56.043 --> 00:07:00.092
He really captures this entrepreneuring,
creative spirit in biology.

00:07:00.116 --> 00:07:03.919
He would design his own gear,
make his own cameras,

00:07:03.943 --> 00:07:07.937
and he was fascinated with the seahorse,
Hippocampus erectus,

00:07:07.961 --> 00:07:11.188
and he filmed for the first time
the seahorse giving birth.

00:07:12.044 --> 00:07:13.596
So this is the male seahorse.

00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:18.334
They were one of the first fish
to start swimming upright

00:07:18.358 --> 00:07:19.986
with their brain above their head.

00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:21.161
The males give birth,

00:07:21.185 --> 00:07:22.605
just phenomenal creatures.

00:07:24.913 --> 00:07:26.255
So he stayed awake for days.

00:07:26.279 --> 00:07:29.454
He even put this electrical visor
on his head that would shock him,

00:07:29.478 --> 00:07:31.070
so he could capture this moment.

00:07:32.754 --> 00:07:34.874
Now, I wish I could have shown Painlevé

00:07:34.898 --> 00:07:37.995
the moment where we found
biofluorescent seahorses

00:07:38.019 --> 00:07:40.718
in the exact same species
that he was studying.

00:07:40.742 --> 00:07:41.956
And here's our footage.

00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:44.807
(Music)

00:07:46.434 --> 00:07:47.901
They're the most cryptic fish.

00:07:47.925 --> 00:07:51.305
You could be swimming right on top of them
and not see the seahorse.

00:07:52.186 --> 00:07:56.694
They would blend right into the algae,
which would also fluoresce red,

00:07:56.718 --> 00:07:58.179
but they've got great vision,

00:07:58.203 --> 00:08:00.377
and they go through
this long mating ritual,

00:08:00.401 --> 00:08:02.503
and perhaps they're using it
in that effect.

00:08:03.605 --> 00:08:06.524
But things got pretty edgy

00:08:07.400 --> 00:08:12.413
when we found green
fluorescence in the stingray,

00:08:12.437 --> 00:08:15.201
because stingrays are
in the Elasmobranch class,

00:08:15.225 --> 00:08:16.464
which includes ...

00:08:17.033 --> 00:08:18.492
sharks.

00:08:18.516 --> 00:08:21.714
So I'm, like, a coral biologist.

00:08:22.119 --> 00:08:25.564
Somebody's got to go down and check
to see if the sharks are fluorescent.

00:08:25.588 --> 00:08:26.850
And there I am.

00:08:26.874 --> 00:08:28.272
(Laughter)

00:08:28.296 --> 00:08:30.835
And I was like, "Maybe I should
go back to corals."

00:08:30.859 --> 00:08:31.891
(Laughter)

00:08:31.915 --> 00:08:34.311
It turns out that these sharks
are not fluorescent.

00:08:35.431 --> 00:08:36.847
And then we found it.

00:08:36.871 --> 00:08:41.709
In a deep, dark canyon
off the coast of California,

00:08:41.733 --> 00:08:46.170
we found the first
biofluorescent swellshark,

00:08:46.194 --> 00:08:47.969
right underneath all the surfers.

00:08:47.993 --> 00:08:49.178
Here it is.

00:08:49.202 --> 00:08:51.926
They're just about a meter long.
It's called a swellshark.

00:08:51.950 --> 00:08:54.862
And they call them a swellshark
because if they're threatened,

00:08:54.886 --> 00:08:57.632
they can gulp down water
and blow up like an inner tube,

00:08:57.656 --> 00:08:58.815
about twice their size,

00:08:58.839 --> 00:09:03.584
and wedge themselves under a rock,
so they don't get eaten by a predator.

00:09:04.116 --> 00:09:08.259
And here is our first footage
of these biofluorescent swellsharks.

00:09:09.187 --> 00:09:13.908
Just magnificent -- I mean,
they're showing these distinct patterns,

00:09:13.932 --> 00:09:17.505
and there are areas that are fluorescent
and areas that are not fluorescent,

00:09:17.529 --> 00:09:20.118
but they've also got these
twinkling spots on them

00:09:20.142 --> 00:09:22.733
that are much brighter
than other parts of the shark.

00:09:22.757 --> 00:09:25.284
But this is all beautiful to see.

00:09:25.308 --> 00:09:26.938
I was like, this is gorgeous.

00:09:26.962 --> 00:09:29.793
But what does it mean to the shark?

00:09:29.817 --> 00:09:31.164
Can they see this?

00:09:31.188 --> 00:09:32.720
And we looked in the literature,

00:09:32.744 --> 00:09:35.902
and nothing was known
about this shark's vision.

00:09:35.926 --> 00:09:40.108
So I took this shark to eye specialist
Ellis Loew at Cornell University,

00:09:40.132 --> 00:09:43.655
and we found out that this shark
sees discretely and acutely

00:09:43.679 --> 00:09:45.773
in the blue-green interface,

00:09:45.797 --> 00:09:48.627
probably about 100 times better
than we can see in the dark,

00:09:48.651 --> 00:09:50.377
but they only see blue-green.

00:09:50.401 --> 00:09:53.520
So what it's doing
is taking this blue world

00:09:53.544 --> 00:09:56.297
and it's absorbing the blue,
creating green.

00:09:56.321 --> 00:09:59.139
It's creating contrast
that they can indeed see.

00:09:59.163 --> 00:10:00.314
So we have a model,

00:10:00.338 --> 00:10:03.710
showing that it creates an ability
for them to see all these patterns.

00:10:03.734 --> 00:10:06.615
And males and females
also have, we're finding,

00:10:06.639 --> 00:10:08.575
distinct patterns among them.

00:10:09.234 --> 00:10:14.667
But our last find came really just
a few miles from where we are now,

00:10:14.691 --> 00:10:16.142
in the Solomon Islands.

00:10:16.166 --> 00:10:20.626
Swimming at night, I encountered
the first biofluorescent sea turtle.

00:10:20.650 --> 00:10:24.062
So now it's going from fish
and sharks into reptiles,

00:10:24.086 --> 00:10:27.370
which, again, this is only one month old,

00:10:27.394 --> 00:10:29.772
but it shows us
that we know almost nothing

00:10:29.796 --> 00:10:32.070
about this hawksbill turtle's vision.

00:10:32.094 --> 00:10:34.950
And it makes me think about
how much more there is to learn.

00:10:34.974 --> 00:10:36.506
And here in the Solomon Islands,

00:10:36.530 --> 00:10:40.101
there's only a few thousand
breeding females of this species left,

00:10:40.125 --> 00:10:42.169
and this is one of the hotspots for them.

00:10:42.193 --> 00:10:45.260
So it shows us how much we need
to really protect these animals

00:10:45.284 --> 00:10:47.640
while they're still here,
and understand them.

00:10:47.664 --> 00:10:49.808
In thinking about biofluorescence,

00:10:49.832 --> 00:10:51.777
I wanted to know, how deep does it go?

00:10:51.801 --> 00:10:54.245
Does this go all the way
to the bottom of the ocean?

00:10:54.269 --> 00:10:57.816
So we started using submarines,
and we equipped them

00:10:57.840 --> 00:11:00.014
with special blue lights
on the front here.

00:11:00.038 --> 00:11:01.998
And we dropped down,

00:11:02.022 --> 00:11:04.739
and we noticed one important thing --

00:11:04.763 --> 00:11:08.061
that as we get down to 1,000 meters,

00:11:08.085 --> 00:11:09.401
it drops off.

00:11:09.425 --> 00:11:13.329
There's no biofluorescent marine life
down there, below 1,000 meters --

00:11:13.353 --> 00:11:15.358
almost nothing, it's just darkness.

00:11:15.382 --> 00:11:17.812
So it's mainly a shallow phenomenon.

00:11:17.836 --> 00:11:19.289
And below 1,000 meters,

00:11:19.313 --> 00:11:21.974
we encountered the bioluminescent zone,

00:11:21.998 --> 00:11:25.335
where nine out of 10 animals
are actually making their own lights

00:11:25.359 --> 00:11:27.113
and flashing and blinking.

00:11:27.137 --> 00:11:28.510
As I try to get deeper,

00:11:28.534 --> 00:11:31.509
this is slapping on a one-person
submarine suit --

00:11:31.533 --> 00:11:35.296
some people call this my "Jacques Cousteau
meets Woody Allen" moment.

00:11:35.320 --> 00:11:36.471
(Laughter)

00:11:36.495 --> 00:11:38.546
But as we explore down here,

00:11:38.570 --> 00:11:42.289
I was thinking about: How do we
interact with life delicately?

00:11:42.313 --> 00:11:45.010
Because we're entering
a new age of exploration,

00:11:45.034 --> 00:11:46.837
where we have to take great care,

00:11:46.861 --> 00:11:49.556
and we have to set examples
how we explore.

00:11:49.580 --> 00:11:53.244
So I've teamed up with roboticist Rob Wood
at Harvard University,

00:11:53.268 --> 00:11:57.407
and we've been designing
squishy underwater robot fingers,

00:11:58.318 --> 00:12:01.420
so we can delicately interact
with the marine life down there.

00:12:01.444 --> 00:12:06.159
The idea is that most of our technologies
to explore the deep ocean

00:12:06.183 --> 00:12:08.963
come from oil and gas and military,

00:12:08.987 --> 00:12:11.828
who, you know, they're not really
caring to be gentle.

00:12:11.852 --> 00:12:14.535
Some corals could be 1,000 years old.

00:12:14.559 --> 00:12:17.668
You don't want to just go
and crush them with a big claw.

00:12:17.692 --> 00:12:19.690
So my dream is something like this.

00:12:19.714 --> 00:12:22.010
At night, I'm in a submarine,

00:12:22.034 --> 00:12:24.144
I have force-feedback gloves,

00:12:24.168 --> 00:12:27.486
and I could delicately set up
a lab in the front of my submarine,

00:12:27.510 --> 00:12:30.049
where the squishy robot fingers

00:12:30.073 --> 00:12:32.558
are delicately collecting
and putting things in jars,

00:12:32.582 --> 00:12:34.167
and we can conduct our research.

00:12:34.565 --> 00:12:37.415
Back to the powerful applied applications.

00:12:37.439 --> 00:12:40.279
Here, you're looking at a living brain

00:12:40.303 --> 00:12:43.670
that's using the DNA
of fluorescent marine creatures,

00:12:43.694 --> 00:12:45.700
this one from jellyfish and corals,

00:12:45.724 --> 00:12:49.193
to illuminate the living brain
and see its connections.

00:12:49.217 --> 00:12:50.733
It's funny that we're using RGB

00:12:50.757 --> 00:12:53.305
just to kind of satisfy
our own human intuition,

00:12:53.329 --> 00:12:55.663
so we can see our brains better.

00:12:55.687 --> 00:12:57.735
And even more mind-blowing,

00:12:57.759 --> 00:13:00.869
is my close colleague
Vincent Pieribone at Yale,

00:13:00.893 --> 00:13:04.270
who has actually designed and engineered
a fluorescent protein

00:13:04.294 --> 00:13:06.389
that responds to voltage.

00:13:06.413 --> 00:13:09.515
So he could see
when a single neuron fires.

00:13:09.539 --> 00:13:14.078
You're essentially looking at
a portal into consciousness

00:13:14.102 --> 00:13:17.016
that was designed by marine creatures.

00:13:18.060 --> 00:13:22.746
So this brings me all back
to perspective and relationship.

00:13:22.770 --> 00:13:25.009
From deep space,

00:13:25.033 --> 00:13:28.185
our universe looks
like a human brain cell,

00:13:28.209 --> 00:13:30.691
and then here we are in the deep ocean,

00:13:30.715 --> 00:13:33.586
and we're finding
marine creatures and cells

00:13:33.610 --> 00:13:35.889
that can illuminate the human mind.

00:13:35.913 --> 00:13:39.031
And it's my hope
that with illuminated minds,

00:13:39.055 --> 00:13:42.840
we could ponder the overarching
interconnectedness of all life,

00:13:42.864 --> 00:13:45.222
and fathom how much more lies in store

00:13:45.246 --> 00:13:46.961
if we keep our oceans healthy.

00:13:46.985 --> 00:13:48.143
Thank you.

00:13:48.167 --> 00:13:53.283
(Applause)

title: Should you be able to patent a human gene?
transcript: It was an afternoon in the fall of 2005. I was working at the ACLU as the organization's science advisor. I really, really loved my job, but I was having one of those days where I was feeling just a little bit discouraged.So I wandered down the hallway to my colleague Chris Hansen's office. Chris had been at the ACLU for more than 30 years, so he had deep institutional knowledge and insights.I explained to Chris that I was feeling a little bit stuck. I had been investigating a number of issues at the intersection of science and civil liberties — super interesting.
