title: What really happens when you mix medications?
transcript: So you go to the doctor and get some tests. The doctor determines that you have high cholesterol and you would benefit from medication to treat it. So you get a pillbox. You have some confidence, your physician has some confidence that this is going to work. The company that invented it did a lot of studies, submitted it to the FDA. They studied it very carefully, skeptically, they approved it. They have a rough idea of how it works, they have a rough idea of what the side effects are. It should be OK. You have a little more of a conversation with your physician and the physician is a little worried because you've been blue, haven't felt like yourself, you haven't been able to enjoy things in life quite as much as you usually do. Your physician says, "You know, I think you have some depression. I'm going to have to give you another pill."So now we're talking about two medications. This pill also — millions of people have taken it, the company did studies, the FDA looked at it — all good. Think things should go OK. Think things should go OK. Well, wait a minute. How much have we studied these two together?Well, it's very hard to do that. In fact, it's not traditionally done. We totally depend on what we call "post-marketing surveillance," after the drugs hit the market. How can we figure out if bad things are happening between two medications? Three? Five? Seven? Ask your favorite person who has several diagnoses how many medications they're on.Why do I care about this problem? I care about it deeply. I'm an informatics and data science guy and really, in my opinion, the only hope — only hope — to understand these interactions is to leverage lots of different sources of data in order to figure out when drugs can be used together safely and when it's not so safe.So let me tell you a data science story. And it begins with my student Nick. Let's call him "Nick," because that's his name.(Laughter)Nick was a young student. I said, "You know, Nick, we have to understand how drugs work and how they work together and how they work separately, and we don't have a great understanding. But the FDA has made available an amazing database. It's a database of adverse events. They literally put on the web — publicly available, you could all download it right now — hundreds of thousands of adverse event reports from patients, doctors, companies, pharmacists. And these reports are pretty simple: it has all the diseases that the patient has, all the drugs that they're on, and all the adverse events, or side effects, that they experience. It is not all of the adverse events that are occurring in America today, but it's hundreds and hundreds of thousands of drugs.So I said to Nick, "Let's think about glucose. Glucose is very important, and we know it's involved with diabetes. Let's see if we can understand glucose response. I sent Nick off. Nick came back."Russ," he said, "I've created a classifier that can look at the side effects of a drug based on looking at this database, and can tell you whether that drug is likely to change glucose or not."He did it. It was very simple, in a way. He took all the drugs that were known to change glucose and a bunch of drugs that don't change glucose, and said, "What's the difference in their side effects? Differences in fatigue? In appetite? In urination habits?" All those things conspired to give him a really good predictor. He said, "Russ, I can predict with 93 percent accuracy when a drug will change glucose."I said, "Nick, that's great." He's a young student, you have to build his confidence. "But Nick, there's a problem. It's that every physician in the world knows all the drugs that change glucose, because it's core to our practice. So it's great, good job, but not really that interesting, definitely not publishable."(Laughter)He said, "I know, Russ. I thought you might say that." Nick is smart. "I thought you might say that, so I did one other experiment. I looked at people in this database who were on two drugs, and I looked for signals similar, glucose-changing signals, for people taking two drugs, where each drug alone did not change glucose, but together I saw a strong signal."And I said, "Oh! You're clever. Good idea. Show me the list." And there's a bunch of drugs, not very exciting. But what caught my eye was, on the list there were two drugs: paroxetine, or Paxil, an antidepressant; and pravastatin, or Pravachol, a cholesterol medication.And I said, "Huh. There are millions of Americans on those two drugs." In fact, we learned later, 15 million Americans on paroxetine at the time, 15 million on pravastatin, and a million, we estimated, on both. So that's a million people who might be having some problems with their glucose if this machine-learning mumbo jumbo that he did in the FDA database actually holds up. But I said, "It's still not publishable, because I love what you did with the mumbo jumbo, with the machine learning, but it's not really standard-of-proof evidence that we have." So we have to do something else. Let's go into the Stanford electronic medical record. We have a copy of it that's OK for research, we removed identifying information. And I said, "Let's see if people on these two drugs have problems with their glucose."Now there are thousands and thousands of people in the Stanford medical records that take paroxetine and pravastatin. But we needed special patients. We needed patients who were on one of them and had a glucose measurement, then got the second one and had another glucose measurement, all within a reasonable period of time — something like two months. And when we did that, we found 10 patients. However, eight out of the 10 had a bump in their glucose when they got the second P — we call this P and P — when they got the second P. Either one could be first, the second one comes up, glucose went up 20 milligrams per deciliter. Just as a reminder, you walk around normally, if you're not diabetic, with a glucose of around 90. And if it gets up to 120, 125, your doctor begins to think about a potential diagnosis of diabetes. So a 20 bump — pretty significant.I said, "Nick, this is very cool. But, I'm sorry, we still don't have a paper, because this is 10 patients and — give me a break — it's not enough patients."So we said, what can we do? And we said, let's call our friends at Harvard and Vanderbilt, who also — Harvard in Boston, Vanderbilt in Nashville, who also have electronic medical records similar to ours. Let's see if they can find similar patients with the one P, the other P, the glucose measurements in that range that we need.God bless them, Vanderbilt in one week found 40 such patients, same trend. Harvard found 100 patients, same trend. So at the end, we had 150 patients from three diverse medical centers that were telling us that patients getting these two drugs were having their glucose bump somewhat significantly.More interestingly, we had left out diabetics, because diabetics already have messed up glucose. When we looked at the glucose of diabetics, it was going up 60 milligrams per deciliter, not just 20. This was a big deal, and we said, "We've got to publish this." We submitted the paper. It was all data evidence, data from the FDA, data from Stanford, data from Vanderbilt, data from Harvard. We had not done a single real experiment.But we were nervous. So Nick, while the paper was in review, went to the lab. We found somebody who knew about lab stuff. I don't do that. I take care of patients, but I don't do pipettes. They taught us how to feed mice drugs. We took mice and we gave them one P, paroxetine. We gave some other mice pravastatin. And we gave a third group of mice both of them. And lo and behold, glucose went up 20 to 60 milligrams per deciliter in the mice.So the paper was accepted based on the informatics evidence alone, but we added a little note at the end, saying, oh by the way, if you give these to mice, it goes up.That was great, and the story could have ended there. But I still have six and a half minutes.(Laughter)So we were sitting around thinking about all of this, and I don't remember who thought of it, but somebody said, "I wonder if patients who are taking these two drugs are noticing side effects of hyperglycemia. They could and they should. How would we ever determine that?"We said, well, what do you do? You're taking a medication, one new medication or two, and you get a funny feeling. What do you do? You go to Google and type in the two drugs you're taking or the one drug you're taking, and you type in "side effects." What are you experiencing? So we said OK, let's ask Google if they will share their search logs with us, so that we can look at the search logs and see if patients are doing these kinds of searches. Google, I am sorry to say, denied our request. So I was bummed. I was at a dinner with a colleague who works at Microsoft Research and I said, "We wanted to do this study, Google said no, it's kind of a bummer." He said, "Well, we have the Bing searches."(Laughter)Yeah. That's great. Now I felt like I was —(Laughter)I felt like I was talking to Nick again. He works for one of the largest companies in the world, and I'm already trying to make him feel better. But he said, "No, Russ — you might not understand. We not only have Bing searches, but if you use Internet Explorer to do searches at Google, Yahoo, Bing, any ... Then, for 18 months, we keep that data for research purposes only." I said, "Now you're talking!" This was Eric Horvitz, my friend at Microsoft.So we did a study where we defined 50 words that a regular person might type in if they're having hyperglycemia, like "fatigue," "loss of appetite," "urinating a lot," "peeing a lot" — forgive me, but that's one of the things you might type in. So we had 50 phrases that we called the "diabetes words." And we did first a baseline. And it turns out that about .5 to one percent of all searches on the Internet involve one of those words. So that's our baseline rate. If people type in "paroxetine" or "Paxil" — those are synonyms — and one of those words, the rate goes up to about two percent of diabetes-type words, if you already know that there's that "paroxetine" word. If it's "pravastatin," the rate goes up to about three percent from the baseline. If both "paroxetine" and "pravastatin" are present in the query, it goes up to 10 percent, a huge three- to four-fold increase in those searches with the two drugs that we were interested in, and diabetes-type words or hyperglycemia-type words.We published this, and it got some attention. The reason it deserves attention is that patients are telling us their side effects indirectly through their searches. We brought this to the attention of the FDA. They were interested. They have set up social media surveillance programs to collaborate with Microsoft, which had a nice infrastructure for doing this, and others, to look at Twitter feeds, to look at Facebook feeds, to look at search logs, to try to see early signs that drugs, either individually or together, are causing problems.What do I take from this? Why tell this story? Well, first of all, we have now the promise of big data and medium-sized data to help us understand drug interactions and really, fundamentally, drug actions. How do drugs work? This will create and has created a new ecosystem for understanding how drugs work and to optimize their use. Nick went on; he's a professor at Columbia now. He did this in his PhD for hundreds of pairs of drugs. He found several very important interactions, and so we replicated this and we showed that this is a way that really works for finding drug-drug interactions.However, there's a couple of things. We don't just use pairs of drugs at a time. As I said before, there are patients on three, five, seven, nine drugs. Have they been studied with respect to their nine-way interaction? Yes, we can do pair-wise, A and B, A and C, A and D, but what about A, B, C, D, E, F, G all together, being taken by the same patient, perhaps interacting with each other in ways that either makes them more effective or less effective or causes side effects that are unexpected? We really have no idea. It's a blue sky, open field for us to use data to try to understand the interaction of drugs.Two more lessons: I want you to think about the power that we were able to generate with the data from people who had volunteered their adverse reactions through their pharmacists, through themselves, through their doctors, the people who allowed the databases at Stanford, Harvard, Vanderbilt, to be used for research. People are worried about data. They're worried about their privacy and security — they should be. We need secure systems. But we can't have a system that closes that data off, because it is too rich of a source of inspiration, innovation and discovery for new things in medicine.And the final thing I want to say is, in this case we found two drugs and it was a little bit of a sad story. The two drugs actually caused problems. They increased glucose. They could throw somebody into diabetes who would otherwise not be in diabetes, and so you would want to use the two drugs very carefully together, perhaps not together, make different choices when you're prescribing. But there was another possibility. We could have found two drugs or three drugs that were interacting in a beneficial way. We could have found new effects of drugs that neither of them has alone, but together, instead of causing a side effect, they could be a new and novel treatment for diseases that don't have treatments or where the treatments are not effective. If we think about drug treatment today, all the major breakthroughs — for HIV, for tuberculosis, for depression, for diabetes — it's always a cocktail of drugs.And so the upside here, and the subject for a different TED Talk on a different day, is how can we use the same data sources to find good effects of drugs in combination that will provide us new treatments, new insights into how drugs work and enable us to take care of our patients even better?Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.769 --> 00:00:16.090
So you go to the doctor
and get some tests.

00:00:16.632 --> 00:00:19.252
The doctor determines
that you have high cholesterol

00:00:19.276 --> 00:00:22.447
and you would benefit
from medication to treat it.

00:00:22.939 --> 00:00:24.495
So you get a pillbox.

00:00:25.463 --> 00:00:26.662
You have some confidence,

00:00:26.686 --> 00:00:29.623
your physician has some confidence
that this is going to work.

00:00:29.647 --> 00:00:33.200
The company that invented it did
a lot of studies, submitted it to the FDA.

00:00:33.224 --> 00:00:36.331
They studied it very carefully,
skeptically, they approved it.

00:00:36.355 --> 00:00:38.244
They have a rough idea of how it works,

00:00:38.268 --> 00:00:40.721
they have a rough idea
of what the side effects are.

00:00:40.745 --> 00:00:41.895
It should be OK.

00:00:42.822 --> 00:00:45.640
You have a little more
of a conversation with your physician

00:00:45.664 --> 00:00:48.627
and the physician is a little worried
because you've been blue,

00:00:48.651 --> 00:00:49.944
haven't felt like yourself,

00:00:49.968 --> 00:00:53.699
you haven't been able to enjoy things
in life quite as much as you usually do.

00:00:53.723 --> 00:00:56.909
Your physician says, "You know,
I think you have some depression.

00:00:57.750 --> 00:01:00.065
I'm going to have to give
you another pill."

00:01:00.892 --> 00:01:03.375
So now we're talking
about two medications.

00:01:03.399 --> 00:01:06.503
This pill also -- millions
of people have taken it,

00:01:06.527 --> 00:01:10.158
the company did studies,
the FDA looked at it -- all good.

00:01:10.781 --> 00:01:12.838
Think things should go OK.

00:01:12.862 --> 00:01:15.059
Think things should go OK.

00:01:15.083 --> 00:01:16.522
Well, wait a minute.

00:01:16.546 --> 00:01:20.063
How much have we studied
these two together?

00:01:20.588 --> 00:01:22.888
Well, it's very hard to do that.

00:01:22.912 --> 00:01:25.042
In fact, it's not traditionally done.

00:01:25.066 --> 00:01:30.584
We totally depend on what we call
"post-marketing surveillance,"

00:01:30.608 --> 00:01:32.488
after the drugs hit the market.

00:01:32.954 --> 00:01:35.802
How can we figure out
if bad things are happening

00:01:35.826 --> 00:01:37.183
between two medications?

00:01:37.207 --> 00:01:39.237
Three? Five? Seven?

00:01:39.666 --> 00:01:42.081
Ask your favorite person
who has several diagnoses

00:01:42.105 --> 00:01:43.939
how many medications they're on.

00:01:44.488 --> 00:01:46.068
Why do I care about this problem?

00:01:46.092 --> 00:01:47.249
I care about it deeply.

00:01:47.273 --> 00:01:51.577
I'm an informatics and data science guy
and really, in my opinion,

00:01:51.601 --> 00:01:55.346
the only hope -- only hope --
to understand these interactions

00:01:55.370 --> 00:01:58.426
is to leverage lots
of different sources of data

00:01:58.450 --> 00:02:02.006
in order to figure out
when drugs can be used together safely

00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:03.807
and when it's not so safe.

00:02:04.573 --> 00:02:06.624
So let me tell you a data science story.

00:02:06.648 --> 00:02:08.802
And it begins with my student Nick.

00:02:08.826 --> 00:02:11.206
Let's call him "Nick,"
because that's his name.

00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:12.822
(Laughter)

00:02:12.846 --> 00:02:14.047
Nick was a young student.

00:02:14.071 --> 00:02:17.150
I said, "You know, Nick, we have
to understand how drugs work

00:02:17.174 --> 00:02:19.800
and how they work together
and how they work separately,

00:02:19.824 --> 00:02:21.746
and we don't have a great understanding.

00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:24.175
But the FDA has made available
an amazing database.

00:02:24.199 --> 00:02:25.898
It's a database of adverse events.

00:02:26.279 --> 00:02:27.921
They literally put on the web --

00:02:27.945 --> 00:02:31.064
publicly available, you could all
download it right now --

00:02:31.088 --> 00:02:34.715
hundreds of thousands
of adverse event reports

00:02:34.739 --> 00:02:38.499
from patients, doctors,
companies, pharmacists.

00:02:38.523 --> 00:02:40.272
And these reports are pretty simple:

00:02:40.296 --> 00:02:42.954
it has all the diseases
that the patient has,

00:02:42.978 --> 00:02:44.745
all the drugs that they're on,

00:02:44.769 --> 00:02:48.587
and all the adverse events,
or side effects, that they experience.

00:02:48.611 --> 00:02:52.047
It is not all of the adverse events
that are occurring in America today,

00:02:52.071 --> 00:02:54.649
but it's hundreds and hundreds
of thousands of drugs.

00:02:54.673 --> 00:02:55.972
So I said to Nick,

00:02:55.996 --> 00:02:57.822
"Let's think about glucose.

00:02:57.846 --> 00:03:01.413
Glucose is very important,
and we know it's involved with diabetes.

00:03:01.437 --> 00:03:05.407
Let's see if we can understand
glucose response.

00:03:05.431 --> 00:03:07.889
I sent Nick off. Nick came back.

00:03:08.206 --> 00:03:09.992
"Russ," he said,

00:03:10.309 --> 00:03:15.421
"I've created a classifier that can
look at the side effects of a drug

00:03:15.445 --> 00:03:17.496
based on looking at this database,

00:03:17.520 --> 00:03:21.791
and can tell you whether that drug
is likely to change glucose or not."

00:03:21.815 --> 00:03:23.831
He did it. It was very simple, in a way.

00:03:23.855 --> 00:03:26.490
He took all the drugs
that were known to change glucose

00:03:26.514 --> 00:03:28.903
and a bunch of drugs
that don't change glucose,

00:03:28.927 --> 00:03:31.815
and said, "What's the difference
in their side effects?

00:03:31.839 --> 00:03:36.691
Differences in fatigue? In appetite?
In urination habits?"

00:03:36.715 --> 00:03:39.675
All those things conspired
to give him a really good predictor.

00:03:39.699 --> 00:03:42.247
He said, "Russ, I can predict
with 93 percent accuracy

00:03:42.271 --> 00:03:43.843
when a drug will change glucose."

00:03:43.867 --> 00:03:45.283
I said, "Nick, that's great."

00:03:45.307 --> 00:03:48.203
He's a young student,
you have to build his confidence.

00:03:48.227 --> 00:03:49.617
"But Nick, there's a problem.

00:03:49.641 --> 00:03:53.601
It's that every physician in the world
knows all the drugs that change glucose,

00:03:53.625 --> 00:03:55.663
because it's core to our practice.

00:03:55.687 --> 00:03:59.409
So it's great, good job,
but not really that interesting,

00:03:59.433 --> 00:04:00.964
definitely not publishable."

00:04:00.988 --> 00:04:02.002
(Laughter)

00:04:02.026 --> 00:04:04.576
He said, "I know, Russ.
I thought you might say that."

00:04:04.600 --> 00:04:05.752
Nick is smart.

00:04:06.107 --> 00:04:08.981
"I thought you might say that,
so I did one other experiment.

00:04:09.005 --> 00:04:11.933
I looked at people in this database
who were on two drugs,

00:04:11.957 --> 00:04:16.379
and I looked for signals similar,
glucose-changing signals,

00:04:16.403 --> 00:04:18.027
for people taking two drugs,

00:04:18.051 --> 00:04:23.620
where each drug alone
did not change glucose,

00:04:23.644 --> 00:04:26.104
but together I saw a strong signal."

00:04:26.128 --> 00:04:29.277
And I said, "Oh! You're clever.
Good idea. Show me the list."

00:04:29.301 --> 00:04:31.555
And there's a bunch of drugs,
not very exciting.

00:04:31.579 --> 00:04:35.511
But what caught my eye
was, on the list there were two drugs:

00:04:35.535 --> 00:04:38.928
paroxetine, or Paxil, an antidepressant;

00:04:39.714 --> 00:04:43.284
and pravastatin, or Pravachol,
a cholesterol medication.

00:04:43.894 --> 00:04:48.177
And I said, "Huh. There are millions
of Americans on those two drugs."

00:04:48.201 --> 00:04:49.447
In fact, we learned later,

00:04:49.471 --> 00:04:55.503
15 million Americans on paroxetine
at the time, 15 million on pravastatin,

00:04:55.527 --> 00:04:58.344
and a million, we estimated, on both.

00:04:58.725 --> 00:04:59.979
So that's a million people

00:05:00.003 --> 00:05:02.456
who might be having some problems
with their glucose

00:05:02.480 --> 00:05:05.686
if this machine-learning mumbo jumbo
that he did in the FDA database

00:05:05.710 --> 00:05:06.964
actually holds up.

00:05:06.988 --> 00:05:08.915
But I said, "It's still not publishable,

00:05:08.939 --> 00:05:11.235
because I love what you did
with the mumbo jumbo,

00:05:11.259 --> 00:05:12.505
with the machine learning,

00:05:12.529 --> 00:05:16.393
but it's not really standard-of-proof
evidence that we have."

00:05:17.576 --> 00:05:19.165
So we have to do something else.

00:05:19.189 --> 00:05:22.065
Let's go into the Stanford
electronic medical record.

00:05:22.089 --> 00:05:24.153
We have a copy of it
that's OK for research,

00:05:24.177 --> 00:05:26.223
we removed identifying information.

00:05:26.539 --> 00:05:29.042
And I said, "Let's see if people
on these two drugs

00:05:29.066 --> 00:05:30.835
have problems with their glucose."

00:05:31.200 --> 00:05:33.407
Now there are thousands
and thousands of people

00:05:33.431 --> 00:05:36.890
in the Stanford medical records
that take paroxetine and pravastatin.

00:05:36.914 --> 00:05:38.713
But we needed special patients.

00:05:38.737 --> 00:05:43.334
We needed patients who were on one of them
and had a glucose measurement,

00:05:43.358 --> 00:05:46.807
then got the second one and had
another glucose measurement,

00:05:46.831 --> 00:05:50.446
all within a reasonable period of time --
something like two months.

00:05:50.470 --> 00:05:53.629
And when we did that,
we found 10 patients.

00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:59.088
However, eight out of the 10
had a bump in their glucose

00:05:59.112 --> 00:06:01.757
when they got the second P --
we call this P and P --

00:06:01.781 --> 00:06:03.091
when they got the second P.

00:06:03.115 --> 00:06:05.677
Either one could be first,
the second one comes up,

00:06:05.701 --> 00:06:08.548
glucose went up
20 milligrams per deciliter.

00:06:08.572 --> 00:06:09.730
Just as a reminder,

00:06:09.754 --> 00:06:12.079
you walk around normally,
if you're not diabetic,

00:06:12.103 --> 00:06:13.462
with a glucose of around 90.

00:06:13.486 --> 00:06:15.562
And if it gets up to 120, 125,

00:06:15.586 --> 00:06:19.036
your doctor begins to think
about a potential diagnosis of diabetes.

00:06:19.060 --> 00:06:22.051
So a 20 bump -- pretty significant.

00:06:22.559 --> 00:06:24.463
I said, "Nick, this is very cool.

00:06:25.574 --> 00:06:27.627
But, I'm sorry, we still
don't have a paper,

00:06:27.651 --> 00:06:30.230
because this is 10 patients
and -- give me a break --

00:06:30.254 --> 00:06:31.499
it's not enough patients."

00:06:31.523 --> 00:06:32.829
So we said, what can we do?

00:06:32.853 --> 00:06:35.829
And we said, let's call our friends
at Harvard and Vanderbilt,

00:06:35.853 --> 00:06:38.440
who also -- Harvard in Boston,
Vanderbilt in Nashville,

00:06:38.464 --> 00:06:41.285
who also have electronic
medical records similar to ours.

00:06:41.309 --> 00:06:43.329
Let's see if they can find
similar patients

00:06:43.353 --> 00:06:46.629
with the one P, the other P,
the glucose measurements

00:06:46.653 --> 00:06:48.253
in that range that we need.

00:06:48.745 --> 00:06:53.700
God bless them, Vanderbilt
in one week found 40 such patients,

00:06:53.724 --> 00:06:54.913
same trend.

00:06:55.762 --> 00:06:59.382
Harvard found 100 patients, same trend.

00:06:59.406 --> 00:07:03.687
So at the end, we had 150 patients
from three diverse medical centers

00:07:03.711 --> 00:07:07.008
that were telling us that patients
getting these two drugs

00:07:07.032 --> 00:07:09.735
were having their glucose bump
somewhat significantly.

00:07:10.275 --> 00:07:13.085
More interestingly,
we had left out diabetics,

00:07:13.109 --> 00:07:15.426
because diabetics already
have messed up glucose.

00:07:15.450 --> 00:07:17.688
When we looked
at the glucose of diabetics,

00:07:17.712 --> 00:07:21.147
it was going up 60 milligrams
per deciliter, not just 20.

00:07:21.718 --> 00:07:25.170
This was a big deal, and we said,
"We've got to publish this."

00:07:25.194 --> 00:07:26.373
We submitted the paper.

00:07:26.397 --> 00:07:28.508
It was all data evidence,

00:07:28.532 --> 00:07:31.015
data from the FDA, data from Stanford,

00:07:31.039 --> 00:07:32.985
data from Vanderbilt, data from Harvard.

00:07:33.009 --> 00:07:35.405
We had not done a single real experiment.

00:07:36.453 --> 00:07:37.749
But we were nervous.

00:07:38.159 --> 00:07:41.889
So Nick, while the paper
was in review, went to the lab.

00:07:41.913 --> 00:07:44.375
We found somebody
who knew about lab stuff.

00:07:44.399 --> 00:07:45.792
I don't do that.

00:07:45.816 --> 00:07:48.233
I take care of patients,
but I don't do pipettes.

00:07:49.378 --> 00:07:52.431
They taught us how to feed mice drugs.

00:07:52.822 --> 00:07:55.236
We took mice and we gave them
one P, paroxetine.

00:07:55.260 --> 00:07:57.768
We gave some other mice pravastatin.

00:07:57.792 --> 00:08:01.387
And we gave a third group
of mice both of them.

00:08:01.851 --> 00:08:05.797
And lo and behold, glucose went up
20 to 60 milligrams per deciliter

00:08:05.821 --> 00:08:06.992
in the mice.

00:08:07.016 --> 00:08:10.174
So the paper was accepted
based on the informatics evidence alone,

00:08:10.198 --> 00:08:12.092
but we added a little note at the end,

00:08:12.116 --> 00:08:15.015
saying, oh by the way,
if you give these to mice, it goes up.

00:08:15.039 --> 00:08:17.547
That was great, and the story
could have ended there.

00:08:17.571 --> 00:08:19.568
But I still have six and a half minutes.

00:08:19.592 --> 00:08:22.399
(Laughter)

00:08:22.423 --> 00:08:25.238
So we were sitting around
thinking about all of this,

00:08:25.262 --> 00:08:27.997
and I don't remember who thought
of it, but somebody said,

00:08:28.021 --> 00:08:31.222
"I wonder if patients
who are taking these two drugs

00:08:31.246 --> 00:08:34.799
are noticing side effects
of hyperglycemia.

00:08:34.823 --> 00:08:36.319
They could and they should.

00:08:36.719 --> 00:08:38.596
How would we ever determine that?"

00:08:39.509 --> 00:08:40.952
We said, well, what do you do?

00:08:40.976 --> 00:08:43.556
You're taking a medication,
one new medication or two,

00:08:43.580 --> 00:08:45.118
and you get a funny feeling.

00:08:45.142 --> 00:08:46.293
What do you do?

00:08:46.317 --> 00:08:47.468
You go to Google

00:08:47.492 --> 00:08:50.841
and type in the two drugs you're taking
or the one drug you're taking,

00:08:50.865 --> 00:08:52.468
and you type in "side effects."

00:08:52.492 --> 00:08:53.848
What are you experiencing?

00:08:54.197 --> 00:08:55.348
So we said OK,

00:08:55.372 --> 00:08:58.428
let's ask Google if they will share
their search logs with us,

00:08:58.452 --> 00:09:00.285
so that we can look at the search logs

00:09:00.309 --> 00:09:02.874
and see if patients are doing
these kinds of searches.

00:09:02.898 --> 00:09:06.173
Google, I am sorry to say,
denied our request.

00:09:06.777 --> 00:09:07.928
So I was bummed.

00:09:07.952 --> 00:09:11.118
I was at a dinner with a colleague
who works at Microsoft Research

00:09:11.142 --> 00:09:13.083
and I said, "We wanted to do this study,

00:09:13.107 --> 00:09:14.987
Google said no, it's kind of a bummer."

00:09:15.011 --> 00:09:17.097
He said, "Well, we have
the Bing searches."

00:09:18.153 --> 00:09:21.636
(Laughter)

00:09:22.763 --> 00:09:24.030
Yeah.

00:09:24.054 --> 00:09:25.205
That's great.

00:09:25.229 --> 00:09:26.380
Now I felt like I was --

00:09:26.404 --> 00:09:27.404
(Laughter)

00:09:27.428 --> 00:09:29.840
I felt like I was talking to Nick again.

00:09:30.395 --> 00:09:33.019
He works for one of the largest
companies in the world,

00:09:33.043 --> 00:09:35.249
and I'm already trying
to make him feel better.

00:09:35.273 --> 00:09:37.718
But he said, "No, Russ --
you might not understand.

00:09:37.742 --> 00:09:39.242
We not only have Bing searches,

00:09:39.266 --> 00:09:42.606
but if you use Internet Explorer
to do searches at Google,

00:09:42.630 --> 00:09:44.521
Yahoo, Bing, any ...

00:09:44.545 --> 00:09:48.188
Then, for 18 months, we keep that data
for research purposes only."

00:09:48.212 --> 00:09:50.148
I said, "Now you're talking!"

00:09:50.172 --> 00:09:52.370
This was Eric Horvitz,
my friend at Microsoft.

00:09:52.394 --> 00:09:54.089
So we did a study

00:09:54.113 --> 00:09:58.732
where we defined 50 words
that a regular person might type in

00:09:58.756 --> 00:10:00.358
if they're having hyperglycemia,

00:10:00.382 --> 00:10:05.144
like "fatigue," "loss of appetite,"
"urinating a lot," "peeing a lot" --

00:10:05.168 --> 00:10:07.935
forgive me, but that's one
of the things you might type in.

00:10:07.959 --> 00:10:10.749
So we had 50 phrases
that we called the "diabetes words."

00:10:10.773 --> 00:10:12.836
And we did first a baseline.

00:10:12.860 --> 00:10:15.564
And it turns out
that about .5 to one percent

00:10:15.588 --> 00:10:18.570
of all searches on the Internet
involve one of those words.

00:10:18.594 --> 00:10:20.336
So that's our baseline rate.

00:10:20.360 --> 00:10:24.503
If people type in "paroxetine"
or "Paxil" -- those are synonyms --

00:10:24.527 --> 00:10:25.742
and one of those words,

00:10:25.766 --> 00:10:30.656
the rate goes up to about two percent
of diabetes-type words,

00:10:30.680 --> 00:10:33.724
if you already know
that there's that "paroxetine" word.

00:10:34.149 --> 00:10:38.696
If it's "pravastatin," the rate goes up
to about three percent from the baseline.

00:10:39.129 --> 00:10:43.519
If both "paroxetine" and "pravastatin"
are present in the query,

00:10:43.543 --> 00:10:45.212
it goes up to 10 percent,

00:10:45.236 --> 00:10:48.697
a huge three- to four-fold increase

00:10:48.721 --> 00:10:52.110
in those searches with the two drugs
that we were interested in,

00:10:52.134 --> 00:10:55.700
and diabetes-type words
or hyperglycemia-type words.

00:10:56.174 --> 00:10:57.439
We published this,

00:10:57.463 --> 00:10:58.929
and it got some attention.

00:10:58.953 --> 00:11:00.731
The reason it deserves attention

00:11:00.755 --> 00:11:05.067
is that patients are telling us
their side effects indirectly

00:11:05.091 --> 00:11:06.247
through their searches.

00:11:06.271 --> 00:11:08.409
We brought this
to the attention of the FDA.

00:11:08.433 --> 00:11:09.702
They were interested.

00:11:09.726 --> 00:11:13.332
They have set up social media
surveillance programs

00:11:13.356 --> 00:11:15.107
to collaborate with Microsoft,

00:11:15.131 --> 00:11:17.925
which had a nice infrastructure
for doing this, and others,

00:11:17.949 --> 00:11:19.231
to look at Twitter feeds,

00:11:19.255 --> 00:11:20.971
to look at Facebook feeds,

00:11:20.995 --> 00:11:22.306
to look at search logs,

00:11:22.330 --> 00:11:27.239
to try to see early signs that drugs,
either individually or together,

00:11:27.263 --> 00:11:28.852
are causing problems.

00:11:28.876 --> 00:11:31.050
What do I take from this?
Why tell this story?

00:11:31.074 --> 00:11:32.281
Well, first of all,

00:11:32.305 --> 00:11:36.342
we have now the promise
of big data and medium-sized data

00:11:36.366 --> 00:11:39.284
to help us understand drug interactions

00:11:39.308 --> 00:11:41.728
and really, fundamentally, drug actions.

00:11:41.752 --> 00:11:43.165
How do drugs work?

00:11:43.189 --> 00:11:46.025
This will create and has created
a new ecosystem

00:11:46.049 --> 00:11:49.316
for understanding how drugs work
and to optimize their use.

00:11:50.261 --> 00:11:52.920
Nick went on; he's a professor
at Columbia now.

00:11:52.944 --> 00:11:57.016
He did this in his PhD
for hundreds of pairs of drugs.

00:11:57.040 --> 00:11:59.557
He found several
very important interactions,

00:11:59.581 --> 00:12:00.795
and so we replicated this

00:12:00.819 --> 00:12:03.393
and we showed that this
is a way that really works

00:12:03.417 --> 00:12:05.756
for finding drug-drug interactions.

00:12:06.240 --> 00:12:07.974
However, there's a couple of things.

00:12:07.998 --> 00:12:11.044
We don't just use pairs
of drugs at a time.

00:12:11.068 --> 00:12:15.537
As I said before, there are patients
on three, five, seven, nine drugs.

00:12:15.939 --> 00:12:19.581
Have they been studied with respect
to their nine-way interaction?

00:12:19.605 --> 00:12:23.813
Yes, we can do pair-wise,
A and B, A and C, A and D,

00:12:23.837 --> 00:12:28.123
but what about A, B, C,
D, E, F, G all together,

00:12:28.147 --> 00:12:29.909
being taken by the same patient,

00:12:29.933 --> 00:12:32.051
perhaps interacting with each other

00:12:32.075 --> 00:12:35.853
in ways that either makes them
more effective or less effective

00:12:35.877 --> 00:12:38.209
or causes side effects
that are unexpected?

00:12:38.233 --> 00:12:40.060
We really have no idea.

00:12:40.084 --> 00:12:43.840
It's a blue sky, open field
for us to use data

00:12:43.864 --> 00:12:46.366
to try to understand
the interaction of drugs.

00:12:46.806 --> 00:12:48.176
Two more lessons:

00:12:48.200 --> 00:12:52.399
I want you to think about the power
that we were able to generate

00:12:52.423 --> 00:12:57.134
with the data from people who had
volunteered their adverse reactions

00:12:57.158 --> 00:13:00.427
through their pharmacists,
through themselves, through their doctors,

00:13:00.451 --> 00:13:04.118
the people who allowed the databases
at Stanford, Harvard, Vanderbilt,

00:13:04.142 --> 00:13:05.569
to be used for research.

00:13:05.887 --> 00:13:07.332
People are worried about data.

00:13:07.356 --> 00:13:10.543
They're worried about their privacy
and security -- they should be.

00:13:10.567 --> 00:13:11.718
We need secure systems.

00:13:11.742 --> 00:13:15.148
But we can't have a system
that closes that data off,

00:13:15.172 --> 00:13:17.924
because it is too rich of a source

00:13:17.948 --> 00:13:21.919
of inspiration, innovation and discovery

00:13:21.943 --> 00:13:23.521
for new things in medicine.

00:13:24.452 --> 00:13:26.246
And the final thing I want to say is,

00:13:26.270 --> 00:13:29.627
in this case we found two drugs
and it was a little bit of a sad story.

00:13:29.651 --> 00:13:31.572
The two drugs actually caused problems.

00:13:31.596 --> 00:13:33.071
They increased glucose.

00:13:33.095 --> 00:13:35.541
They could throw somebody into diabetes

00:13:35.565 --> 00:13:37.859
who would otherwise not be in diabetes,

00:13:37.883 --> 00:13:41.058
and so you would want to use
the two drugs very carefully together,

00:13:41.082 --> 00:13:42.233
perhaps not together,

00:13:42.257 --> 00:13:44.597
make different choices
when you're prescribing.

00:13:44.621 --> 00:13:46.467
But there was another possibility.

00:13:46.491 --> 00:13:48.835
We could have found
two drugs or three drugs

00:13:48.859 --> 00:13:51.120
that were interacting in a beneficial way.

00:13:51.574 --> 00:13:54.286
We could have found new effects of drugs

00:13:54.310 --> 00:13:56.470
that neither of them has alone,

00:13:56.494 --> 00:13:58.987
but together, instead
of causing a side effect,

00:13:59.011 --> 00:14:01.436
they could be a new and novel treatment

00:14:01.460 --> 00:14:03.342
for diseases that don't have treatments

00:14:03.366 --> 00:14:05.373
or where the treatments are not effective.

00:14:05.397 --> 00:14:07.792
If we think about drug treatment today,

00:14:07.816 --> 00:14:09.568
all the major breakthroughs --

00:14:09.592 --> 00:14:13.889
for HIV, for tuberculosis,
for depression, for diabetes --

00:14:13.913 --> 00:14:16.743
it's always a cocktail of drugs.

00:14:16.767 --> 00:14:18.497
And so the upside here,

00:14:18.521 --> 00:14:21.370
and the subject for a different
TED Talk on a different day,

00:14:21.394 --> 00:14:23.987
is how can we use the same data sources

00:14:24.011 --> 00:14:27.574
to find good effects
of drugs in combination

00:14:27.598 --> 00:14:29.773
that will provide us new treatments,

00:14:29.797 --> 00:14:31.649
new insights into how drugs work

00:14:31.673 --> 00:14:35.459
and enable us to take care
of our patients even better?

00:14:35.483 --> 00:14:36.649
Thank you very much.

00:14:36.673 --> 00:14:40.172
(Applause)

title: Our refugee system is failing. Here's how we can fix it
transcript: There are times when I feel really quite ashamed to be a European. In the last year, more than a million people arrived in Europe in need of our help, and our response, frankly, has been pathetic.There are just so many contradictions. We mourn the tragic death of two-year-old Alan Kurdi, and yet, since then, more than 200 children have subsequently drowned in the Mediterranean. We have international treaties that recognize that refugees are a shared responsibility, and yet we accept that tiny Lebanon hosts more Syrians than the whole of Europe combined. We lament the existence of human smugglers, and yet we make that the only viable route to seek asylum in Europe. We have labor shortages, and yet we exclude people who fit our economic and demographic needs from coming to Europe. We proclaim our liberal values in opposition to fundamentalist Islam, and yet — we have repressive policies that detain child asylum seekers, that separate children from their families, and that seize property from refugees.What are we doing? How has the situation come to this, that we've adopted such an inhumane response to a humanitarian crisis?I don't believe it's because people don't care, or at least I don't want to believe it's because people don't care. I believe it's because our politicians lack a vision, a vision for how to adapt an international refugee system created over 50 years ago for a changing and globalized world. And so what I want to do is take a step back and ask two really fundamental questions, the two questions we all need to ask. First, why is the current system not working? And second, what can we do to fix it?So the modern refugee regime was created in the aftermath of the Second World War by these guys. Its basic aim is to ensure that when a state fails, or worse, turns against its own people, people have somewhere to go, to live in safety and dignity until they can go home. It was created precisely for situations like the situation we see in Syria today. Through an international convention signed by 147 governments, the 1951 Convention on the Status of Refugees, and an international organization, UNHCR, states committed to reciprocally admit people onto their territory who flee conflict and persecution.But today, that system is failing. In theory, refugees have a right to seek asylum. In practice, our immigration policies block the path to safety. In theory, refugees have a right to a pathway to integration, or return to the country they've come from. But in practice, they get stuck in almost indefinite limbo. In theory, refugees are a shared global responsibility. In practice, geography means that countries proximate the conflict take the overwhelming majority of the world's refugees. The system isn't broken because the rules are wrong. It's that we're not applying them adequately to a changing world, and that's what we need to reconsider.So I want to explain to you a little bit about how the current system works. How does the refugee regime actually work? But not from a top-down institutional perspective, rather from the perspective of a refugee. So imagine a Syrian woman. Let's call her Amira. And Amira to me represents many of the people I've met in the region. Amira, like around 25 percent of the world's refugees, is a woman with children, and she can't go home because she comes from this city that you see before you, Homs, a once beautiful and historic city now under rubble. And so Amira can't go back there. But Amira also has no hope of resettlement to a third country, because that's a lottery ticket only available to less than one percent of the world's refugees.So Amira and her family face an almost impossible choice. They have three basic options. The first option is that Amira can take her family to a camp. In the camp, she might get assistance, but there are very few prospects for Amira and her family. Camps are in bleak, arid locations, often in the desert. In the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan, you can hear the shells across the border in Syria at nighttime. There's restricted economic activity. Education is often of poor quality. And around the world, some 80 percent of refugees who are in camps have to stay for at least five years. It's a miserable existence, and that's probably why, in reality, only nine percent of Syrians choose that option.Alternatively, Amira can head to an urban area in a neighboring country, like Amman or Beirut. That's an option that about 75 percent of Syrian refugees have taken. But there, there's great difficulty as well. Refugees in such urban areas don't usually have the right to work. They don't usually get significant access to assistance. And so when Amira and her family have used up their basic savings, they're left with very little and likely to face urban destitution.So there's a third alternative, and it's one that increasing numbers of Syrians are taking. Amira can seek some hope for her family by risking their lives on a dangerous and perilous journey to another country, and it's that which we're seeing in Europe today.Around the world, we present refugees with an almost impossible choice between three options: encampment, urban destitution and dangerous journeys. For refugees, that choice is the global refugee regime today. But I think it's a false choice. I think we can reconsider that choice. The reason why we limit those options is because we think that those are the only options that are available to refugees, and they're not. Politicians frame the issue as a zero-sum issue, that if we benefit refugees, we're imposing costs on citizens. We tend to have a collective assumption that refugees are an inevitable cost or burden to society. But they don't have to. They can contribute.So what I want to argue is there are ways in which we can expand that choice set and still benefit everyone else: the host states and communities, our societies and refugees themselves. And I want to suggest four ways we can transform the paradigm of how we think about refugees. All four ways have one thing in common: they're all ways in which we take the opportunities of globalization, mobility and markets, and update the way we think about the refugee issue.The first one I want to think about is the idea of enabling environments, and it starts from a very basic recognition that refugees are human beings like everyone else, but they're just in extraordinary circumstances. Together with my colleagues in Oxford, we've embarked on a research project in Uganda looking at the economic lives of refugees. We chose Uganda not because it's representative of all host countries. It's not. It's exceptional. Unlike most host countries around the world, what Uganda has done is give refugees economic opportunity. It gives them the right to work. It gives them freedom of movement. And the results of that are extraordinary both for refugees and the host community. In the capital city, Kampala, we found that 21 percent of refugees own a business that employs other people, and 40 percent of those employees are nationals of the host country. In other words, refugees are making jobs for citizens of the host country. Even in the camps, we found extraordinary examples of vibrant, flourishing and entrepreneurial businesses.For example, in a settlement called Nakivale, we found examples of Congolese refugees running digital music exchange businesses. We found a Rwandan who runs a business that's available to allow the youth to play computer games on recycled games consoles and recycled televisions. Against the odds of extreme constraint, refugees are innovating, and the gentleman you see before you is a Congolese guy called Demou-Kay. Demou-Kay arrived in the settlement with very little, but he wanted to be a filmmaker. So with friends and colleagues, he started a community radio station, he rented a video camera, and he's now making films. He made two documentary films with and for our team, and he's making a successful business out of very little. It's those kinds of examples that should guide our response to refugees. Rather than seeing refugees as inevitably dependent upon humanitarian assistance, we need to provide them with opportunities for human flourishing.Yes, clothes, blankets, shelter, food are all important in the emergency phase, but we need to also look beyond that. We need to provide opportunities to connectivity, electricity, education, the right to work, access to capital and banking. All the ways in which we take for granted that we are plugged in to the global economy can and should apply to refugees.The second idea I want to discuss is economic zones. Unfortunately, not every host country in the world takes the approach Uganda has taken. Most host countries don't open up their economies to refugees in the same way. But there are still pragmatic alternative options that we can use.Last April, I traveled to Jordan with my colleague, the development economist Paul Collier, and we brainstormed an idea while we were there with the international community and the government, an idea to bring jobs to Syrians while supporting Jordan's national development strategy. The idea is for an economic zone, one in which we could potentially integrate the employment of refugees alongside the employment of Jordanian host nationals. And just 15 minutes away from the Zaatari refugee camp, home to 83,000 refugees, is an existing economic zone called the King Hussein Bin Talal Development Area. The government has spent over a hundred million dollars connecting it to the electricity grid, connecting it to the road network, but it lacked two things: access to labor and inward investment. So what if refugees were able to work there rather than being stuck in camps, able to support their families and develop skills through vocational training before they go back to Syria? We recognized that that could benefit Jordan, whose development strategy requires it to make the leap as a middle income country to manufacturing. It could benefit refugees, but it could also contribute to the postconflict reconstruction of Syria by recognizing that we need to incubate refugees as the best source of eventually rebuilding Syria.We published the idea in the journal Foreign Affairs. King Abdullah has picked up on the idea. It was announced at the London Syria Conference two weeks ago, and a pilot will begin in the summer.(Applause)The third idea that I want to put to you is preference matching between states and refugees to lead to the kinds of happy outcomes you see here in the selfie featuring Angela Merkel and a Syrian refugee. What we rarely do is ask refugees what they want, where they want to go, but I'd argue we can do that and still make everyone better off. The economist Alvin Roth has developed the idea of matching markets, ways in which the preference ranking of the parties shapes an eventual match. My colleagues Will Jones and Alex Teytelboym have explored ways in which that idea could be applied to refugees, to ask refugees to rank their preferred destinations, but also allow states to rank the types of refugees they want on skills criteria or language criteria and allow those to match. Now, of course you'd need to build in quotas on things like diversity and vulnerability, but it's a way of increasing the possibilities of matching. The matching idea has been successfully used to match, for instance, students with university places, to match kidney donors with patients, and it underlies the kind of algorithms that exist on dating websites. So why not apply that to give refugees greater choice?It could also be used at the national level, where one of the great challenges we face is to persuade local communities to accept refugees. And at the moment, in my country, for instance, we often send engineers to rural areas and farmers to the cities, which makes no sense at all. So matching markets offer a potential way to bring those preferences together and listen to the needs and demands of the populations that host and the refugees themselves.The fourth idea I want to put to you is of humanitarian visas. Much of the tragedy and chaos we've seen in Europe was entirely avoidable. It stems from a fundamental contradiction in Europe's asylum policy, which is the following: that in order to seek asylum in Europe, you have to arrive spontaneously by embarking on those dangerous journeys that I described. But why should those journeys be necessary in an era of the budget airline and modern consular capabilities? They're completely unnecessary journeys, and last year, they led to the deaths of over 3,000 people on Europe's borders and within European territory.If refugees were simply allowed to travel directly and seek asylum in Europe, we would avoid that, and there's a way of doing that through something called a humanitarian visa, that allows people to collect a visa at an embassy or a consulate in a neighboring country and then simply pay their own way through a ferry or a flight to Europe. It costs around a thousand euros to take a smuggler from Turkey to the Greek islands. It costs 200 euros to take a budget airline from Bodrum to Frankfurt. If we allowed refugees to do that, it would have major advantages. It would save lives, it would undercut the entire market for smugglers, and it would remove the chaos we see from Europe's front line in areas like the Greek islands. It's politics that prevents us doing that rather than a rational solution.And this is an idea that has been applied. Brazil has adopted a pioneering approach where over 2,000 Syrians have been able to get humanitarian visas, enter Brazil, and claim refugee status on arrival in Brazil. And in that scheme, every Syrian who has gone through it has received refugee status and been recognized as a genuine refugee.There is a historical precedent for it as well. Between 1922 and 1942, these Nansen passports were used as travel documents to allow 450,000 Assyrians, Turks and Chechens to travel across Europe and claim refugee status elsewhere in Europe. And the Nansen International Refugee Office received the Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of this being a viable strategy.So all four of these ideas that I've presented you are ways in which we can expand Amira's choice set. They're ways in which we can have greater choice for refugees beyond those basic, impossible three options I explained to you and still leave others better off.In conclusion, we really need a new vision, a vision that enlarges the choices of refugees but recognizes that they don't have to be a burden. There's nothing inevitable about refugees being a cost. Yes, they are a humanitarian responsibility, but they're human beings with skills, talents, aspirations, with the ability to make contributions — if we let them.In the new world, migration is not going to go away. What we've seen in Europe will be with us for many years. People will continue to travel, they'll continue to be displaced, and we need to find rational, realistic ways of managing this — not based on the old logics of humanitarian assistance, not based on logics of charity, but building on the opportunities offered by globalization, markets and mobility. I'd urge you all to wake up and urge our politicians to wake up to this challenge.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:01:45.038 --> 00:01:49.838
that we've adopted such an inhumane
response to a humanitarian crisis?

00:01:51.238 --> 00:01:53.654
I don't believe
it's because people don't care,

00:01:53.678 --> 00:01:56.854
or at least I don't want to believe
it's because people don't care.

00:01:56.878 --> 00:02:00.694
I believe it's because
our politicians lack a vision,

00:02:00.718 --> 00:02:04.334
a vision for how to adapt
an international refugee system

00:02:04.358 --> 00:02:06.494
created over 50 years ago

00:02:06.518 --> 00:02:09.318
for a changing and globalized world.

00:02:09.758 --> 00:02:12.294
And so what I want to do
is take a step back

00:02:12.318 --> 00:02:15.734
and ask two really fundamental questions,

00:02:15.758 --> 00:02:18.214
the two questions we all need to ask.

00:02:18.238 --> 00:02:21.534
First, why is the current
system not working?

00:02:21.558 --> 00:02:24.958
And second, what can we do to fix it?

00:02:26.718 --> 00:02:28.774
So the modern refugee regime

00:02:28.798 --> 00:02:32.878
was created in the aftermath
of the Second World War by these guys.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:37.094
Its basic aim is to ensure

00:02:37.118 --> 00:02:41.334
that when a state fails,
or worse, turns against its own people,

00:02:41.358 --> 00:02:42.934
people have somewhere to go,

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:46.614
to live in safety and dignity
until they can go home.

00:02:46.638 --> 00:02:51.918
It was created precisely for situations
like the situation we see in Syria today.

00:02:52.638 --> 00:02:57.494
Through an international convention
signed by 147 governments,

00:02:57.518 --> 00:03:00.534
the 1951 Convention
on the Status of Refugees,

00:03:00.558 --> 00:03:03.734
and an international organization, UNHCR,

00:03:03.758 --> 00:03:08.534
states committed to reciprocally
admit people onto their territory

00:03:08.558 --> 00:03:11.078
who flee conflict and persecution.

00:03:11.638 --> 00:03:14.238
But today, that system is failing.

00:03:14.878 --> 00:03:18.318
In theory, refugees
have a right to seek asylum.

00:03:18.838 --> 00:03:22.798
In practice, our immigration policies
block the path to safety.

00:03:23.238 --> 00:03:27.574
In theory, refugees have a right
to a pathway to integration,

00:03:27.598 --> 00:03:29.638
or return to the country
they've come from.

00:03:30.318 --> 00:03:33.558
But in practice, they get stuck
in almost indefinite limbo.

00:03:34.198 --> 00:03:37.278
In theory, refugees
are a shared global responsibility.

00:03:37.998 --> 00:03:42.334
In practice, geography means
that countries proximate the conflict

00:03:42.358 --> 00:03:45.958
take the overwhelming majority
of the world's refugees.

00:03:46.678 --> 00:03:49.414
The system isn't broken
because the rules are wrong.

00:03:49.438 --> 00:03:53.358
It's that we're not applying them
adequately to a changing world,

00:03:53.798 --> 00:03:55.798
and that's what we need to reconsider.

00:03:56.398 --> 00:04:00.894
So I want to explain to you a little bit
about how the current system works.

00:04:00.918 --> 00:04:03.078
How does the refugee regime actually work?

00:04:03.518 --> 00:04:06.294
But not from a top-down
institutional perspective,

00:04:06.318 --> 00:04:09.638
rather from the perspective of a refugee.

00:04:10.198 --> 00:04:12.654
So imagine a Syrian woman.

00:04:12.678 --> 00:04:14.278
Let's call her Amira.

00:04:14.838 --> 00:04:18.718
And Amira to me represents
many of the people I've met in the region.

00:04:19.518 --> 00:04:22.854
Amira, like around 25 percent
of the world's refugees,

00:04:22.878 --> 00:04:24.158
is a woman with children,

00:04:24.798 --> 00:04:28.054
and she can't go home
because she comes from this city

00:04:28.078 --> 00:04:30.094
that you see before you, Homs,

00:04:30.118 --> 00:04:32.854
a once beautiful and historic city

00:04:32.878 --> 00:04:34.374
now under rubble.

00:04:34.398 --> 00:04:36.238
And so Amira can't go back there.

00:04:37.078 --> 00:04:41.294
But Amira also has no hope
of resettlement to a third country,

00:04:41.318 --> 00:04:42.814
because that's a lottery ticket

00:04:42.838 --> 00:04:46.278
only available to less than one percent
of the world's refugees.

00:04:46.838 --> 00:04:49.094
So Amira and her family

00:04:49.118 --> 00:04:51.294
face an almost impossible choice.

00:04:51.318 --> 00:04:53.718
They have three basic options.

00:04:54.518 --> 00:04:59.478
The first option is that Amira
can take her family to a camp.

00:05:00.478 --> 00:05:02.638
In the camp, she might get assistance,

00:05:03.118 --> 00:05:06.814
but there are very few prospects
for Amira and her family.

00:05:06.838 --> 00:05:10.094
Camps are in bleak, arid locations,

00:05:10.118 --> 00:05:11.358
often in the desert.

00:05:11.998 --> 00:05:14.694
In the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan,

00:05:14.718 --> 00:05:19.118
you can hear the shells
across the border in Syria at nighttime.

00:05:20.558 --> 00:05:23.134
There's restricted economic activity.

00:05:23.158 --> 00:05:25.318
Education is often of poor quality.

00:05:25.918 --> 00:05:27.254
And around the world,

00:05:27.278 --> 00:05:30.374
some 80 percent of refugees
who are in camps

00:05:30.398 --> 00:05:32.934
have to stay for at least five years.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.854
It's a miserable existence,

00:05:34.878 --> 00:05:37.254
and that's probably why, in reality,

00:05:37.278 --> 00:05:39.878
only nine percent of Syrians
choose that option.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:44.934
Alternatively, Amira can head
to an urban area

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.998
in a neighboring country,
like Amman or Beirut.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:52.998
That's an option that about 75 percent
of Syrian refugees have taken.

00:05:54.158 --> 00:05:56.878
But there, there's
great difficulty as well.

00:05:57.678 --> 00:06:01.974
Refugees in such urban areas
don't usually have the right to work.

00:06:01.998 --> 00:06:04.958
They don't usually get
significant access to assistance.

00:06:05.398 --> 00:06:09.094
And so when Amira and her family
have used up their basic savings,

00:06:09.118 --> 00:06:12.798
they're left with very little
and likely to face urban destitution.

00:06:14.238 --> 00:06:16.078
So there's a third alternative,

00:06:16.878 --> 00:06:20.598
and it's one that increasing
numbers of Syrians are taking.

00:06:21.798 --> 00:06:25.974
Amira can seek some hope for her family

00:06:25.998 --> 00:06:29.734
by risking their lives
on a dangerous and perilous journey

00:06:29.758 --> 00:06:31.254
to another country,

00:06:31.278 --> 00:06:34.798
and it's that which we're seeing
in Europe today.

00:06:35.398 --> 00:06:40.654
Around the world, we present refugees
with an almost impossible choice

00:06:40.678 --> 00:06:42.494
between three options:

00:06:42.518 --> 00:06:46.718
encampment, urban destitution
and dangerous journeys.

00:06:47.478 --> 00:06:51.798
For refugees, that choice is
the global refugee regime today.

00:06:52.558 --> 00:06:54.198
But I think it's a false choice.

00:06:54.718 --> 00:06:56.798
I think we can reconsider that choice.

00:06:57.398 --> 00:07:00.758
The reason why we limit those options

00:07:01.998 --> 00:07:04.478
is because we think

00:07:05.038 --> 00:07:09.414
that those are the only options
that are available to refugees,

00:07:09.438 --> 00:07:10.638
and they're not.

00:07:11.078 --> 00:07:14.574
Politicians frame the issue
as a zero-sum issue,

00:07:14.598 --> 00:07:18.534
that if we benefit refugees,
we're imposing costs on citizens.

00:07:18.558 --> 00:07:20.614
We tend to have a collective assumption

00:07:20.638 --> 00:07:24.294
that refugees are an inevitable cost
or burden to society.

00:07:24.318 --> 00:07:26.398
But they don't have to.
They can contribute.

00:07:26.838 --> 00:07:28.254
So what I want to argue

00:07:28.278 --> 00:07:31.254
is there are ways in which we can
expand that choice set

00:07:31.278 --> 00:07:33.294
and still benefit everyone else:

00:07:33.318 --> 00:07:35.174
the host states and communities,

00:07:35.198 --> 00:07:38.518
our societies and refugees themselves.

00:07:39.038 --> 00:07:41.014
And I want to suggest four ways

00:07:41.038 --> 00:07:44.878
we can transform the paradigm
of how we think about refugees.

00:07:45.478 --> 00:07:47.918
All four ways have one thing in common:

00:07:48.398 --> 00:07:52.174
they're all ways in which we take
the opportunities of globalization,

00:07:52.198 --> 00:07:54.254
mobility and markets,

00:07:54.278 --> 00:07:57.518
and update the way we think
about the refugee issue.

00:07:58.238 --> 00:07:59.934
The first one I want to think about

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
is the idea of enabling environments,

00:08:02.678 --> 00:08:05.534
and it starts from
a very basic recognition

00:08:05.558 --> 00:08:08.254
that refugees are human beings
like everyone else,

00:08:08.278 --> 00:08:10.678
but they're just
in extraordinary circumstances.

00:08:11.238 --> 00:08:13.214
Together with my colleagues in Oxford,

00:08:13.238 --> 00:08:15.894
we've embarked on
a research project in Uganda

00:08:15.918 --> 00:08:18.958
looking at the economic lives of refugees.

00:08:19.798 --> 00:08:23.854
We chose Uganda not because
it's representative of all host countries.

00:08:23.878 --> 00:08:25.358
It's not. It's exceptional.

00:08:25.918 --> 00:08:28.294
Unlike most host countries
around the world,

00:08:28.318 --> 00:08:29.774
what Uganda has done

00:08:29.798 --> 00:08:32.174
is give refugees economic opportunity.

00:08:32.198 --> 00:08:35.558
It gives them the right to work.
It gives them freedom of movement.

00:08:36.158 --> 00:08:39.054
And the results of that are extraordinary

00:08:39.078 --> 00:08:41.678
both for refugees and the host community.

00:08:42.438 --> 00:08:44.414
In the capital city, Kampala,

00:08:44.438 --> 00:08:49.853
we found that 21 percent of refugees
own a business that employs other people,

00:08:49.877 --> 00:08:52.334
and 40 percent of those employees

00:08:52.358 --> 00:08:54.334
are nationals of the host country.

00:08:54.358 --> 00:08:56.534
In other words, refugees are making jobs

00:08:56.558 --> 00:08:59.198
for citizens of the host country.

00:08:59.878 --> 00:09:03.214
Even in the camps,
we found extraordinary examples

00:09:03.238 --> 00:09:06.798
of vibrant, flourishing
and entrepreneurial businesses.

00:09:07.758 --> 00:09:11.094
For example, in a settlement
called Nakivale,

00:09:11.118 --> 00:09:14.094
we found examples of Congolese refugees

00:09:14.118 --> 00:09:16.654
running digital music exchange businesses.

00:09:16.678 --> 00:09:20.454
We found a Rwandan
who runs a business that's available

00:09:20.478 --> 00:09:23.214
to allow the youth to play computer games

00:09:23.238 --> 00:09:26.998
on recycled games consoles
and recycled televisions.

00:09:28.398 --> 00:09:31.214
Against the odds of extreme constraint,

00:09:31.238 --> 00:09:32.558
refugees are innovating,

00:09:33.278 --> 00:09:36.707
and the gentleman you see before you
is a Congolese guy called Demou-Kay.

00:09:37.158 --> 00:09:40.814
Demou-Kay arrived
in the settlement with very little,

00:09:40.838 --> 00:09:43.134
but he wanted to be a filmmaker.

00:09:43.158 --> 00:09:47.094
So with friends and colleagues,
he started a community radio station,

00:09:47.118 --> 00:09:48.854
he rented a video camera,

00:09:48.878 --> 00:09:50.374
and he's now making films.

00:09:50.398 --> 00:09:52.374
He made two documentary films

00:09:52.398 --> 00:09:54.374
with and for our team,

00:09:54.398 --> 00:09:57.718
and he's making a successful business
out of very little.

00:09:58.598 --> 00:10:00.574
It's those kinds of examples

00:10:00.598 --> 00:10:03.334
that should guide
our response to refugees.

00:10:03.358 --> 00:10:04.694
Rather than seeing refugees

00:10:04.718 --> 00:10:07.974
as inevitably dependent
upon humanitarian assistance,

00:10:07.998 --> 00:10:11.398
we need to provide them
with opportunities for human flourishing.

00:10:12.158 --> 00:10:16.384
Yes, clothes, blankets, shelter, food

00:10:16.396 --> 00:10:19.174
are all important in the emergency phase,

00:10:19.198 --> 00:10:21.798
but we need to also look beyond that.

00:10:22.158 --> 00:10:26.494
We need to provide opportunities
to connectivity, electricity,

00:10:26.518 --> 00:10:28.798
education, the right to work,

00:10:29.358 --> 00:10:31.078
access to capital and banking.

00:10:31.518 --> 00:10:33.654
All the ways in which we take for granted

00:10:33.678 --> 00:10:35.814
that we are plugged in
to the global economy

00:10:35.838 --> 00:10:38.398
can and should apply to refugees.

00:10:39.238 --> 00:10:42.718
The second idea I want to discuss
is economic zones.

00:10:43.278 --> 00:10:46.014
Unfortunately, not every
host country in the world

00:10:46.038 --> 00:10:48.078
takes the approach Uganda has taken.

00:10:48.438 --> 00:10:51.774
Most host countries don't open up
their economies to refugees

00:10:51.798 --> 00:10:52.998
in the same way.

00:10:53.318 --> 00:10:57.918
But there are still pragmatic
alternative options that we can use.

00:10:59.118 --> 00:11:01.654
Last April, I traveled to Jordan
with my colleague,

00:11:01.678 --> 00:11:03.638
the development economist Paul Collier,

00:11:04.358 --> 00:11:07.214
and we brainstormed an idea
while we were there

00:11:07.238 --> 00:11:09.694
with the international community
and the government,

00:11:09.718 --> 00:11:12.054
an idea to bring jobs to Syrians

00:11:12.078 --> 00:11:15.694
while supporting Jordan's
national development strategy.

00:11:15.718 --> 00:11:18.518
The idea is for an economic zone,

00:11:19.038 --> 00:11:22.574
one in which we could potentially
integrate the employment of refugees

00:11:22.598 --> 00:11:26.078
alongside the employment
of Jordanian host nationals.

00:11:26.798 --> 00:11:30.214
And just 15 minutes away
from the Zaatari refugee camp,

00:11:30.238 --> 00:11:32.374
home to 83,000 refugees,

00:11:32.398 --> 00:11:34.414
is an existing economic zone

00:11:34.438 --> 00:11:37.158
called the King Hussein
Bin Talal Development Area.

00:11:37.878 --> 00:11:40.654
The government has spent
over a hundred million dollars

00:11:40.678 --> 00:11:44.494
connecting it to the electricity grid,
connecting it to the road network,

00:11:44.518 --> 00:11:46.134
but it lacked two things:

00:11:46.158 --> 00:11:48.894
access to labor and inward investment.

00:11:48.918 --> 00:11:51.814
So what if refugees
were able to work there

00:11:51.838 --> 00:11:53.654
rather than being stuck in camps,

00:11:53.678 --> 00:11:57.694
able to support their families and develop
skills through vocational training

00:11:57.718 --> 00:11:59.158
before they go back to Syria?

00:11:59.798 --> 00:12:02.094
We recognized that
that could benefit Jordan,

00:12:02.118 --> 00:12:04.894
whose development strategy
requires it to make the leap

00:12:04.918 --> 00:12:07.734
as a middle income country
to manufacturing.

00:12:07.758 --> 00:12:11.454
It could benefit refugees,
but it could also contribute

00:12:11.478 --> 00:12:13.854
to the postconflict
reconstruction of Syria

00:12:13.878 --> 00:12:16.654
by recognizing that we need
to incubate refugees

00:12:16.678 --> 00:12:20.238
as the best source
of eventually rebuilding Syria.

00:12:20.718 --> 00:12:23.774
We published the idea
in the journal Foreign Affairs.

00:12:23.798 --> 00:12:26.014
King Abdullah has picked up on the idea.

00:12:26.038 --> 00:12:29.014
It was announced at the London
Syria Conference two weeks ago,

00:12:29.038 --> 00:12:31.638
and a pilot will begin in the summer.

00:12:32.078 --> 00:12:35.678
(Applause)

00:12:37.078 --> 00:12:39.774
The third idea that I want to put to you

00:12:39.798 --> 00:12:43.414
is preference matching
between states and refugees

00:12:43.438 --> 00:12:46.574
to lead to the kinds of happy outcomes
you see here in the selfie

00:12:46.598 --> 00:12:49.478
featuring Angela Merkel
and a Syrian refugee.

00:12:50.398 --> 00:12:54.398
What we rarely do is ask refugees
what they want, where they want to go,

00:12:54.918 --> 00:12:56.774
but I'd argue we can do that

00:12:56.798 --> 00:12:58.878
and still make everyone better off.

00:12:59.598 --> 00:13:03.734
The economist Alvin Roth has developed
the idea of matching markets,

00:13:03.758 --> 00:13:08.998
ways in which the preference ranking
of the parties shapes an eventual match.

00:13:09.678 --> 00:13:12.734
My colleagues Will Jones
and Alex Teytelboym

00:13:12.758 --> 00:13:16.894
have explored ways in which that idea
could be applied to refugees,

00:13:16.918 --> 00:13:20.454
to ask refugees to rank
their preferred destinations,

00:13:20.478 --> 00:13:24.254
but also allow states to rank
the types of refugees they want

00:13:24.278 --> 00:13:27.094
on skills criteria or language criteria

00:13:27.118 --> 00:13:28.814
and allow those to match.

00:13:28.838 --> 00:13:30.934
Now, of course
you'd need to build in quotas

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:34.214
on things like diversity
and vulnerability,

00:13:34.238 --> 00:13:37.774
but it's a way of increasing
the possibilities of matching.

00:13:37.798 --> 00:13:40.294
The matching idea
has been successfully used

00:13:40.318 --> 00:13:45.454
to match, for instance,
students with university places,

00:13:45.478 --> 00:13:47.974
to match kidney donors with patients,

00:13:47.998 --> 00:13:52.134
and it underlies the kind of algorithms
that exist on dating websites.

00:13:52.158 --> 00:13:55.254
So why not apply that
to give refugees greater choice?

00:13:55.278 --> 00:13:57.326
It could also be used
at the national level,

00:13:57.350 --> 00:13:59.334
where one of the great challenges we face

00:13:59.358 --> 00:14:03.094
is to persuade local communities
to accept refugees.

00:14:03.118 --> 00:14:05.574
And at the moment,
in my country, for instance,

00:14:05.598 --> 00:14:09.774
we often send engineers to rural areas
and farmers to the cities,

00:14:09.798 --> 00:14:11.654
which makes no sense at all.

00:14:11.678 --> 00:14:16.254
So matching markets offer a potential way
to bring those preferences together

00:14:16.278 --> 00:14:20.214
and listen to the needs and demands
of the populations that host

00:14:20.238 --> 00:14:22.078
and the refugees themselves.

00:14:22.798 --> 00:14:26.518
The fourth idea I want to put to you
is of humanitarian visas.

00:14:27.198 --> 00:14:29.894
Much of the tragedy and chaos
we've seen in Europe

00:14:29.918 --> 00:14:31.918
was entirely avoidable.

00:14:32.358 --> 00:14:36.454
It stems from a fundamental contradiction
in Europe's asylum policy,

00:14:36.478 --> 00:14:37.854
which is the following:

00:14:37.878 --> 00:14:40.374
that in order to seek asylum in Europe,

00:14:40.398 --> 00:14:45.414
you have to arrive spontaneously
by embarking on those dangerous journeys

00:14:45.438 --> 00:14:46.638
that I described.

00:14:47.478 --> 00:14:52.214
But why should those journeys be necessary
in an era of the budget airline

00:14:52.238 --> 00:14:54.654
and modern consular capabilities?

00:14:54.678 --> 00:14:57.014
They're completely unnecessary journeys,

00:14:57.038 --> 00:15:00.814
and last year, they led to the deaths
of over 3,000 people

00:15:00.838 --> 00:15:04.318
on Europe's borders
and within European territory.

00:15:05.318 --> 00:15:06.934
If refugees were simply allowed

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.734
to travel directly
and seek asylum in Europe,

00:15:09.758 --> 00:15:11.054
we would avoid that,

00:15:11.078 --> 00:15:12.614
and there's a way of doing that

00:15:12.638 --> 00:15:14.934
through something
called a humanitarian visa,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:18.494
that allows people
to collect a visa at an embassy

00:15:18.518 --> 00:15:20.654
or a consulate in a neighboring country

00:15:20.678 --> 00:15:22.574
and then simply pay their own way

00:15:22.598 --> 00:15:25.158
through a ferry or a flight to Europe.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.934
It costs around a thousand euros

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:31.374
to take a smuggler
from Turkey to the Greek islands.

00:15:31.398 --> 00:15:36.854
It costs 200 euros to take a budget
airline from Bodrum to Frankfurt.

00:15:36.878 --> 00:15:40.654
If we allowed refugees to do that,
it would have major advantages.

00:15:40.678 --> 00:15:41.958
It would save lives,

00:15:42.718 --> 00:15:46.654
it would undercut
the entire market for smugglers,

00:15:46.678 --> 00:15:50.014
and it would remove the chaos
we see from Europe's front line

00:15:50.038 --> 00:15:52.094
in areas like the Greek islands.

00:15:52.118 --> 00:15:56.358
It's politics that prevents us doing that
rather than a rational solution.

00:15:56.838 --> 00:15:59.174
And this is an idea that has been applied.

00:15:59.198 --> 00:16:01.854
Brazil has adopted a pioneering approach

00:16:01.878 --> 00:16:06.174
where over 2,000 Syrians
have been able to get humanitarian visas,

00:16:06.198 --> 00:16:10.574
enter Brazil, and claim refugee status
on arrival in Brazil.

00:16:10.598 --> 00:16:13.494
And in that scheme,
every Syrian who has gone through it

00:16:13.518 --> 00:16:17.478
has received refugee status
and been recognized as a genuine refugee.

00:16:18.118 --> 00:16:20.358
There is a historical precedent
for it as well.

00:16:20.878 --> 00:16:24.214
Between 1922 and 1942,

00:16:24.238 --> 00:16:28.014
these Nansen passports
were used as travel documents

00:16:28.038 --> 00:16:33.574
to allow 450,000 Assyrians,
Turks and Chechens

00:16:33.598 --> 00:16:35.094
to travel across Europe

00:16:35.118 --> 00:16:37.878
and claim refugee status
elsewhere in Europe.

00:16:38.478 --> 00:16:41.214
And the Nansen
International Refugee Office

00:16:41.238 --> 00:16:43.094
received the Nobel Peace Prize

00:16:43.118 --> 00:16:46.078
in recognition of this
being a viable strategy.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:50.174
So all four of these ideas
that I've presented you

00:16:50.198 --> 00:16:53.518
are ways in which we can expand
Amira's choice set.

00:16:53.878 --> 00:16:57.134
They're ways in which we can have
greater choice for refugees

00:16:57.158 --> 00:17:00.974
beyond those basic,
impossible three options

00:17:00.998 --> 00:17:02.214
I explained to you

00:17:02.238 --> 00:17:04.318
and still leave others better off.

00:17:04.918 --> 00:17:08.294
In conclusion,
we really need a new vision,

00:17:08.318 --> 00:17:11.094
a vision that enlarges
the choices of refugees

00:17:11.118 --> 00:17:13.654
but recognizes that they
don't have to be a burden.

00:17:13.678 --> 00:17:17.133
There's nothing inevitable
about refugees being a cost.

00:17:17.158 --> 00:17:20.413
Yes, they are a humanitarian
responsibility,

00:17:20.438 --> 00:17:24.054
but they're human beings
with skills, talents, aspirations,

00:17:24.077 --> 00:17:26.758
with the ability to make
contributions -- if we let them.

00:17:28.478 --> 00:17:29.718
In the new world,

00:17:30.277 --> 00:17:32.534
migration is not going to go away.

00:17:32.557 --> 00:17:35.534
What we've seen in Europe
will be with us for many years.

00:17:35.557 --> 00:17:37.373
People will continue to travel,

00:17:37.398 --> 00:17:39.254
they'll continue to be displaced,

00:17:39.277 --> 00:17:42.774
and we need to find rational,
realistic ways of managing this --

00:17:42.798 --> 00:17:45.814
not based on the old logics
of humanitarian assistance,

00:17:45.838 --> 00:17:47.934
not based on logics of charity,

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.574
but building on the opportunities

00:17:49.598 --> 00:17:52.974
offered by globalization,
markets and mobility.

00:17:52.998 --> 00:17:56.414
I'd urge you all to wake up
and urge our politicians

00:17:56.438 --> 00:17:58.294
to wake up to this challenge.

00:17:58.318 --> 00:17:59.574
Thank you very much.
