and I am truly grateful for my upbringing,

00:00:31.758 --> 00:00:36.254
because I always felt completely
comfortable designing my life

00:00:36.278 --> 00:00:38.238
exactly as I saw fit.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.294
And in point of fact,

00:00:40.318 --> 00:00:43.414
I took a route that was not exactly
what my parents had in mind.

00:00:43.438 --> 00:00:46.358
When I was 19, I dropped out of college --

00:00:47.078 --> 00:00:49.134
dropped out, kicked out, splitting hairs.

00:00:49.158 --> 00:00:51.518
(Laughter)

00:00:52.638 --> 00:00:56.894
And I went on the road
as a professional French horn player,

00:00:56.918 --> 00:00:58.614
which was my lifelong dream.

00:00:58.638 --> 00:01:01.534
I played chamber music
all over the United States and Europe,

00:01:01.558 --> 00:01:03.334
and I toured for a couple of years

00:01:03.358 --> 00:01:06.334
with a great jazz guitar player
named Charlie Bird.

00:01:06.358 --> 00:01:07.934
And by the end of my 20s,

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:12.134
I wound up as a member of the Barcelona
Symphony Orchestra in Spain.

00:01:12.158 --> 00:01:13.374
What a great life.

00:01:13.398 --> 00:01:16.974
And you know, my parents never complained.

00:01:16.998 --> 00:01:18.974
They supported me all the way through it.

00:01:18.998 --> 00:01:20.894
It wasn't their dream.

00:01:20.918 --> 00:01:23.061
They used to tell
their neighbors and friends,

00:01:23.085 --> 00:01:26.134
"Our son, he's taking a gap decade."

00:01:26.158 --> 00:01:27.998
(Laughter)

00:01:28.838 --> 00:01:30.734
And --

00:01:30.758 --> 00:01:35.654
There was, however, one awkward
conversation about my lifestyle

00:01:35.678 --> 00:01:37.134
that I want to tell you about.

00:01:37.158 --> 00:01:39.934
I was 27, and I was home from Barcelona,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.654
and I was visiting
my parents for Christmas,

00:01:42.678 --> 00:01:46.358
and I was cooking dinner with my mother,
and we were alone in the kitchen.

00:01:47.198 --> 00:01:50.014
And she was quiet, too quiet.

00:01:50.038 --> 00:01:51.494
Something was wrong.

00:01:51.518 --> 00:01:54.038
And so I said, "Mom, what's on your mind?"

00:01:54.718 --> 00:01:58.974
And she said, "Your dad and I
are really worried about you."

00:01:58.998 --> 00:02:01.894
And I said, "What?"
I mean, what could it be, at this point?

00:02:01.918 --> 00:02:04.718
And she said, "I want you to be
completely honest with me:

00:02:05.638 --> 00:02:07.574
have you been voting for Republicans?"

00:02:07.598 --> 00:02:09.798
(Laughter)

00:02:12.638 --> 00:02:14.014
Now, the truth is,

00:02:14.038 --> 00:02:18.414
I wasn't really political,
I was just a French horn player.

00:02:18.438 --> 00:02:21.973
But I had a bit of an epiphany,

00:02:21.997 --> 00:02:24.854
and they had detected it,
and it was causing some confusion.

00:02:24.878 --> 00:02:29.558
You see, I had become
an enthusiast for capitalism,

00:02:30.158 --> 00:02:32.774
and I want to tell you why that is.

00:02:32.798 --> 00:02:36.934
It stems from a lifelong interest of mine

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:38.918
in, believe it or not, poverty.

00:02:39.878 --> 00:02:42.214
See, when I was a kid
growing up in Seattle,

00:02:42.238 --> 00:02:45.854
I remember the first time
I saw real poverty.

00:02:45.878 --> 00:02:50.254
We were a lower middle class family,
but that's of course not real poverty.

00:02:50.278 --> 00:02:52.014
That's not even close.

00:02:52.038 --> 00:02:55.454
The first time I saw poverty,
and poverty's face,

00:02:55.478 --> 00:02:58.294
was when I was six
or seven years old, early 1970s.

00:02:58.318 --> 00:03:02.854
And it was like a lot of you,
kind of a prosaic example, kind of trite.

00:03:02.878 --> 00:03:06.254
It was a picture in the National
Geographic Magazine

00:03:06.278 --> 00:03:10.574
of a kid who was my age in East Africa,

00:03:10.598 --> 00:03:13.174
and there were flies on his face
and a distended belly.

00:03:13.198 --> 00:03:18.118
And he wasn't going to make it,
and I knew that, and I was helpless.

00:03:18.678 --> 00:03:20.654
Some of you remember that picture,

00:03:20.678 --> 00:03:22.694
not exactly that picture,
one just like it.

00:03:22.718 --> 00:03:27.518
It introduced the West
to grinding poverty around the world.

00:03:28.198 --> 00:03:32.974
Well, that vision kind of haunted me
as I grew up and I went to school

00:03:32.998 --> 00:03:34.774
and I dropped out and dropped in

00:03:34.798 --> 00:03:36.758
and started my family.

00:03:37.454 --> 00:03:39.454
And I wondered, what happened to that kid?

00:03:39.478 --> 00:03:42.158
Or to people just like him
all over the world?

00:03:43.158 --> 00:03:45.934
And so I started to study,
even though I wasn't in college,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.374
I was looking for the answer:

00:03:47.398 --> 00:03:49.494
what happened to the world's
poorest people?

00:03:49.518 --> 00:03:51.774
Has it gotten worse?
Has it gotten better? What?

00:03:51.798 --> 00:03:54.574
And I found the answer,
and it changed my life,

00:03:54.598 --> 00:03:56.158
and I want to share it with you.

00:03:56.998 --> 00:03:58.198
See --

00:03:59.718 --> 00:04:03.974
most Americans believe
that poverty has gotten worse

00:04:03.998 --> 00:04:07.134
since we were children,
since they saw that vision.

00:04:07.158 --> 00:04:10.814
If you ask Americans, "Has poverty
gotten worse or better around the world?",

00:04:10.838 --> 00:04:14.174
70 percent will say that hunger
has gotten worse since the early 1970s.

00:04:14.198 --> 00:04:15.694
But here's the truth.

00:04:15.718 --> 00:04:19.414
Here's the epiphany that I had
that changed my thinking.

00:04:19.438 --> 00:04:22.198
From 1970 until today,

00:04:22.838 --> 00:04:25.694
the percentage of the world's population

00:04:25.718 --> 00:04:27.734
living in starvation levels,

00:04:27.758 --> 00:04:31.414
living on a dollar a day or less,
obviously adjusted for inflation,

00:04:31.438 --> 00:04:34.654
that percentage has declined

00:04:34.678 --> 00:04:36.358
by 80 percent.

00:04:37.038 --> 00:04:40.014
There's been an 80 percent decline
in the world's worst poverty

00:04:40.038 --> 00:04:41.254
since I was a kid.

00:04:41.278 --> 00:04:42.854
And I didn't even know about it.

00:04:42.878 --> 00:04:44.758
This, my friends, that's a miracle.

00:04:45.278 --> 00:04:47.574
That's something we ought to celebrate.

00:04:47.598 --> 00:04:51.854
It's the greatest antipoverty achievement
in the history of mankind,

00:04:51.878 --> 00:04:54.414
and it happened in our lifetimes.

00:04:54.438 --> 00:04:57.974
(Applause)

00:04:57.998 --> 00:05:02.854
So when I learned this, I asked,
what did that? What made it possible?

00:05:02.878 --> 00:05:05.694
Because if you don't know why,
you can't do it again.

00:05:05.718 --> 00:05:07.054
If you want to replicate it

00:05:07.078 --> 00:05:09.614
and get the next two billion
people out of poverty,

00:05:09.638 --> 00:05:12.414
because that's what we're talking about:
since I was a kid,

00:05:12.438 --> 00:05:15.254
two billion of the least of these,
our brothers and sisters,

00:05:15.274 --> 00:05:16.814
have been pulled out of poverty.

00:05:16.838 --> 00:05:19.324
I want the next two billion,
so I've got to know why.

00:05:19.344 --> 00:05:20.974
And I went in search of an answer.

00:05:20.998 --> 00:05:23.654
And it wasn't a political answer,
because I didn't care.

00:05:23.678 --> 00:05:25.334
You know what, I still don't care.

00:05:25.358 --> 00:05:30.174
I wanted the best answer
from mainstream economists

00:05:30.198 --> 00:05:32.318
left, right and center.

00:05:32.838 --> 00:05:34.038
And here it is.

00:05:34.518 --> 00:05:35.774
Here are the reasons.

00:05:35.798 --> 00:05:39.534
There are five reasons that two billion
of our brothers and sisters

00:05:39.558 --> 00:05:41.934
have been pulled out of poverty
since I was a kid.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.478
Number one: globalization.

00:05:45.038 --> 00:05:47.134
Number two: free trade.

00:05:47.158 --> 00:05:49.494
Number three: property rights.

00:05:49.518 --> 00:05:52.054
Number four: rule of law.

00:05:52.078 --> 00:05:55.054
Number five: entrepreneurship.

00:05:55.078 --> 00:05:59.334
It was the free enterprise system
spreading around the world

00:05:59.358 --> 00:06:01.134
after 1970 that did that.

00:06:01.158 --> 00:06:03.574
Now, I'm not naive.

00:06:03.598 --> 00:06:06.054
I know that free enterprise isn't perfect,

00:06:06.078 --> 00:06:09.214
and I know that free enterprise
isn't everything we need

00:06:09.238 --> 00:06:10.454
to build a better world.

00:06:10.478 --> 00:06:13.014
But that is great.

00:06:13.038 --> 00:06:14.374
And that's beyond politics.

00:06:14.398 --> 00:06:16.494
Here's what I learned.
This is the epiphany.

00:06:16.518 --> 00:06:19.534
Capitalism is not just about accumulation.

00:06:19.558 --> 00:06:22.094
At its best, it's about aspiration,

00:06:22.118 --> 00:06:24.814
which is what so many people
on this stage talk about,

00:06:24.838 --> 00:06:28.054
is the aspiration that comes from dreams

00:06:28.078 --> 00:06:30.334
that are embedded
in the free enterprise system.

00:06:30.358 --> 00:06:32.534
And we've got to share it
with more people.

00:06:32.558 --> 00:06:35.774
Now, I want to tell you
about a second epiphany

00:06:35.798 --> 00:06:38.294
that's related to that first one

00:06:38.318 --> 00:06:41.374
that I think can bring us progress,
not just around the world,

00:06:41.398 --> 00:06:42.638
but right here at home.

00:06:43.798 --> 00:06:45.814
The best quote I've ever heard

00:06:45.838 --> 00:06:49.414
to summarize the thoughts
that I've just given you

00:06:49.438 --> 00:06:51.494
about pulling people out of poverty

00:06:51.518 --> 00:06:53.614
is as follows:

00:06:53.638 --> 00:06:58.494
"Free markets have created more wealth
than any system in history.

00:06:58.518 --> 00:07:01.318
They have lifted billions out of poverty."

00:07:02.358 --> 00:07:03.614
Who said it?

00:07:03.638 --> 00:07:07.038
It sounds like Milton Friedman
or Ronald Reagan.

00:07:07.758 --> 00:07:08.958
Wrong.

00:07:09.438 --> 00:07:11.678
President Barack Obama said that.

00:07:12.398 --> 00:07:13.998
Why do I know it by heart?

00:07:14.918 --> 00:07:16.358
Because he said it to me.

00:07:17.598 --> 00:07:19.094
Crazy.

00:07:19.118 --> 00:07:21.798
And I said, "Hallelujah."

00:07:22.758 --> 00:07:25.254
But more than that, I said,

00:07:25.278 --> 00:07:26.974
"What an opportunity."

00:07:26.998 --> 00:07:28.494
You know what I was thinking?

00:07:28.518 --> 00:07:30.974
It was at an event
that we were doing on the subject

00:07:30.998 --> 00:07:32.934
at Georgetown University in May of 2015.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.734
And I thought, this is the solution

00:07:35.758 --> 00:07:39.254
to the biggest problem
facing America today. What?

00:07:39.278 --> 00:07:42.054
It's coming together around these ideas,

00:07:42.078 --> 00:07:43.814
liberals and conservatives,

00:07:43.838 --> 00:07:46.918
to help people who need us the most.

00:07:47.438 --> 00:07:50.734
Now, I don't have to tell anybody
in this room that we're in a crisis,

00:07:50.758 --> 00:07:54.334
in America and many countries around
the world with political polarization.

00:07:54.358 --> 00:07:56.254
It's risen to critical, crisis levels.

00:07:56.278 --> 00:07:58.678
It's unpleasant. It's not right.

00:07:59.278 --> 00:08:00.934
There was an article last year

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.574
in the Proceedings
of the National Academy of Sciences,

00:08:03.598 --> 00:08:07.078
which is one of the most
prestigious scientific journals

00:08:08.038 --> 00:08:09.294
published in the West.

00:08:09.318 --> 00:08:11.774
And it was an article in 2014

00:08:11.798 --> 00:08:14.214
on political motive asymmetry.

00:08:14.238 --> 00:08:16.953
What's that? That's what psychologists
call the phenomenon

00:08:16.977 --> 00:08:20.897
of assuming that your ideology
is based in love

00:08:21.398 --> 00:08:24.278
but your opponents' ideology
is based in hate.

00:08:24.878 --> 00:08:27.694
It's common in world conflict.

00:08:27.718 --> 00:08:31.758
You expect to see this between
Palestinians and Israelis, for example.

00:08:32.358 --> 00:08:34.774
What the authors of this article found

00:08:34.798 --> 00:08:39.414
was that in America today,
a majority of Republicans and Democrats

00:08:39.438 --> 00:08:42.014
suffer from political motive asymmetry.

00:08:42.038 --> 00:08:45.894
A majority of people in our country today
who are politically active believe

00:08:45.918 --> 00:08:49.334
that they are motivated by love
but the other side is motivated by hate.

00:08:49.358 --> 00:08:50.894
Think about it. Think about it.

00:08:50.918 --> 00:08:53.093
Most people are walking around saying,

00:08:53.117 --> 00:08:56.294
"You know, my ideology
is based on basic benevolence,

00:08:56.318 --> 00:08:57.534
I want to help people,

00:08:57.558 --> 00:09:00.358
but the other guys,
they're evil and out to get me."

00:09:01.158 --> 00:09:06.454
You can't progress as a society
when you have this kind of asymmetry.

00:09:06.478 --> 00:09:07.678
It's impossible.

00:09:08.518 --> 00:09:09.774
How do we solve it?

00:09:09.798 --> 00:09:13.454
Well, first, let's be honest:
there are differences.

00:09:13.478 --> 00:09:17.174
Let's not minimize the differences.
That would be really naïve.

00:09:17.198 --> 00:09:19.254
There's a lot of good research on this.

00:09:19.278 --> 00:09:22.414
A veteran of the TED stage
is my friend Jonathan Haidt.

00:09:22.438 --> 00:09:25.494
He's a psychology professor
at New York University.

00:09:25.518 --> 00:09:30.454
He does work on the ideology
and values and morals of different people

00:09:30.478 --> 00:09:31.718
to see how they differ.

00:09:32.318 --> 00:09:35.128
And he's shown, for example,
that conservatives and liberals

00:09:35.152 --> 00:09:38.168
have a very different emphasis
on what they think is important.

00:09:38.192 --> 00:09:41.494
For example, Jon Haidt has shown

00:09:41.518 --> 00:09:44.494
that liberals care about poverty

00:09:44.518 --> 00:09:47.398
59 percent more than they care
about economic liberty.

00:09:48.238 --> 00:09:50.734
And conservatives
care about economic liberty

00:09:50.758 --> 00:09:53.918
28 percent more
than they care about poverty.

00:09:54.878 --> 00:09:56.934
Irreconcilable differences, right?

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
We'll never come together. Wrong.

00:09:59.478 --> 00:10:02.854
That is diversity
in which lies our strength.

00:10:02.878 --> 00:10:07.014
Remember what pulled up the poor.

00:10:07.038 --> 00:10:10.094
It was the obsession with poverty,

00:10:10.118 --> 00:10:14.334
accompanied by the method
of economic freedom

00:10:14.358 --> 00:10:15.974
spreading around the world.

00:10:15.998 --> 00:10:18.534
We need each other, in other words,

00:10:18.558 --> 00:10:22.178
if we want to help people and get the next
two billion people out of poverty.

00:10:22.202 --> 00:10:23.482
There's no other way.

00:10:24.518 --> 00:10:25.854
Hmm.

00:10:25.878 --> 00:10:27.358
How are we going to get that?

00:10:28.318 --> 00:10:29.974
It's a tricky thing, isn't it.

00:10:29.998 --> 00:10:32.214
We need innovative thinking.

00:10:32.238 --> 00:10:33.894
A lot of it's on this stage.

00:10:33.918 --> 00:10:37.078
Social entrepreneurship.
Yeah. Absolutely. Phenomenal.

00:10:38.238 --> 00:10:40.574
We need investment overseas

00:10:40.598 --> 00:10:44.974
in a sustainable, responsible,
ethical and moral way. Yes. Yes.

00:10:44.998 --> 00:10:46.814
But you know what we really need?

00:10:46.838 --> 00:10:51.454
We need a new day in flexible ideology.

00:10:51.478 --> 00:10:54.038
We need to be less predictable.

00:10:54.638 --> 00:10:55.854
Don't we?

00:10:55.878 --> 00:11:00.454
Do you ever feel like your own ideology
is starting to get predictable?

00:11:00.478 --> 00:11:02.214
Kinda conventional?

00:11:02.238 --> 00:11:06.374
Do you ever feel like you're always
listening to people who agree with you?

00:11:06.398 --> 00:11:08.134
Why is that dangerous?

00:11:08.158 --> 00:11:11.734
Because when we talk
in this country about economics,

00:11:11.758 --> 00:11:13.414
on the right, conservatives,

00:11:13.438 --> 00:11:18.078
you're always talking about taxes
and regulations and big government.

00:11:18.838 --> 00:11:21.574
And on the left, liberals,
you're talking about economics,

00:11:21.598 --> 00:11:23.854
it's always about income inequality.

00:11:23.878 --> 00:11:27.294
Right? Now those are important things,

00:11:27.318 --> 00:11:29.574
really important to me,
really important to you.

00:11:29.598 --> 00:11:32.134
But when it comes to lifting people up

00:11:32.158 --> 00:11:36.614
who are starving and need us today,
those are distractions.

00:11:36.638 --> 00:11:40.054
We need to come together
around the best ways

00:11:40.078 --> 00:11:43.414
to mitigate poverty
using the best tools at our disposal,

00:11:43.438 --> 00:11:47.934
and that comes only when conservatives
recognize that they need liberals

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.574
and their obsession with poverty,

00:11:49.598 --> 00:11:54.718
and liberals need conservatives
and their obsession with free markets.

00:11:55.198 --> 00:11:59.694
That's the diversity in which lies
the future strength of this country,

00:11:59.718 --> 00:12:01.678
if we choose to take it.

00:12:02.718 --> 00:12:05.774
So how are we going to do it?
How are we going to do it together?

00:12:05.798 --> 00:12:08.958
I've got to have some action items,
not just for you but for me.

00:12:09.358 --> 00:12:12.254
Number one. Action item number one:

00:12:12.278 --> 00:12:17.494
remember, it's not good enough
just to tolerate people who disagree.

00:12:17.518 --> 00:12:19.214
It's not good enough.

00:12:19.238 --> 00:12:23.134
We have to remember that we need
people who disagree with us,

00:12:23.158 --> 00:12:25.494
because there are people
who need all of us

00:12:25.518 --> 00:12:27.958
who are still waiting for these tools.

00:12:28.638 --> 00:12:31.934
Now, what are you going to do?
How are you going to express that?

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.894
Where does this start? It starts here.

00:12:33.918 --> 00:12:37.174
You know, all of us
in this room, we're blessed.

00:12:37.198 --> 00:12:39.254
We're blessed with people
who listen to us.

00:12:39.278 --> 00:12:42.174
We're blessed with prosperity.
We're blessed with leadership.

00:12:42.198 --> 00:12:46.598
When people hear us,
with the kind of unpredictable ideology,

00:12:47.158 --> 00:12:49.574
then maybe people will listen.

00:12:49.598 --> 00:12:51.774
Maybe progress will start at that point.

00:12:51.798 --> 00:12:53.558
That's number one. Number two.

00:12:54.118 --> 00:12:57.918
Number two: I'm asking you
and I'm asking me

00:12:58.638 --> 00:13:03.014
to be the person specifically
who blurs the lines,

00:13:03.038 --> 00:13:06.318
who is ambiguous, who is hard to classify.

00:13:07.118 --> 00:13:08.374
If you're a conservative,

00:13:08.398 --> 00:13:11.934
be the conservative
who is always going on about poverty

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:14.774
and the moral obligation
to be a warrior for the poor.

00:13:14.798 --> 00:13:18.494
And if you're a liberal,
be a liberal who is always talking

00:13:18.518 --> 00:13:23.094
about the beauty of free markets
to solve our problems

00:13:23.118 --> 00:13:24.718
when we use them responsibly.

00:13:25.278 --> 00:13:28.014
If we do that, we get two things.

00:13:28.038 --> 00:13:32.614
Number one: we get to start
to work on the next two billion

00:13:32.638 --> 00:13:36.174
and be the solution
that we've seen so much of in the past

00:13:36.198 --> 00:13:39.094
and we need to see more of in the future.
That's what we get.

00:13:39.118 --> 00:13:42.094
And the second is
that we might just be able

00:13:42.118 --> 00:13:46.774
to take the ghastly holy war of ideology
that we're suffering under in this country

00:13:46.798 --> 00:13:51.054
and turn it into a competition of ideas

00:13:51.078 --> 00:13:54.054
based on solidarity and mutual respect.

00:13:54.078 --> 00:13:57.934
And then maybe, just maybe,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:01.638
we'll all realize that our big differences

00:14:02.318 --> 00:14:04.438
aren't really that big after all.

title: A glimpse of the future through an augmented reality headset

And then he forces his eyeballs back up to mine and he goes, "Keep going. I'm with you." He was swiping through pictures on Instagram, and these kids were laughing hysterically. And that dichotomy between how crappy I was feeling and how happy they were feeling about the same technology, really got me thinking. And the more I thought of it, the more I realized it was clearly not the digital information that was the bad guy here, it was simply the display position that was separating me from my friend and that was binding those kids together.See, they were connected around something, just like our ancestors who evolved their social cognitions telling stories around the campfire. We should use machines that bring our work back into the world. Let's try it out. Now in front of me right now, I can see the audience, and I can see my very hands. And that's what I'm very passionate about.Now, I want to tell you a little secret. In about five years — this is not the smallest device — in about five years, these are all going to look like strips of glass on our eyes that project holograms. the way we collaborate.

Thanks, Ray.

The future of computers is not
locked inside one of these screens.

00:09:20.902 --> 00:09:23.669

(Applause)

leave you with here today,

00:09:32.818 --> 00:09:35.874
it's that the natural machine
is not some figment of the future,

00:09:35.898 --> 00:09:37.931
it's right here in 2016.

00:09:38.405 --> 00:09:41.180
Which is why all hundred of us at Meta,

00:09:41.204 --> 00:09:42.879
including the administrative staff,

00:09:42.903 --> 00:09:44.345
the executives,

00:09:44.369 --> 00:09:46.092
the designers, the engineers --

00:09:46.116 --> 00:09:48.018

00:09:48.042 --> 00:09:51.699

away our external monitors

00:09:51.723 --> 00:09:56.843

and profoundly more natural machine.

00:09:56.867 --> 00:09:58.058
Thank you very much.

me out on one thing,

augmented reality demos

a debate among technologists

about, are we really seeing
the real thing on-screen?

There's this issue of field of view,

that somehow the technology
is showing a broader view

wearing the glasses.

we took extra measures to shoot it
with a GoPro through the actual lens

in the various videos

the experience for the world

that we're actually seeing
through the glasses,

and not cut any corners.

title: A prosecutor's vision for a better justice system
transcript: The following are my opinions, and do not reflect the opinions or policies of any particular prosecutor's office.(Laughter)I am a prosecutor. I believe in law and order. I am the adopted son of a police officer, a Marine and a hairdresser. I believe in accountability and that we should all be safe in our communities. I love my job and the people that do it. I just think that it's our responsibility to do it better.By a show of hands, how many of you, by the age of 25, had either acted up in school, went somewhere you were specifically told to stay out of, or drank alcohol before your legal age?(Laughter)All right.How many of you shoplifted, tried an illegal drug or got into a physical fight — yes, even with a sibling? Now, how many of you ever spent one day in jail for any of those decisions? How many of you sitting here today think that you're a danger to society or should be defined by those actions of youthful indiscretion?(Laughter)Point taken.When we talk about criminal justice reform, we often focus on a few things, and that's what I want to talk to you about today. But first I'm going to — since you shared with me, I'm going to give you a confession on my part. I went to law school to make money. I had no interest in being a public servant, I had no interest in criminal law, and I definitely didn't think that I would ever be a prosecutor.Near the end of my first year of law school, I got an internship in the Roxbury Division of Boston Municipal Court. I knew of Roxbury as an impoverished neighborhood in Boston, plagued by gun violence and drug crime. My life and my legal career changed the first day of that internship. I walked into a courtroom, and I saw an auditorium of people who, one by one, would approach the front of that courtroom to say two words and two words only: "Not guilty." They were predominately black and brown. And then a judge, a defense attorney and a prosecutor would make life-altering decisions about that person without their input. They were predominately white. As each person, one by one, approached the front of that courtroom, I couldn't stop but think: How did they get here? I wanted to know their stories. And as the prosecutor read the facts of each case, I was thinking to myself, we could have predicted that. That seems so preventable... not because I was an expert in criminal law, but because it was common sense.Over the course of the internship, I began to recognize people in the auditorium, not because they were criminal masterminds but because they were coming to us for help and we were sending them out without any.My second year of law school I worked as a paralegal for a defense attorney, and in that experience I met many young men accused of murder. Even in our "worst," I saw human stories. And they all contained childhood trauma, victimization, poverty, loss, disengagement from school, early interaction with the police and the criminal justice system, all leading to a seat in a courtroom. Those convicted of murder were condemned to die in prison, and it was during those meetings with those men that I couldn't fathom why we would spend so much money to keep this one person in jail for the next 80 years when we could have reinvested it up front, and perhaps prevented the whole thing from happening in the first place.(Applause)My third year of law school, I defended people accused of small street crimes, mostly mentally ill, mostly homeless, mostly drug-addicted, all in need of help. They would come to us, and we would send them away without that help. They were in need of our assistance. But we weren't giving them any. Prosecuted, adjudged and defended by people who knew nothing about them.The staggering inefficiency is what drove me to criminal justice work. The unfairness of it all made me want to be a defender. The power dynamic that I came to understand made me become a prosecutor.I don't want to spend a lot of time talking about the problem. We know the criminal justice system needs reform, we know there are 2.3 million people in American jails and prisons, making us the most incarcerated nation on the planet. We know there's another seven million people on probation or parole, we know that the criminal justice system disproportionately affects people of color, particularly poor people of color. And we know there are system failures happening everywhere that bring people to our courtrooms. But what we do not discuss is how ill-equipped our prosecutors are to receive them. When we talk about criminal justice reform, we, as a society, focus on three things. We complain, we tweet, we protest about the police, about sentencing laws and about prison. We rarely, if ever, talk about the prosecutor.In the fall of 2009, a young man was arrested by the Boston Police Department. He was 18 years old, he was African American and he was a senior at a local public school. He had his sights set on college but his part-time, minimum-wage job wasn't providing the financial opportunity he needed to enroll in school. In a series of bad decisions, he stole 30 laptops from a store and sold them on the Internet. This led to his arrest and a criminal complaint of 30 felony charges. The potential jail time he faced is what stressed Christopher out the most. But what he had little understanding of was the impact a criminal record would have on his future.I was standing in arraignments that day when Christopher's case came across my desk. And at the risk of sounding dramatic, in that moment, I had Christopher's life in my hands. I was 29 years old, a brand-new prosecutor, and I had little appreciation for how the decisions I would make would impact Christopher's life. Christopher's case was a serious one and it needed to be dealt with as such, but I didn't think branding him a felon for the rest of his life was the right answer.For the most part, prosecutors step onto the job with little appreciation of the impact of our decisions, regardless of our intent. Despite our broad discretion, we learn to avoid risk at all cost, rendering our discretion basically useless. History has conditioned us to believe that somehow, the criminal justice system brings about accountability and improves public safety, despite evidence to the contrary. We're judged internally and externally by our convictions and our trial wins, so prosecutors aren't really incentivized to be creative at our case dispositions, or to take risks on people we might not otherwise. We stick to an outdated method, counterproductive to achieving the very goal that we all want, and that's safer communities.Yet most prosecutors standing in my space would have arraigned Christopher. They have little appreciation for what we can do. Arraigning Christopher would give him a criminal record, making it harder for him to get a job, setting in motion a cycle that defines the failing criminal justice system today. With a criminal record and without a job, Christopher would be unable to find employment, education or stable housing. Without those protective factors in his life, Christopher would be more likely to commit further, more serious crime. The more contact Christopher had with the criminal justice system, the more likely it would be that he would return again and again and again — all at tremendous social cost to his children, to his family and to his peers. And, ladies and gentlemen, it is a terrible public safety outcome for the rest of us.When I came out of law school, I did the same thing as everybody else. I came out as a prosecutor expected to do justice, but I never learned what justice was in my classes — none of us do. None of us do.And yet, prosecutors are the most powerful actors in the criminal justice system. Our power is virtually boundless. In most cases, not the judge, not the police, not the legislature, not the mayor, not the governor, not the President can tell us how to prosecute our cases. The decision to arraign Christopher and give him a criminal record was exclusively mine. I would choose whether to prosecute him for 30 felonies, for one felony, for a misdemeanor, or at all. I would choose whether to leverage Christopher into a plea deal or take the case to trial, and ultimately, I would be in a position to ask for Christopher to go to jail. These are decisions that prosecutors make every day unfettered, and we are unaware and untrained of the grave consequences of those decisions.One night this past summer, I was at a small gathering of professional men of color from around the city. As I stood there stuffing free finger sandwiches into my mouth, as you do as public servant —(Laughter)I noticed across the room, a young man waving and smiling at me and approaching me. And I recognized him, but I couldn't place from where, and before I knew it, this young man was hugging me. And thanking me. "You cared about me, and you changed my life." It was Christopher.See, I never arraigned Christopher. He never faced a judge or a jail, he never had a criminal record. Instead, I worked with Christopher; first on being accountable for his actions, and then, putting him in a position where he wouldn't re-offend. We recovered 75 percent of the computers that he sold and gave them back to Best Buy, and came up with a financial plan to repay for the computers we couldn't recover. Christopher did community service. He wrote an essay reflecting on how this case could impact his future and that of the community. He applied to college, he obtained financial aid, and he went on to graduate from a four-year school.(Applause)After we finished hugging, I looked at his name tag, to learn that Christopher was the manager of a large bank in Boston. Christopher had accomplished — and making a lot more money than me —(Laughter)He had accomplished all of this in the six years since I had first seen him in Roxbury Court. I can't take credit for Christopher's journey to success, but I certainly did my part to keep him on the path.There are thousands of Christophers out there, some locked in our jails and prisons. We need thousands of prosecutors to recognize that and to protect them. An employed Christopher is better for public safety than a condemned one. It's a bigger win for all of us. In retrospect, the decision not to throw the book at Christopher makes perfect sense. When I saw him that first day in Roxbury Court, I didn't see a criminal standing there. I saw myself — a young person in need of intervention. As an individual caught selling a large quantity of drugs in my late teens, I knew firsthand the power of opportunity as opposed to the wrath of the criminal justice system. Along the way, with the help and guidance of my district attorney, my supervisor and judges, I learned the power of the prosecutor to change lives instead of ruining them.And that's how we do it in Boston. We helped a woman who was arrested for stealing groceries to feed her kids get a job. Instead of putting an abused teenager in adult jail for punching another teenager, we secured mental health treatment and community supervision. A runaway girl who was arrested for prostituting, to survive on the streets, needed a safe place to live and grow — something we could help her with. I even helped a young man who was so afraid of the older gang kids showing up after school, that one morning instead of a lunchbox into his backpack, he put a loaded 9-millimeter. We would spend our time that we'd normally take prepping our cases for months and months for trial down the road by coming up with real solutions to the problems as they presented.Which is the better way to spend our time? How would you prefer your prosecutors to spend theirs? Why are we spending 80 billion dollars on a prison industry that we know is failing, when we could take that money and reallocate it into education, into mental health treatment, into substance abuse treatment and to community investment so we can develop our neighborhoods?(Applause)So why should this matter to you? Well, one, we're spending a lot of money. Our money. It costs 109,000 dollars in some states to lock up a teenager for a year, with a 60 percent chance that that person will return to the very same system. That is a terrible return on investment.Number two: it's the right thing to do. If prosecutors were a part of creating the problem, it's incumbent on us to create a solution and we can do that using other disciplines that have already done the data and research for us.And number three: your voice and your vote can make that happen. The next time there's a local district attorney's election in your jurisdiction, ask candidates these questions. One: What are you doing to make me and my neighbors safer? Two: What data are you collecting, and how are you training your prosecutors to make sure that it's working? And number three: If it's not working for everybody, what are you doing to fix it? If they can't answer the questions, they shouldn't be doing the job.Each one of you that raised your hand at the beginning of this talk is a living, breathing example of the power of opportunity, of intervention, of support and of love. While each of you may have faced your own brand of discipline for whatever malfeasances you committed, barely any of you needed a day in jail to make you the people that you are today — some of the greatest minds on the planet.Every day, thousands of times a day, prosecutors around the United States wield power so great that it can bring about catastrophe as quickly as it can bring about opportunity, intervention, support and yes, even love. Those qualities are the hallmarks of a strong community, and a strong community is a safe one. If our communities are broken, don't let the lawyers that you elect fix them with outdated, inefficient, expensive methods.Demand more; vote for the prosecutor who's helping people stay out of jail, not putting them in.Demand better. You deserve it, your children deserve it, the people who are tied up in the system deserve it, but most of all, the people that we are sworn to protect and do justice for demand it.We must, we must do better.Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)Thank you very much.
