00:04:58.318 --> 00:04:59.973
These give us color depth cues,

00:04:59.997 --> 00:05:02.092
but also tells which direction is up

00:05:02.116 --> 00:05:04.392
in shots where we don't
see the water surface.

00:05:04.746 --> 00:05:06.865
The other really cool thing
you can see here

00:05:06.889 --> 00:05:10.049
is that we lit that particulate
only with the caustics,

00:05:10.073 --> 00:05:12.731
so that as it goes in and out
of those ribbons of light,

00:05:12.755 --> 00:05:14.268
it appears and disappears,

00:05:14.292 --> 00:05:17.361
lending a subtle, magical
sparkle to the underwater.

00:05:18.488 --> 00:05:21.030
You can see how we're using the science --

00:05:21.054 --> 00:05:23.930
the physics of water,
light and movement --

00:05:23.954 --> 00:05:26.000
to tether that artistic freedom.

00:05:26.528 --> 00:05:28.849
But we are not beholden to it.

00:05:28.873 --> 00:05:30.672
We considered each of these elements

00:05:30.696 --> 00:05:33.710
and which ones had to be
scientifically accurate

00:05:33.734 --> 00:05:37.816
and which ones we could push and pull
to suit the story and the mood.

00:05:37.840 --> 00:05:41.649
We realized early on that color
was one we had some leeway with.

00:05:41.673 --> 00:05:44.285
So here's a traditionally colored
underwater scene.

00:05:44.309 --> 00:05:47.150
But here, we can take Sydney Harbor
and push it fairly green

00:05:47.174 --> 00:05:49.434
to suit the sad mood of what's happening.

00:05:50.273 --> 00:05:53.532
In this scene, it's really important
we see deep into the underwater,

00:05:53.556 --> 00:05:56.223
so we understand what
the East Australian Current is,

00:05:56.247 --> 00:05:59.635
that the turtles are diving into
and going on this roller coaster ride.

00:05:59.659 --> 00:06:01.596
So we pushed the visibility of the water

00:06:01.620 --> 00:06:04.323
well past anything you would
ever see in real life.

00:06:04.801 --> 00:06:05.963
Because in the end,

00:06:05.987 --> 00:06:10.611
we are not trying to recreate
the scientifically correct real world,

00:06:10.635 --> 00:06:12.675
we're trying to create a believable world,

00:06:12.699 --> 00:06:16.646
one the audience can immerse
themselves in to experience the story.

00:06:17.302 --> 00:06:20.025
We use science to create
something wonderful.

00:06:20.480 --> 00:06:24.776
We use story and artistic touch
to get us to a place of wonder.

00:06:25.536 --> 00:06:28.012
This guy, WALL-E, is a great
example of that.

00:06:28.036 --> 00:06:30.466
He finds beauty in the simplest things.

00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:33.579
But when he came in to lighting,
we knew we had a big problem.

00:06:33.936 --> 00:06:37.381
We got so geeked-out on making
WALL-E this convincing robot,

00:06:37.405 --> 00:06:40.785
that we made his binoculars
practically optically perfect.

00:06:40.809 --> 00:06:42.339
(Laughter)

00:06:43.286 --> 00:06:47.280
His binoculars are one of the most
critical acting devices he has.

00:06:47.304 --> 00:06:50.846
He doesn't have a face or even
traditional dialogue, for that matter.

00:06:50.870 --> 00:06:53.797
So the animators were heavily
dependent on the binoculars

00:06:53.821 --> 00:06:56.074
to sell his acting and emotions.

00:06:56.468 --> 00:06:58.177
We started lighting and we realized

00:06:58.201 --> 00:07:02.415
the triple lenses inside his binoculars
were a mess of reflections.

00:07:02.947 --> 00:07:05.000
He was starting to look glassy-eyed.

00:07:05.024 --> 00:07:06.748
(Laughter)

00:07:06.772 --> 00:07:10.186
Now, glassy-eyed
is a fundamentally awful thing

00:07:10.210 --> 00:07:12.226
when you are trying
to convince an audience

00:07:12.250 --> 00:07:15.733
that a robot has a personality
and he's capable of falling in love.

00:07:16.456 --> 00:07:19.980
So we went to work on these optically
perfect binoculars,

00:07:20.004 --> 00:07:23.706
trying to find a solution that would
maintain his true robot materials

00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:25.721
but solve this reflection problem.

00:07:26.054 --> 00:07:27.512
So we started with the lenses.

00:07:27.536 --> 00:07:28.928
Here's the flat-front lens,

00:07:28.952 --> 00:07:30.458
we have a concave lens

00:07:30.482 --> 00:07:31.739
and a convex lens.

00:07:31.763 --> 00:07:33.868
And here you see all three together,

00:07:33.892 --> 00:07:35.777
showing us all these reflections.

00:07:36.166 --> 00:07:37.796
We tried turning them down,

00:07:37.820 --> 00:07:39.516
we tried blocking them,

00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:40.980
nothing was working.

00:07:41.744 --> 00:07:42.895
You can see here,

00:07:42.919 --> 00:07:46.043
sometimes we needed something specific
reflected in his eyes --

00:07:46.067 --> 00:07:47.218
usually Eve.

00:07:47.242 --> 00:07:50.773
So we couldn't just use some faked
abstract image on the lenses.

00:07:50.797 --> 00:07:52.947
So here we have Eve on the first lens,

00:07:52.971 --> 00:07:55.022
we put Eve on the second lens,

00:07:55.046 --> 00:07:56.291
it's not working.

00:07:56.315 --> 00:07:57.475
We turn it down,

00:07:57.499 --> 00:07:59.175
it's still not working.

00:07:59.199 --> 00:08:01.529
And then we have our eureka moment.

00:08:01.553 --> 00:08:05.369
We add a light to WALL-E
that accidentally leaks into his eyes.

00:08:06.050 --> 00:08:09.440
You can see it light up
these gray aperture blades.

00:08:10.195 --> 00:08:13.518
Suddenly, those aperture blades
are poking through that reflection

00:08:13.542 --> 00:08:15.327
the way nothing else has.

00:08:15.924 --> 00:08:19.466
Now we recognize WALL-E as having an eye.

00:08:19.490 --> 00:08:22.139
As humans we have the white of our eye,

00:08:22.163 --> 00:08:23.314
the colored iris

00:08:23.338 --> 00:08:24.559
and the black pupil.

00:08:24.906 --> 00:08:28.247
Now WALL-E has the black of an eye,

00:08:28.271 --> 00:08:29.798
the gray aperture blades

00:08:29.822 --> 00:08:31.241
and the black pupil.

00:08:31.647 --> 00:08:35.289
Suddenly, WALL-E feels like he has a soul,

00:08:35.313 --> 00:08:38.191
like there's a character
with emotion inside.

00:08:39.996 --> 00:08:41.813
Later in the movie towards the end,

00:08:41.837 --> 00:08:43.315
WALL-E loses his personality,

00:08:43.339 --> 00:08:44.917
essentially going dead.

00:08:45.339 --> 00:08:48.868
This is the perfect time to bring back
that glassy-eyed look.

00:08:49.511 --> 00:08:51.991
In the next scene,
WALL-E comes back to life.

00:08:52.015 --> 00:08:55.198
We bring that light back to bring
the aperture blades back,

00:08:55.222 --> 00:08:58.682
and he returns to that sweet,
soulful robot we've come to love.

00:09:02.402 --> 00:09:03.766
(Video) WALL-E: Eva?

00:09:06.799 --> 00:09:09.919
Danielle Feinberg: There's a beauty
in these unexpected moments --

00:09:09.943 --> 00:09:13.509
when you find the key
to unlocking a robot's soul,

00:09:13.533 --> 00:09:16.696
the moment when you discover
what you want to do with your life.

00:09:17.093 --> 00:09:20.395
The jellyfish in "Finding Nemo"
was one of those moments for me.

00:09:20.791 --> 00:09:24.010
There are scenes in every movie
that struggle to come together.

00:09:24.034 --> 00:09:25.969
This was one of those scenes.

00:09:25.993 --> 00:09:28.127
The director had a vision for this scene

00:09:28.151 --> 00:09:31.959
based on some wonderful footage
of jellyfish in the South Pacific.

00:09:33.097 --> 00:09:34.954
As we went along,

00:09:34.978 --> 00:09:36.431
we were floundering.

00:09:36.455 --> 00:09:38.544
The reviews with the director

00:09:38.568 --> 00:09:41.257
turned from the normal
look-and-feel conversation

00:09:41.281 --> 00:09:45.408
into more and more questions
about numbers and percentages.

00:09:46.043 --> 00:09:47.734
Maybe because unlike normal,

00:09:47.758 --> 00:09:50.011
we were basing it on
something in real life,

00:09:50.035 --> 00:09:52.620
or maybe just because we had lost our way.

00:09:52.644 --> 00:09:55.755
But it had become about using
our brain without our eyes,

00:09:55.779 --> 00:09:57.634
the science without the art.

00:09:58.209 --> 00:10:01.388
That scientific tether
was strangling the scene.

00:10:02.492 --> 00:10:04.338
But even through all the frustrations,

00:10:04.362 --> 00:10:06.397
I still believed it could be beautiful.

00:10:06.421 --> 00:10:08.080
So when it came in to lighting,

00:10:08.104 --> 00:10:09.335
I dug in.

00:10:10.107 --> 00:10:13.398
As I worked to balance
the blues and the pinks,

00:10:13.422 --> 00:10:16.238
the caustics dancing
on the jellyfish bells,

00:10:16.262 --> 00:10:18.436
the undulating fog beams,

00:10:18.460 --> 00:10:20.882
something promising began to appear.

00:10:21.644 --> 00:10:24.871
I came in one morning and checked
the previous night's work.

00:10:24.895 --> 00:10:26.371
And I got excited.

00:10:26.395 --> 00:10:28.503
And then I showed it
to the lighting director

00:10:28.527 --> 00:10:29.702
and she got excited.

00:10:29.726 --> 00:10:34.142
Soon, I was showing to the director
in a dark room full of 50 people.

00:10:34.521 --> 00:10:35.784
In director review,

00:10:35.808 --> 00:10:37.866
you hope you might get some nice words,

00:10:38.307 --> 00:10:40.603
then you get some notes
and fixes, generally.

00:10:41.366 --> 00:10:43.803
And then, hopefully, you get a final,

00:10:43.827 --> 00:10:45.875
signaling to move on to the next stage.

00:10:46.420 --> 00:10:49.788
I gave my intro, and I played
the jellyfish scene.

00:10:50.661 --> 00:10:54.513
And the director was silent
for an uncomfortably long amount of time.

00:10:55.198 --> 00:10:57.705
Just long enough for me to think,

00:10:57.729 --> 00:10:59.585
"Oh no, this is doomed."

00:11:00.877 --> 00:11:02.637
And then he started clapping.

00:11:03.339 --> 00:11:05.731
And then the production
designer started clapping.

00:11:06.198 --> 00:11:08.342
And then the whole room was clapping.

00:11:14.243 --> 00:11:17.329
This is the moment
that I live for in lighting.

00:11:17.353 --> 00:11:19.516
The moment where it all comes together

00:11:19.540 --> 00:11:22.187
and we get a world that we can believe in.

00:11:22.676 --> 00:11:26.564
We use math, science and code
to create these amazing worlds.

00:11:26.988 --> 00:11:29.834
We use storytelling and art
to bring them to life.

00:11:30.398 --> 00:11:34.409
It's this interweaving of art and science

00:11:34.433 --> 00:11:38.096
that elevates the world
to a place of wonder,

00:11:38.120 --> 00:11:39.753
a place with soul,

00:11:39.777 --> 00:11:41.547
a place we can believe in,

00:11:42.220 --> 00:11:45.561
a place where the things
you imagine can become real --

00:11:47.029 --> 00:11:50.241
and a world where a girl suddenly realizes

00:11:50.265 --> 00:11:52.425
not only is she a scientist,

00:11:52.449 --> 00:11:53.764
but also an artist.

00:11:54.502 --> 00:11:55.653
Thank you.

00:11:55.677 --> 00:11:58.957
(Applause)

title: The most mysterious star in the universe
transcript: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, and it is my job, my responsibility, as an astronomer to remind people that alien hypotheses should always be a last resort.Now, I want to tell you a story about that. It involves data from a NASA mission, ordinary people and one of the most extraordinary stars in our galaxy.It began in 2009 with the launch of NASA's Kepler mission. Kepler's main scientific objective was to find planets outside of our solar system. It did this by staring at a single field in the sky, this one, with all the tiny boxes. And in this one field, it monitored the brightness of over 150,000 stars continuously for four years, taking a data point every 30 minutes. It was looking for what astronomers call a transit. This is when the planet's orbit is aligned in our line of sight, just so that the planet crosses in front of a star. And when this happens, it blocks out a tiny bit of starlight, which you can see as a dip in this curve.And so the team at NASA had developed very sophisticated computers to search for transits in all the Kepler data.At the same time of the first data release, astronomers at Yale were wondering an interesting thing: What if computers missed something?And so we launched the citizen science project called Planet Hunters to have people look at the same data. The human brain has an amazing ability for pattern recognition, sometimes even better than a computer. However, there was a lot of skepticism around this. My colleague, Debra Fischer, founder of the Planet Hunters project, said that people at the time were saying, "You're crazy. There's no way that a computer will miss a signal." And so it was on, the classic human versus machine gamble. And if we found one planet, we would be thrilled. When I joined the team four years ago, we had already found a couple. And today, with the help of over 300,000 science enthusiasts, we have found dozens, and we've also found one of the most mysterious stars in our galaxy.So to understand this, let me show you what a normal transit in Kepler data looks like. On this graph on the left-hand side you have the amount of light, and on the bottom is time. The white line is light just from the star, what astronomers call a light curve. Now, when a planet transits a star, it blocks out a little bit of this light, and the depth of this transit reflects the size of the object itself. And so, for example, let's take Jupiter. Planets don't get much bigger than Jupiter. Jupiter will make a one percent drop in a star's brightness. Earth, on the other hand, is 11 times smaller than Jupiter, and the signal is barely visible in the data.So back to our mystery. A few years ago, Planet Hunters were sifting through data looking for transits, and they spotted a mysterious signal coming from the star KIC 8462852. The observations in May of 2009 were the first they spotted, and they started talking about this in the discussion forums.They said and object like Jupiter would make a drop like this in the star's light, but they were also saying it was giant. You see, transits normally only last for a few hours, and this one lasted for almost a week.They were also saying that it looks asymmetric, meaning that instead of the clean, U-shaped dip that we saw with Jupiter, it had this strange slope that you can see on the left side. This seemed to indicate that whatever was getting in the way and blocking the starlight was not circular like a planet. There are few more dips that happened, but for a couple of years, it was pretty quiet.And then in March of 2011, we see this. The star's light drops by a whole 15 percent, and this is huge compared to a planet, which would only make a one percent drop. We described this feature as both smooth and clean. It also is asymmetric, having a gradual dimming that lasts almost a week, and then it snaps right back up to normal in just a matter of days.And again, after this, not much happens until February of 2013. Things start to get really crazy. There is a huge complex of dips in the light curve that appear, and they last for like a hundred days, all the way up into the Kepler mission's end. These dips have variable shapes. Some are very sharp, and some are broad, and they also have variable durations. Some last just for a day or two, and some for more than a week. And there's also up and down trends within some of these dips, almost like several independent events were superimposed on top of each other. And at this time, this star drops in its brightness over 20 percent. This means that whatever is blocking its light has an area of over 1,000 times the area of our planet Earth.This is truly remarkable. And so the citizen scientists, when they saw this, they notified the science team that they found something weird enough that it might be worth following up. And so when the science team looked at it, we're like, "Yeah, there's probably just something wrong with the data." But we looked really, really, really hard, and the data were good. And so what was happening had to be astrophysical, meaning that something in space was getting in the way and blocking starlight. And so at this point, we set out to learn everything we could about the star to see if we could find any clues to what was going on. And the citizen scientists who helped us in this discovery, they joined along for the ride watching science in action firsthand.First, somebody said, you know, what if this star was very young and it still had the cloud of material it was born from surrounding it. And then somebody else said, well, what if the star had already formed planets, and two of these planets had collided, similar to the Earth-Moon forming event. Well, both of these theories could explain part of the data, but the difficulties were that the star showed no signs of being young, and there was no glow from any of the material that was heated up by the star's light, and you would expect this if the star was young or if there was a collision and a lot of dust was produced. And so somebody else said, well, how about a huge swarm of comets that are passing by this star in a very elliptical orbit? Well, it ends up that this is actually consistent with our observations. But I agree, it does feel a little contrived. You see, it would take hundreds of comets to reproduce what we're observing. And these are only the comets that happen to pass between us and the star. And so in reality, we're talking thousands to tens of thousands of comets. But of all the bad ideas we had, this one was the best. And so we went ahead and published our findings.Now, let me tell you, this was one of the hardest papers I ever wrote. Scientists are meant to publish results, and this situation was far from that. And so we decided to give it a catchy title, and we called it: "Where's The Flux?" I will let you work out the acronym.(Laughter)So this isn't the end of the story. Around the same time I was writing this paper, I met with a colleague of mine, Jason Wright, and he was also writing a paper on Kepler data. And he was saying that with Kepler's extreme precision, it could actually detect alien megastructures around stars, but it didn't. And then I showed him this weird data that our citizen scientists had found, and he said to me, "Aw crap, Tabby. Now I have to rewrite my paper."So yes, the natural explanations were weak, and we were curious now. So we had to find a way to rule out aliens. So together, we convinced a colleague of ours who works on SETI, the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence, that this would be an extraordinary target to pursue. We wrote a proposal to observe the star with the world's largest radio telescope at the Green Bank Observatory.A couple months later, news of this proposal got leaked to the press and now there are thousands of articles, over 10,000 articles, on this star alone. And if you search Google Images, this is what you'll find.Now, you may be wondering, OK, Tabby, well, how do aliens actually explain this light curve? OK, well, imagine a civilization that's much more advanced than our own. In this hypothetical circumstance, this civilization would have exhausted the energy supply of their home planet, so where could they get more energy? Well, they have a host star just like we have a sun, and so if they were able to capture more energy from this star, then that would solve their energy needs. So they would go and build huge structures. These giant megastructures, like ginormous solar panels, are called Dyson spheres.This image above are lots of artists' impressions of Dyson spheres. It's really hard to provide perspective on the vastness of these things, but you can think of it this way. The Earth-Moon distance is a quarter of a million miles. The simplest element on one of these structures is 100 times that size. They're enormous. And now imagine one of these structures in motion around a star. You can see how it would produce anomalies in the data such as uneven, unnatural looking dips.But it remains that even alien megastructures cannot defy the laws of physics. You see, anything that uses a lot of energy is going to produce heat, and we don't observe this. But it could be something as simple as they're just reradiating it away in another direction, just not at Earth.Another idea that's one of my personal favorites is that we had just witnessed an interplanetary space battle and the catastrophic destruction of a planet. Now, I admit that this would produce a lot of dust that we don't observe. But if we're already invoking aliens in this explanation, then who is to say they didn't efficiently clean up all this mess for recycling purposes?(Laughter)You can see how this quickly captures your imagination.Well, there you have it. We're in a situation that could unfold to be a natural phenomenon we don't understand or an alien technology we don't understand. Personally, as a scientist, my money is on the natural explanation. But don't get me wrong, I do think it would be awesome to find aliens. Either way, there is something new and really interesting to discover.So what happens next? We need to continue to observe this star to learn more about what's happening. But professional astronomers, like me, we have limited resources for this kind of thing, and Kepler is on to a different mission.And I'm happy to say that once again, citizen scientists have come in and saved the day. You see, this time, amateur astronomers with their backyard telescopes stepped up immediately and started observing this star nightly at their own facilities, and I am so excited to see what they find.What's amazing to me is that this star would have never been found by computers because we just weren't looking for something like this. And what's more exciting is that there's more data to come. There are new missions that are coming up that are observing millions more stars all over the sky.And just think: What will it mean when we find another star like this? And what will it mean if we don't find another star like this?Thank you.(Applause)

When I joined the team four years ago,

00:02:29.438 --> 00:02:30.878
we had already found a couple.

00:02:32.318 --> 00:02:36.974
And today, with the help
of over 300,000 science enthusiasts,

00:02:36.998 --> 00:02:38.774
we have found dozens,

00:02:38.798 --> 00:02:42.054
and we've also found
one of the most mysterious stars

00:02:42.078 --> 00:02:43.278
in our galaxy.

00:02:44.998 --> 00:02:46.454
So to understand this,

00:02:46.478 --> 00:02:49.678
let me show you what a normal transit
in Kepler data looks like.

00:02:50.638 --> 00:02:54.014
On this graph on the left-hand side
you have the amount of light,

00:02:54.038 --> 00:02:55.894
and on the bottom is time.

00:02:55.918 --> 00:02:58.974
The white line
is light just from the star,

00:02:58.998 --> 00:03:01.374
what astronomers call a light curve.

00:03:01.398 --> 00:03:05.254
Now, when a planet transits a star,
it blocks out a little bit of this light,

00:03:05.278 --> 00:03:10.734
and the depth of this transit
reflects the size of the object itself.

00:03:10.758 --> 00:03:13.374
And so, for example, let's take Jupiter.

00:03:13.398 --> 00:03:15.534
Planets don't get
much bigger than Jupiter.

00:03:15.558 --> 00:03:19.334
Jupiter will make a one percent drop
in a star's brightness.

00:03:19.358 --> 00:03:23.534
Earth, on the other hand,
is 11 times smaller than Jupiter,

00:03:23.558 --> 00:03:26.374
and the signal
is barely visible in the data.

00:03:26.398 --> 00:03:27.678
So back to our mystery.

00:03:28.478 --> 00:03:32.358
A few years ago, Planet Hunters were
sifting through data looking for transits,

00:03:33.158 --> 00:03:39.118
and they spotted a mysterious signal
coming from the star KIC 8462852.

00:03:39.878 --> 00:03:43.894
The observations in May of 2009
were the first they spotted,

00:03:43.918 --> 00:03:46.776
and they started talking about this
in the discussion forums.

00:03:47.278 --> 00:03:49.374
They said and object like Jupiter

00:03:49.398 --> 00:03:52.294
would make a drop like this
in the star's light,

00:03:52.318 --> 00:03:55.654
but they were also saying it was giant.

00:03:55.678 --> 00:03:58.894
You see, transits normally
only last for a few hours,

00:03:58.918 --> 00:04:01.038
and this one lasted for almost a week.

00:04:01.838 --> 00:04:05.374
They were also saying
that it looks asymmetric,

00:04:05.398 --> 00:04:09.654
meaning that instead of the clean,
U-shaped dip that we saw with Jupiter,

00:04:09.678 --> 00:04:13.174
it had this strange slope
that you can see on the left side.

00:04:13.198 --> 00:04:14.534
This seemed to indicate

00:04:14.558 --> 00:04:17.934
that whatever was getting in the way
and blocking the starlight

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.878
was not circular like a planet.

00:04:21.198 --> 00:04:23.094
There are few more dips that happened,

00:04:23.118 --> 00:04:25.478
but for a couple of years,
it was pretty quiet.

00:04:26.358 --> 00:04:30.518
And then in March of 2011, we see this.

00:04:31.078 --> 00:04:35.174
The star's light drops
by a whole 15 percent,

00:04:35.198 --> 00:04:37.374
and this is huge compared to a planet,

00:04:37.398 --> 00:04:39.398
which would only make a one percent drop.

00:04:40.438 --> 00:04:43.974
We described this feature
as both smooth and clean.

00:04:43.998 --> 00:04:46.014
It also is asymmetric,

00:04:46.038 --> 00:04:48.694
having a gradual dimming
that lasts almost a week,

00:04:48.718 --> 00:04:51.878
and then it snaps right back up to normal
in just a matter of days.

00:04:52.878 --> 00:04:57.134
And again, after this, not much happens

00:04:57.158 --> 00:05:00.854
until February of 2013.

00:05:00.878 --> 00:05:03.494
Things start to get really crazy.

00:05:03.518 --> 00:05:08.014
There is a huge complex of dips
in the light curve that appear,

00:05:08.038 --> 00:05:10.174
and they last for like a hundred days,

00:05:10.198 --> 00:05:12.438
all the way up
into the Kepler mission's end.

00:05:13.238 --> 00:05:15.214
These dips have variable shapes.

00:05:15.238 --> 00:05:17.454
Some are very sharp, and some are broad,

00:05:17.478 --> 00:05:19.734
and they also have variable durations.

00:05:19.758 --> 00:05:22.918
Some last just for a day or two,
and some for more than a week.

00:05:24.078 --> 00:05:27.414
And there's also up and down trends
within some of these dips,

00:05:27.438 --> 00:05:32.118
almost like several independent events
were superimposed on top of each other.

00:05:32.878 --> 00:05:39.094
And at this time, this star drops
in its brightness over 20 percent.

00:05:39.118 --> 00:05:41.261
This means that whatever
is blocking its light

00:05:41.285 --> 00:05:45.725
has an area of over 1,000 times
the area of our planet Earth.

00:05:46.158 --> 00:05:48.398
This is truly remarkable.

00:05:49.318 --> 00:05:51.694
And so the citizen scientists,
when they saw this,

00:05:51.718 --> 00:05:55.414
they notified the science team
that they found something weird enough

00:05:55.438 --> 00:05:57.878
that it might be worth following up.

00:05:58.638 --> 00:06:00.694
And so when the science team looked at it,

00:06:00.718 --> 00:06:04.099
we're like, "Yeah, there's probably
just something wrong with the data."

00:06:04.123 --> 00:06:06.654
But we looked really, really, really hard,

00:06:06.678 --> 00:06:09.078
and the data were good.

00:06:10.638 --> 00:06:13.734
And so what was happening
had to be astrophysical,

00:06:13.758 --> 00:06:17.414
meaning that something in space
was getting in the way

00:06:17.438 --> 00:06:18.838
and blocking starlight.

00:06:20.198 --> 00:06:21.414
And so at this point,

00:06:21.438 --> 00:06:24.014
we set out to learn
everything we could about the star

00:06:24.038 --> 00:06:26.958
to see if we could find any clues
to what was going on.

00:06:27.678 --> 00:06:30.854
And the citizen scientists
who helped us in this discovery,

00:06:30.878 --> 00:06:32.414
they joined along for the ride

00:06:32.438 --> 00:06:35.518
watching science in action firsthand.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:42.414
First, somebody said, you know,
what if this star was very young

00:06:42.438 --> 00:06:46.038
and it still had the cloud of material
it was born from surrounding it.

00:06:46.998 --> 00:06:48.414
And then somebody else said,

00:06:48.438 --> 00:06:51.214
well, what if the star
had already formed planets,

00:06:51.238 --> 00:06:53.454
and two of these planets had collided,

00:06:53.478 --> 00:06:55.598
similar to the Earth-Moon forming event.

00:06:56.398 --> 00:06:59.934
Well, both of these theories
could explain part of the data,

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:03.374
but the difficulties were that the star
showed no signs of being young,

00:07:03.398 --> 00:07:06.334
and there was no glow
from any of the material

00:07:06.358 --> 00:07:08.454
that was heated up by the star's light,

00:07:08.478 --> 00:07:11.334
and you would expect this
if the star was young

00:07:11.358 --> 00:07:14.918
or if there was a collision
and a lot of dust was produced.

00:07:15.758 --> 00:07:17.374
And so somebody else said,

00:07:17.398 --> 00:07:22.374
well, how about a huge swarm of comets

00:07:22.398 --> 00:07:26.054
that are passing by this star
in a very elliptical orbit?

00:07:26.078 --> 00:07:30.478
Well, it ends up that this is actually
consistent with our observations.

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:35.214
But I agree, it does feel
a little contrived.

00:07:35.238 --> 00:07:38.534
You see, it would take hundreds of comets

00:07:38.558 --> 00:07:40.198
to reproduce what we're observing.

00:07:41.158 --> 00:07:42.734
And these are only the comets

00:07:42.758 --> 00:07:45.374
that happen to pass
between us and the star.

00:07:45.398 --> 00:07:51.854
And so in reality, we're talking
thousands to tens of thousands of comets.

00:07:51.878 --> 00:07:55.334
But of all the bad ideas we had,

00:07:55.358 --> 00:07:57.494
this one was the best.

00:07:57.518 --> 00:08:00.454
And so we went ahead
and published our findings.

00:08:00.478 --> 00:08:04.694
Now, let me tell you, this was one
of the hardest papers I ever wrote.

00:08:04.718 --> 00:08:07.054
Scientists are meant to publish results,

00:08:07.078 --> 00:08:09.238
and this situation was far from that.

00:08:09.918 --> 00:08:13.054
And so we decided
to give it a catchy title,

00:08:13.078 --> 00:08:15.254
and we called it: "Where's The Flux?"

00:08:15.278 --> 00:08:17.358
I will let you work out the acronym.

00:08:18.118 --> 00:08:21.838
(Laughter)

00:08:22.798 --> 00:08:24.494
So this isn't the end of the story.

00:08:24.518 --> 00:08:26.694
Around the same time
I was writing this paper,

00:08:26.718 --> 00:08:28.854
I met with a colleague
of mine, Jason Wright,

00:08:28.878 --> 00:08:31.094
and he was also writing a paper
on Kepler data.

00:08:31.118 --> 00:08:35.294
And he was saying that with Kepler's
extreme precision,

00:08:35.318 --> 00:08:40.174
it could actually detect
alien megastructures around stars,

00:08:40.198 --> 00:08:41.398
but it didn't.

00:08:42.478 --> 00:08:46.438
And then I showed him this weird data
that our citizen scientists had found,

00:08:47.517 --> 00:08:48.733
and he said to me,

00:08:48.757 --> 00:08:50.534
"Aw crap, Tabby.

00:08:50.558 --> 00:08:52.517
Now I have to rewrite my paper."

00:08:54.398 --> 00:08:56.598
So yes, the natural
explanations were weak,

00:08:58.438 --> 00:09:00.014
and we were curious now.

00:09:00.038 --> 00:09:03.214
So we had to find a way
to rule out aliens.

00:09:03.238 --> 00:09:06.094
So together, we convinced
a colleague of ours

00:09:06.118 --> 00:09:09.374
who works on SETI, the Search
for Extraterrestrial Intelligence,

00:09:09.398 --> 00:09:12.318
that this would be
an extraordinary target to pursue.

00:09:14.438 --> 00:09:16.814
We wrote a proposal to observe the star

00:09:16.838 --> 00:09:21.014
with the world's largest radio telescope
at the Green Bank Observatory.

00:09:21.038 --> 00:09:22.414
A couple months later,

00:09:22.438 --> 00:09:26.678
news of this proposal
got leaked to the press

00:09:27.718 --> 00:09:31.174
and now there are thousands of articles,

00:09:31.198 --> 00:09:34.334
over 10,000 articles, on this star alone.

00:09:34.358 --> 00:09:36.198
And if you search Google Images,

00:09:36.878 --> 00:09:38.078
this is what you'll find.

00:09:39.558 --> 00:09:42.054
Now, you may be wondering,
OK, Tabby, well,

00:09:42.078 --> 00:09:45.934
how do aliens actually explain
this light curve?

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:51.254
OK, well, imagine a civilization
that's much more advanced than our own.

00:09:51.278 --> 00:09:53.598
In this hypothetical circumstance,

00:09:54.638 --> 00:09:59.294
this civilization would have exhausted
the energy supply of their home planet,

00:09:59.318 --> 00:10:01.494
so where could they get more energy?

00:10:01.518 --> 00:10:04.318
Well, they have a host star
just like we have a sun,

00:10:05.198 --> 00:10:09.254
and so if they were able
to capture more energy from this star,

00:10:09.278 --> 00:10:11.238
then that would solve their energy needs.

00:10:11.758 --> 00:10:15.174
So they would go
and build huge structures.

00:10:15.198 --> 00:10:17.974
These giant megastructures,

00:10:17.998 --> 00:10:21.718
like ginormous solar panels,
are called Dyson spheres.

00:10:22.398 --> 00:10:23.694
This image above

00:10:23.718 --> 00:10:26.894
are lots of artists' impressions
of Dyson spheres.

00:10:26.918 --> 00:10:31.934
It's really hard to provide perspective
on the vastness of these things,

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.774
but you can think of it this way.

00:10:33.798 --> 00:10:36.838
The Earth-Moon distance
is a quarter of a million miles.

00:10:37.998 --> 00:10:41.894
The simplest element
on one of these structures

00:10:41.918 --> 00:10:44.358
is 100 times that size.

00:10:45.358 --> 00:10:46.678
They're enormous.

00:10:48.038 --> 00:10:52.454
And now imagine one of these structures
in motion around a star.

00:10:52.478 --> 00:10:55.574
You can see how it would produce
anomalies in the data

00:10:55.598 --> 00:10:58.814
such as uneven, unnatural looking dips.

00:10:58.838 --> 00:11:02.814
But it remains that even
alien megastructures

00:11:02.838 --> 00:11:05.254
cannot defy the laws of physics.

00:11:05.278 --> 00:11:08.718
You see, anything that uses
a lot of energy

00:11:09.758 --> 00:11:11.518
is going to produce heat,

00:11:12.798 --> 00:11:14.774
and we don't observe this.

00:11:14.798 --> 00:11:16.494
But it could be something as simple

00:11:16.518 --> 00:11:19.974
as they're just reradiating it away
in another direction,

00:11:19.998 --> 00:11:21.198
just not at Earth.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.398
Another idea that's one
of my personal favorites

00:11:26.278 --> 00:11:30.054
is that we had just witnessed
an interplanetary space battle

00:11:30.078 --> 00:11:33.078
and the catastrophic
destruction of a planet.

00:11:34.478 --> 00:11:37.734
Now, I admit that this
would produce a lot of dust

00:11:37.758 --> 00:11:39.654
that we don't observe.

00:11:39.678 --> 00:11:44.014
But if we're already invoking aliens
in this explanation,

00:11:44.038 --> 00:11:47.734
then who is to say they didn't
efficiently clean up all this mess

00:11:47.758 --> 00:11:49.294
for recycling purposes?

00:11:49.318 --> 00:11:50.334
(Laughter)

00:11:50.358 --> 00:11:53.318
You can see how this quickly
captures your imagination.

00:11:55.718 --> 00:11:56.974
Well, there you have it.

00:11:56.998 --> 00:12:00.214
We're in a situation that could unfold

00:12:00.238 --> 00:12:03.654
to be a natural phenomenon
we don't understand

00:12:03.678 --> 00:12:06.238
or an alien technology
we don't understand.

00:12:07.558 --> 00:12:12.798
Personally, as a scientist,
my money is on the natural explanation.

00:12:13.998 --> 00:12:17.318
But don't get me wrong, I do think
it would be awesome to find aliens.

00:12:18.758 --> 00:12:23.278
Either way, there is something new
and really interesting to discover.

00:12:23.998 --> 00:12:25.854
So what happens next?

00:12:25.878 --> 00:12:28.534
We need to continue to observe this star

00:12:28.558 --> 00:12:30.974
to learn more about what's happening.

00:12:30.998 --> 00:12:33.574
But professional astronomers, like me,

00:12:33.598 --> 00:12:36.414
we have limited resources
for this kind of thing,

00:12:36.438 --> 00:12:38.358
and Kepler is on to a different mission.

00:12:39.358 --> 00:12:43.574
And I'm happy to say that once again,

00:12:43.598 --> 00:12:46.718
citizen scientists have come in
and saved the day.

00:12:47.838 --> 00:12:50.294
You see, this time,

00:12:50.318 --> 00:12:53.198
amateur astronomers
with their backyard telescopes

00:12:54.078 --> 00:12:58.054
stepped up immediately
and started observing this star nightly

00:12:58.078 --> 00:12:59.574
at their own facilities,

00:12:59.598 --> 00:13:02.398
and I am so excited to see what they find.

00:13:03.478 --> 00:13:07.654
What's amazing to me is that this star
would have never been found by computers

00:13:07.678 --> 00:13:10.318
because we just weren't looking
for something like this.

00:13:11.358 --> 00:13:15.614
And what's more exciting

00:13:15.638 --> 00:13:17.278
is that there's more data to come.

00:13:18.158 --> 00:13:20.134
There are new missions that are coming up

00:13:20.158 --> 00:13:22.838
that are observing millions more stars

00:13:23.798 --> 00:13:25.198
all over the sky.

00:13:26.238 --> 00:13:31.758
And just think: What will it mean
when we find another star like this?

00:13:32.478 --> 00:13:36.558
And what will it mean
if we don't find another star like this?

00:13:37.238 --> 00:13:38.454
Thank you.

00:13:38.478 --> 00:13:45.399
(Applause)

title: The Panama Papers exposed a huge global problem. What's next?
transcript: [On April 3, 2016 we saw the largest data leak in history.] [The Panama Papers exposed rich and powerful people] [hiding vast amounts of money in offshore accounts.] [What does this mean?] [We called Robert Palmer of Global Witness to explain.]This week, there have been a whole slew and deluge of stories coming out from the leak of 11 million documents from a Panamanian-based law firm called Mossack Fonseca. The release of these papers from Panama lifts the veil on a tiny piece of the secretive offshore world. We get an insight into how clients and banks and lawyers go to companies like Mossack Fonseca and say, "OK, we want an anonymous company, can you give us one?" So you actually get to see the emails, you get to see the exchanges of messages, you get to see the mechanics of how this works, how this operates.Now, this has already started to have pretty immediate repercussions. The Prime Minister of Iceland has resigned. We've also had news that an ally of the brutal Syrian dictator Bashar Al-Assad has also got offshore companies. There's been allegations of a $2 billion money trail that leads back to President Vladimir Putin of Russia via his close childhood friend, who happens to be a top cellist. And there will be a lot of rich individuals out there and others who will be nervous about the next set of stories and the next set of leaked documents.Now, this sounds like the plot of a spy thriller or a John Grisham novel. It seems very distant from you, me, ordinary people. Why should we care about this? But the truth is that if rich and powerful individuals are able to keep their money offshore and not pay the taxes that they should, it means that there is less money for vital public services like healthcare, education, roads. And that affects all of us.Now, for my organization Global Witness, this exposé has been phenomenal. We have the world's media and political leaders talking about how individuals can use offshore secrecy to hide and disguise their assets — something we have been talking about and exposing for a decade.Now, I think a lot of people find this entire world baffling and confusing, and hard to understand how this sort of offshore world works. I like to think of it a bit like a Russian doll. So you can have one company stacked inside another company, stacked inside another company, making it almost impossible to really understand who is behind these structures. It can be very difficult for law enforcement or tax authorities, journalists, civil society to really understand what's going on.I also think it's interesting that there's been less coverage of this issue in the United States. And that's perhaps because some prominent US people just haven't figured in this exposé, in this scandal. Now, that's not because there are no rich Americans who are stashing their assets offshore. It's just because of the way in which offshore works, Mossack Fonseca has fewer American clients. I think if we saw leaks from the Cayman Islands or even from Delaware or Wyoming or Nevada, you would see many more cases and examples linking back to Americans.In fact, in a number of US states you need less information, you need to provide less information to get a company than you do to get a library card. That sort of secrecy in America has allowed employees of school districts to rip off schoolchildren. It has allowed scammers to rip off vulnerable investors. This is the sort of behavior that affects all of us.Now, at Global Witness, we wanted to see what this actually looked like in practice. How does this actually work? So what we did is we sent in an undercover investigator to 13 Manhattan law firms. Our investigator posed as an African minister who wanted to move suspect funds into the United States to buy a house, a yacht, a jet. Now, what was truly shocking was that all but one of those lawyers provided our investigator with suggestions on how to move those suspect funds. These were all preliminary meetings, and none of the lawyers took us on as a client and of course no money moved hands, but it really shows the problem with the system.It's also important to not just think about this as individual cases. This is not just about an individual lawyer who's spoken to our undercover investigator and provided suggestions. It's not just about a particular senior politician who's been caught up in a scandal. This is about how a system works, that entrenches corruption, tax evasion, poverty and instability. And in order to tackle this, we need to change the game. We need to change the rules of the game to make this sort of behavior harder.This may seem like doom and gloom, like there's nothing we can do about it, like nothing has ever changed, like there will always be rich and powerful individuals. But as a natural optimist, I do see that we are starting to get some change.Over the last couple of years, we've seen a real push towards greater transparency when it comes to company ownership. This issue was put on the political agenda by the UK Prime Minister David Cameron at a big G8 Summit that was held in Northern Ireland in 2013. And since then, the European Union is going to be creating central registers at a national level of who really owns and controls companies across Europe.One of the things that is sad is that, actually, the US is lagging behind. There's bipartisan legislation that had been introduced in the House and the Senate, but it isn't making as much progress as we'd like to see. So we'd really want to see the Panama leaks, this huge peek into the offshore world, be used as a way of opening up in the US and around the world.For us at Global Witness, this is a moment for change. We need ordinary people to get angry at the way in which people can hide their identity behind secret companies. We need business leaders to stand up and say, "Secrecy like this is not good for business." We need political leaders to recognize the problem, and to commit to changing the law to open up this sort of secrecy.Together, we can end the secrecy that is currently allowing tax evasion, corruption, money laundering to flourish.

00:00:58.954 --> 00:01:00.982

how this operates.

00:01:13.298 --> 00:01:17.351
Now, this has already started
to have pretty immediate repercussions.

00:01:17.375 --> 00:01:19.976
The Prime Minister
of Iceland has resigned.

00:01:20.000 --> 00:01:21.215
We've also had news

00:01:21.239 --> 00:01:26.282
that an ally of the brutal
Syrian dictator Bashar Al-Assad

00:01:26.306 --> 00:01:28.861
has also got offshore companies.

00:01:28.885 --> 00:01:34.114
There's been allegations
of a $2 billion money trail

00:01:34.138 --> 00:01:38.041
that leads back to President
Vladimir Putin of Russia

00:01:38.065 --> 00:01:40.526
via his close childhood friend,

00:01:40.550 --> 00:01:42.778
who happens to be a top cellist.

00:01:42.802 --> 00:01:45.402
And there will be a lot
of rich individuals out there

00:01:45.426 --> 00:01:49.744
and others who will be nervous
about the next set of stories

00:01:49.768 --> 00:01:52.321
and the next set of leaked documents.

00:01:52.345 --> 00:01:56.531
Now, this sounds like the plot
of a spy thriller

00:01:56.555 --> 00:01:58.218
or a John Grisham novel.

00:01:58.242 --> 00:02:02.258
It seems very distant
from you, me, ordinary people.

00:02:02.282 --> 00:02:04.790
Why should we care about this?

00:02:04.814 --> 00:02:09.057
But the truth is that if rich
and powerful individuals

00:02:09.081 --> 00:02:11.735
are able to keep their money offshore

00:02:11.759 --> 00:02:14.246
and not pay the taxes that they should,

00:02:14.270 --> 00:02:18.364
it means that there is less money
for vital public services

00:02:18.388 --> 00:02:21.741
like healthcare, education, roads.

00:02:21.765 --> 00:02:24.086
And that affects all of us.

00:02:24.110 --> 00:02:26.826
Now, for my organization Global Witness,

00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:30.912
this exposé has been phenomenal.

00:02:30.936 --> 00:02:35.424
We have the world's media
and political leaders

00:02:35.448 --> 00:02:40.103
talking about how individuals
can use offshore secrecy

00:02:40.127 --> 00:02:42.522
to hide and disguise their assets --

00:02:42.546 --> 00:02:47.330
something we have been talking about
and exposing for a decade.

00:02:47.354 --> 00:02:51.989
Now, I think a lot of people find
this entire world baffling and confusing,

00:02:52.013 --> 00:02:56.478
and hard to understand how
this sort of offshore world works.

00:02:56.502 --> 00:02:59.334
I like to think of it a bit
like a Russian doll.

00:02:59.358 --> 00:03:02.817
So you can have one company
stacked inside another company,

00:03:02.841 --> 00:03:04.952
stacked inside another company,

00:03:04.976 --> 00:03:09.387
making it almost impossible
to really understand

00:03:09.411 --> 00:03:11.638
who is behind these structures.

00:03:11.662 --> 00:03:14.575
It can be very difficult
for law enforcement

00:03:14.599 --> 00:03:17.562
or tax authorities,
journalists, civil society

00:03:17.586 --> 00:03:19.848
to really understand what's going on.

00:03:20.276 --> 00:03:21.713
I also think it's interesting

00:03:21.737 --> 00:03:24.944
that there's been less coverage
of this issue in the United States.

00:03:24.968 --> 00:03:28.731
And that's perhaps because
some prominent US people

00:03:28.755 --> 00:03:33.293
just haven't figured
in this exposé, in this scandal.

00:03:33.317 --> 00:03:37.252
Now, that's not because
there are no rich Americans

00:03:37.276 --> 00:03:40.086
who are stashing their assets offshore.

00:03:40.110 --> 00:03:43.932
It's just because of the way
in which offshore works,

00:03:43.956 --> 00:03:47.446
Mossack Fonseca has fewer
American clients.

00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:50.726
I think if we saw leaks
from the Cayman Islands

00:03:50.750 --> 00:03:54.401
or even from Delaware
or Wyoming or Nevada,

00:03:54.425 --> 00:04:00.217
you would see many more cases
and examples linking back to Americans.

00:04:00.241 --> 00:04:06.159
In fact, in a number of US states
you need less information,

00:04:06.183 --> 00:04:10.357
you need to provide less
information to get a company

00:04:10.381 --> 00:04:13.174
than you do to get a library card.

00:04:13.198 --> 00:04:18.980
That sort of secrecy in America
has allowed employees of school districts

00:04:19.004 --> 00:04:20.910
to rip off schoolchildren.

00:04:20.934 --> 00:04:25.830
It has allowed scammers
to rip off vulnerable investors.

00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:30.100
This is the sort of behavior
that affects all of us.

00:04:30.124 --> 00:04:31.995
Now, at Global Witness,

00:04:32.019 --> 00:04:35.280
we wanted to see what this
actually looked like in practice.

00:04:35.304 --> 00:04:37.717
How does this actually work?

00:04:37.741 --> 00:04:38.916
So what we did

00:04:38.940 --> 00:04:45.177
is we sent in an undercover investigator
to 13 Manhattan law firms.

00:04:45.721 --> 00:04:49.495
Our investigator posed
as an African minister

00:04:49.519 --> 00:04:53.646
who wanted to move suspect funds
into the United States

00:04:53.670 --> 00:04:56.809
to buy a house, a yacht, a jet.

00:04:57.246 --> 00:05:02.307
Now, what was truly shocking
was that all but one of those lawyers

00:05:02.331 --> 00:05:06.924
provided our investigator with suggestions

00:05:06.948 --> 00:05:08.912
on how to move those suspect funds.

00:05:08.936 --> 00:05:10.748
These were all preliminary meetings,

00:05:10.772 --> 00:05:13.044
and none of the lawyers
took us on as a client

00:05:13.068 --> 00:05:15.357
and of course no money moved hands,

00:05:15.381 --> 00:05:18.839
but it really shows the problem
with the system.

00:05:18.863 --> 00:05:20.782
It's also important

00:05:20.806 --> 00:05:24.172
to not just think about this
as individual cases.

00:05:24.196 --> 00:05:26.409
This is not just about
an individual lawyer

00:05:26.433 --> 00:05:30.287
who's spoken to our undercover
investigator and provided suggestions.

00:05:30.311 --> 00:05:33.166
It's not just about
a particular senior politician

00:05:33.190 --> 00:05:34.819
who's been caught up in a scandal.

00:05:34.843 --> 00:05:37.899
This is about how a system works,

00:05:37.923 --> 00:05:43.866
that entrenches corruption,
tax evasion, poverty and instability.

00:05:43.890 --> 00:05:45.705
And in order to tackle this,

00:05:45.729 --> 00:05:47.400
we need to change the game.

00:05:47.424 --> 00:05:49.946
We need to change the rules of the game

00:05:49.970 --> 00:05:51.962
to make this sort of behavior harder.

00:05:51.986 --> 00:05:54.930
This may seem like doom and gloom,

00:05:54.954 --> 00:05:56.875
like there's nothing we can do about it,

00:05:56.899 --> 00:05:58.529
like nothing has ever changed,

00:05:58.553 --> 00:06:01.889
like there will always be rich
and powerful individuals.

00:06:01.913 --> 00:06:04.360
But as a natural optimist,

00:06:04.384 --> 00:06:07.862
I do see that we are starting
to get some change.

00:06:07.886 --> 00:06:09.761
Over the last couple of years,

00:06:09.785 --> 00:06:13.453
we've seen a real push towards
greater transparency

00:06:13.477 --> 00:06:15.311
when it comes to company ownership.

00:06:15.713 --> 00:06:18.050
This issue was put on the political agenda

00:06:18.074 --> 00:06:20.568
by the UK Prime Minister David Cameron

00:06:20.592 --> 00:06:25.352
at a big G8 Summit that was held
in Northern Ireland in 2013.

00:06:25.830 --> 00:06:30.180
And since then, the European Union
is going to be creating

00:06:30.204 --> 00:06:32.361
central registers at a national level

00:06:32.385 --> 00:06:35.792
of who really owns and controls
companies across Europe.

00:06:35.816 --> 00:06:40.495
One of the things that is sad is that,
actually, the US is lagging behind.

00:06:40.916 --> 00:06:43.616
There's bipartisan legislation
that had been introduced

00:06:43.640 --> 00:06:45.543
in the House and the Senate,

00:06:45.567 --> 00:06:48.724
but it isn't making as much progress
as we'd like to see.

00:06:48.748 --> 00:06:51.835
So we'd really want to see
the Panama leaks,

00:06:51.859 --> 00:06:55.653
this huge peek into the offshore world,

00:06:55.677 --> 00:07:00.729
be used as a way of opening up
in the US and around the world.

00:07:00.753 --> 00:07:05.543
For us at Global Witness,
this is a moment for change.

00:07:05.908 --> 00:07:09.656
We need ordinary people to get angry

00:07:09.680 --> 00:07:12.933
at the way in which people
can hide their identity

00:07:12.957 --> 00:07:14.870
behind secret companies.

00:07:14.894 --> 00:07:18.481
We need business leaders
to stand up and say,

00:07:18.505 --> 00:07:21.789
"Secrecy like this is not
good for business."

00:07:21.813 --> 00:07:26.193
We need political leaders
to recognize the problem,

00:07:26.217 --> 00:07:31.224
and to commit to changing the law
to open up this sort of secrecy.

00:07:31.597 --> 00:07:34.876
Together, we can end the secrecy

00:07:34.900 --> 00:07:37.957
that is currently allowing tax evasion,

00:07:37.981 --> 00:07:41.172
corruption, money laundering to flourish.
